title: The Shocking Life of Africa‚Äôs Extreme Tribes (Ethiopia)
description:
Welcome to the captivating realm of the OMO VALLEY, a destination that is full of culture and stunning landscapes in Southwestern Ethiopia.  The prehistoric valley is known to be the birthplace of humanity (literally where the first humans originated from), and today, it remains a place where 8 indigenous communities are thriving.

I came back to the Omo Valley (for the first time in 6 years) and I am telling you the amazing story of these extreme tribes, who have some of the most painful rituals known to man such as lip piercing and bull jumping!

What do you think about the Omo Valley? Would you ever come here?  

#africa #ethiopia #humanity

title: How I Got Scammed in Sierra Leone
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

This is NOT a story that I'm proud to share with you, but nonetheless, it's very important that it gets told.  

This trip of traveling across West Africa in our own vehicle has been a nightmare in pretty much every category.  We are trying to look past the negatives and stay positive, but it's impossible when situations like this are happening to us every day at every single border crossing and police checkpoint.

The level of corruption and bribery is out of this world, and we've experienced the worst here today on the border of Liberia entering Sierra Leone.  We were scammed because we didn't have a cholera shot (which is 100% NOT the requirement, only yellow fever is).  We were asked to pay $350, which we eventually settled at $150 (for 3 of us), and the worst part is that this money went directly into these corrupt officials' pockets.  

These guys, in full uniforms, are bandits.  Thieves.  And it makes me depressed thinking about it.  I feel defeated.   But we are moving on.

Thanks for watching.  Join my trip in real time on IG Stories: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

#scam #travel #africa

title: 2 WEEKS IN VENEZUELA (full documentary)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Best Flight Hacks FREE! https://bit.ly/32sVpQV

Venezuela is one of the most dangerous countries in the world‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs also one of the most beautiful.  I was lucky enough to recently spend 2 full weeks there - from Caracas to Chuao - traveling alongside my local friend Emmanuel.  This video is a full-length documentary about our trip.   I dig deep into the economic crisis to tell you why a Big Mac costs $17 Million Venezuelan Bolivares and how the minimum wage is $1 USD per month. I explore stunning fishing villages along the Caribbean coast, meet the most hospitable and down-to-earth people, and try delicious food (AREPAS!). I enter the most dangerous slum in the world called Petare, and I also show you what the luxury side of Venezuela looks like. 

Join me in this incredible documentary, that gives you a unique look at the good, the bad and the ugly of my favorite country in Latin American nation. 

THIS IS VENEZUELA.

title: Exploring an Abandoned Soviet Town in the Arctic (Barentsburg)
description:
‚úÖ Watch BTS of this story: https://bit.ly/3WKvk72
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://www.drewbinsky.com/bestphotos

Did you know that there is an abandoned Russian settlement in the Arctic called Barentsburg?  Wait until you see this story, it will blow your mind!!

I had to take a 2-hour boat ride from Longyearbyen (the biggest town in Svalbard) which is under Norwegian control, over to Barentsburg (the second-biggest town in Svalbard) which is under Russian control.

The two towns could not be any more different. 

After visiting 169 countries and more than 500 cities, I find Barentsburg to be the absolute most bizarre town in the world.   

It was purchased by the Soviet Union about 90 years ago from the Dutch because of the on-site coal mine... While there are about 400 Russian & Ukrainian miners still working here today, it's a failing business, and it's obvious that Russia keeps this place alive because they want a presence in the Arctic (think natural resources, trade routes, etc).  

Walking around Barentsburg gave me flash backs to North Korea.  Abandoned buildings.  Seemingly staged people and culture.   I still can't quite wrap my head around this!

If you enjoyed this video, please share it!  It's one of my top 10 favorites of all time.

#abandoned  #adventure #travel

title: North India vs. South India | What's The Difference?
description:
On my last trip to India, I visited only the North and that's what I thought all of India was like.  

This trip, I did only the South and it's completely opposite from the North in every way imaginable!

The best way to think about India is like Europe.  When you move from one Indian state to the next -- the culture, cuisine, language and weather all change in the same way that you'd experience by hopping European countries. 

Have you ever been to India?  What do you think are the biggest differences between the North and the South?  Please share your thoughts below!

title: 5 Things I Love About Muslim Culture (As A Jew)
description:
I am Jewish.  As a kid, I was always told that Muslims are bad people.  I was brainwashed to be intimidated by them. 

But then, I visited dozens of Muslim countries, and I realized that they are THE MOST amazing, humble, and hospitable people on this earth.

The truth is that roughly 1/4th of the world is Muslim. So if Islam was a religion of "violence," then there would be no people left on earth. 

This video explains my honest feelings for the Muslim World, and I hope you will listen to every word I say because it's 100% the truth.

title: Entering The Land of LADYBOYS (Thailand)
description:
Ladyboys, or transgenders, are extremely common in Thailand and you will see them everywhere ‚Äî on the streets, on the metro, in restaurants, and especially in nightlife areas. Many times, you won't even notice it's a ladyboy, since they look like beautiful women.

The reason I made this video is to A) educate you about the ladyboy culture in Thailand and B) tell you how accepting Thailand is to treat them like normal members of society. It's remarkable.

As you and I both know, dozens and dozens of countries in today's world are moving in the opposite direction toward acceptance of those in the LGBTQ community ‚Äî so this video can be a lesson to the world. 

They are just people ‚Äî let them live their lives. 

What are your thoughts on ladyboys? Would love to get your opinions. Thank you

#transgender #lgbt #thailand 

P.S... P.S. - I apologize for my hoarse voice ‚Äî I picked up some infection and it went straight to my throat!

title: I Visited the Only America-Town in China
description:
Somewhere in rural China, there‚Äôs a replica city that is straight out of the American Wild West ‚Äì Welcome to Jackson Hole, China!  With a jaw-dropping $170 million invested to recreate that classic cowboy vibe in Wyoming, I knew that I had to see this for myself. Is it really as ‚ÄúAmerican‚Äù as they claim? Are people actually living there, or is it a ghost town?  

To help me get to the bottom of it, I teamed up with my friend Rachel, a fellow American who‚Äôs been living in China for 8 years and speaks conversational Mandarin. Together, we‚Äôre diving into this strange town to uncover the truth ‚Äì from cowboy hats to horse riding to sizzling steaks, we‚Äôre exploring just how wild (and weird) this ‚ÄúWestern‚Äù town really is.

title: What is a Chukudu? (Only in D.R. Congo)
description:
All over the city of Goma in Eastern Congo, I've been seeing these unique two-wheeled handmade bicycles made of wood.  

They're called chukudus, and I learned that they're a major way that people transport goods around town. 

The kicker?  There is no engine or pedals! 

Given that Goma is so hilly, chukudus simply rolls down the hills and then you need to manually push it up.  Every single time.

It's a fascinating part of Goma's culture and I wanted to share it with you in today's video!

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG Stories for more from the DRC! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

#congo #africa #transport

title: These Are The World's Emptiest Countries
description:
Most of the time you'll see me traveling in densely-populated countries like Singapore or Pakistan or South Korea -- but that doesn't mean I don't enjoy getting out in nature!  The truth is that even with a global population of 8 billion, our world is filled with remote places which are fascinating to visit.  In a sense, they are my escape from reality.  

In today's video, we learn about some of the world's emptiest countries per capita:  NAMIBIA, MONGOLIA, GREENLAND, AUSTRALIA, and SURINAME.

In some of these countries, you will find an average of 1 or 2 people living per square kilometer -- now that sounds like a great escape, (especially these days) -- doesn't it?!

Have you been to any of these countries before?

title: 10 Wacky Things About TURKMENISTAN
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

It's been a wild several days in Turkmenistan.  In my opinion, this is (by a long shot) the world's most bizarre country. 

In this video, I explain the 10 strangest things that I find about Turkmen culture -- from the thousands of white-marble buildings to the shockingly empty streets, a massive fire crater in the desert that hasn't stopped burning for 50 years, and the heavy censorship of the internet. 

Turkmenistan is essentially the "North Korea of Central Asia."  Both the capital cities of Pyongyang and Ashgabat feel eerily similar when walking around.  The only major difference is that the people of North Korea are oppressed, whereas the people of Turkmenistan seem to be warm, friendly, and hospitable.

Please share any thoughts/comments/questions about Turkmenistan and I'll be happy to answer!

#turkmenistan #asia #travel

title: Entering Mogadishu as an American Tourist
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

I can't believe I'm in Somalia's capital of Mogadishu.  It has essentially been the most dangerous city in the world for the last 3 decades, due to the ongoing Civil War which began started in 1991.  Tourism is almost nonexistent, and if you do come, then you must take precautions and follow the rules given to you at all times. 

BUT once I have looked past all the military checkpoints and I've gotten over my initial anxiety of being here, I am seeing an amazing culture with some of the kindest people I've ever met.   And shall we talk about the beaches?  Somalia has the longest coastline in Africa with some of the most stunning coastlines I've ever seen! 

I won't say anything further, as I'll let the video speak for itself.  If you've ever been to Mogadishu or Somalia, or are considering going there, then please comment below and we can get some conversation started. 

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG STORIES for more content from Mogadishu over the coming days: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: Spending $1 in 10 Different Countries (Budget Travel)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Did you know that what $1 USD can buy in one country is never the exact same as in another?  

While this may seem like an obvious statement to you, it's a huge concept in economics called purchasing power parity.   Ever since I studied economics in college, I've been fascinated by comparing different countries' currencies and this is actually what inspired me to create my $10 series (which I've done in 37 countries now!).

In today's video, join me as I show you what $1 can get you in 10 countries worldwide: USA, Bangladesh, Uganda, Czech Republic, Vietnam, Syria, Slovenia, Pakistan, France and the Dominican Republic.

title: Entering Asia's Only Latin Town (They Speak Spanish)
description:
I finally made it down to ZAMBOANGA, a lovely town in the very Southwestern corner of the Philippines! 

Believe it or not, they speak SPANISH here!  Well, it's not 100% Spanish, it's called Chabacano which is more of a Creole (mixed) dialect that developed when the Spaniards settled here almost 500 years ago.  

Not surprisingly, Zamboanga is dubbed "Asia's Latin Town" for its strong roots in Spanish culture that can be seen not only in the language but also in the cuisine and lifestyle.  

I've had a GREAT time here so far and I hope this video opens your eyes to a lesser-known part of the Philippines -- my favorite country in the world. 

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG STORIES for more: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: Meeting the World's Shortest Humans (4 Feet Tall)
description:
After 4 years, I went back to visit the PYGMIES - who are genetically the shortest group of people in the world.  The last time I met the pygmies, I was alone in the Central African Republic, and this time, I went deep into the Democratic Republic of Congo (4,000 miles away) with Deanna and our local friend, Obed. 

The journey was not easy, as we battled flat tires, massive thunderstorms, and my camera nearly getting stolen from someone at a street market in Bukavu (the 3rd biggest city in the DR Congo). But the payoff in the end was pure magic - the pygmies are so welcoming and fun! They literally danced around the fire while beating the drums from the moment we met until we left (15 hours straight).  

This is one of those stories and experiences that (when it's all said and done), I will be remembered for. It is a pleasure to share this story with you, that my team and I spent 5 weeks editing, and I hope that you enjoy!  And don't forget to subscribe for more stories like this one! http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

If you want to visit the DR Congo with Obed, contact him on IG: kumbukumbtours

#travel #africa #humanity

title: Afghanistan is NOT What You Think! (Full Documentary)
description:
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://www.drewbinsky.com/bestphotos
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

Are you ready to discover the hidden gems of Afghanistan? Join me on an inspiring 5 week journey through this complex country, as I uncover the beauty, culture and resilience of the Afghan people.

From the bustling streets of Kabul to the tranquil villages nestled in the mountains, this video takes you on a journey through Afghanistan's diverse landscapes and rich history.

You'll get a glimpse into the daily lives of the Afghan people, as we visit local markets, explore ancient ruins, and meet with artisans and craftspeople who are keeping traditional Afghan culture alive.

One of the highlights of my journey was a visit to the iconic Blue Mosque in Mazar-i-Sharif, a stunning architectural masterpiece with a rich history. I also experience the stunning natural beauty of Bamiyan and the Hazara people, who have been living in the region for centuries.

Throughout the video, you'll see the resilience of the Afghan people, who have faced decades of conflict and hardship, yet continue to persevere and find hope for the future.

This video is a must-see for anyone looking to gain a deeper understanding of Afghanistan and the people who call it home.  Countless hours went into making this film, and I'd love to get your feedback in the comments below.  How do you feel about long-form content like this? Your feedback is very valuable to me. Thank you, and please keep Afghanistan in your thoughts as they are going through a tough period.

#afghanistan #travel #middleeast

title: I Investigated The Village of Identical Twins
description:
Check out Bitwarden: https://btwrdn.com/401ffNW. It's the perfect, easy-to-use password manager to store, manage, and protect all your passwords in one place. 

In Nigeria, there is a village where almost every single household has twins. I didn't believe it was true, so I went there to investigate, and I hope you enjoy the story!

title: $10 Challenge in VENEZUELA (Crazy Inflation)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

After making 1,100+ videos in 194 countries, this is one of my favorite videos thus far! Find out what $10 USD can get you in Venezuela!  

In this epic adventure, I take you on the bustling streets of Caracas and through the beautiful beach towns of Morrocoy to see how many things I could purchase with $10 USD, which at the time I made this video, was 14.7 MILLION Venezuelan Bolivares... Right now, $10 USD is equal to 22 million Bolivares; it's absolutely crazy. 

Despite Venezuela's economic crisis and massive hyperinflation, the cost of everyday items is getting more expensive, which makes it even harder for the local people to afford basic things like bread and water.  It's really sad, and I hope the situation gets better because Venezuelans are some of the warmest and most hospitable people I've ever met.  More to come soon from Venezuela!

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from every country, and join me on Instagram for live updates from my trip: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: This American Town is Run By Druggies (Slab City)
description:
SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

Have you ever heard of Slab City, in Southern California?  It's an experimental town of about 300 outcasts who live without running water or electricity in the middle of the harsh desert.  I first heard about Slab City when my friends Yes Theory went 6 years ago, and it's been on my list ever since then... So I finally decided to go, alone, and I couldn't believe what I saw.

Join me as I take you on a journey through the heart of this extraordinary off-grid community, shedding light on its unique culture, art, and unconventional way of life that thrives in the remnants of an abandoned military base, known as the 'Last Free Place on Earth.'

Whether you're a backpacker or simply curious about this unique corner of the world, this story will provide an authentic look at what it's really like to visit Slab City.

#california #travel #america

title: Meeting the (Forgotten) Jews of Ethiopia
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

I'm back in Ethiopia for the 3rd time because it's one of my favorite countries in Africa!  I am now exploring a city in the North called Gondar, and little did I know that I'd come across thousands of fellow Jews.  

As you might know by now, I enjoy connecting with Jewish communities around the world, like I've done in Afghanistan, Yemen, Turkmenistan, Georgia, Philippines among many others  -- but this experience has been the most eye-opening because of how alive the Jewish culture is.  Some 4,000 Ethiopian Jews are here, studying torah, keeping Shabbat and learning Hebrew.  

If this is not a fascinating story, then I am not sure what is!  Join me as I take you inside the world of the forgotten Jewish tribe of Ethiopia.     

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG Stories for more behind-the-scenes of my trip in Africa! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: Spending 13 Days Alone in Syria (During the War)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Hey guys!!! Join me on an unforgettable and eye-opening journey in SYRIA as I embark on a 13-day solo adventure across one of the most conflict-ridden countries in the world. This is not your typical travel vlog, as I go beyond the tourist hotspots and dive deep into the heart of Syria, experiencing the culture, the people, and the everyday life in a way that few outsiders ever have seen before. 

From the ancient ruins of Aleppo to the bustling streets of Damascus and the lovely beach towns of Latakia, I capture the raw beauty and resilience of a nation torn apart by war. This is a side of Syria that you certainly won't see on the news, and it will leave you with a new perspective on the Middle East. Get ready to be moved, inspired, and maybe even a little bit scared as I take you on the trip of a lifetime. 

Follow me on Instagram for more travel updates in real time! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

title: His Best Friend is a Lion (True Story)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Simba, a 4-year-old lion, was born with a chemical deficiency -- the same deficiency that killed both his mother and brother.  

Luckily, a man named Azlan from Karachi, Pakistan, rescued him when he was 2 weeks old and raised him to live a happy and healthy life.  Because Simba has been domesticated and spoon-fed his entire life, he doesn't know how to hunt and would not make it alive if he was sent back to the wild. 

This is a beautiful story that highlights the companionship between a man and a lion.  

DISCLAIMER:  We do not recommend, endorse or promote anyone to own a pet lion, as it can be dangerous and detrimental to the species itself.  This is an exceptional case. 

More on Instagram! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

#Pakistan #lion #travel

title: Is This The World's Most Confusing Language? (Georgian)
description:
I have this obsession with learning languages -- at least a few words but likely more -- so I can communicate with locals and feel more connected to their culture.   

Few languages have boggled my mind more than what they speak here in Georgia.  It's my second time in this country, and I'm just as confused as I was back in 2015 when trying to grasp the language. 

And then I learned that the Georgian language is, in fact, one of the most ancient, unique and creative languages in the world! So I made this video all about it :)

Have you ever come across a language that you found particularly interesting?  Which ones?  Hungarian and Turkish always make me think!

title: This Ice Cream Doesn't Melt (Find Out Why)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Any ice cream lovers out there?  Prepare to get your mind blown when you hear about Turkish ice cream - IT DOESN'T MELT!

No matter where you go in Turkey, you can find men wearing traditional Turkish clothes, and serving fresh ice cream from a long metal stick inside of a deep bucket.  The consistency of the ice cream is incredibly thick, and it really does not melt!!!  Because of its thickness, the vendors will often play games with you when you try to buy ice cream, making you look like a fool on the streets in public. 

Today, I went to the city where Turkish ice cream was invented (Kahramanmaras) with one mission in mind -- to tell you the full story about how ice cream became such a popular thing in Turkey! 

Share this video if you love ice cream!

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram for more stories from every country in the world: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: These Are The World's Strangest Borders
description:
Join me as I tell you about some of the world's most bizarre borders, which will leave you scratching your head!! 

- NORTH KOREA v. SOUTH KOREA
- KALININGRAD, RUSSIA v. EUROPEAN UNION
- AZERBAIJAN v. NAGORNO-KARABAKH
- THE DIOMEDE ISLANDS: RUSSIA v. USA
- ANTARCTICA

If you ask me, borders (in general) are a strange concept.  Like hundreds of years ago, the notion of creating an imaginary line that separates human beings from one territory to another is weird -- and today, it seems as if borders are permanent.   What are your thoughts on borders?

title: My 7 Favorite Countries in Asia (I Went To Them All)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Asia has been my home since 2013 when I moved to South Korea to teach English. Over the last 8 years, I've lived in Vietnam, the Philippines and currently Thailand -- and I've been to every country on the beautiful continent of Asia.

Each culture in Asia is very unique -- from religions to traditions, nature, history, cuisines and rituals -- and it provides endless opportunities to learn and discover. But above anything else, THE PEOPLE of Asia are the most hospitable and welcoming as they come. 

Admittedly, it has been very hard to choose only 7 of my favorite Asian countries to feature in this video (because I truly love every place for a different reason) -- but when it all comes down to it, these would be my 7 favorite countries on this amazing place called Asia!

THE PHILIPPINES, SOUTH KOREA, SINGAPORE, VIETNAM, NEPAL, INDONESIA, JAPAN

What would be your top 7 in Asia? Why? Please comment below and let's get the discussion started! 

PS - I kept this video limited to East/South/Southeast Asian countries. While the Middle East and West/Central Asia are technically Asian countries, I consider them very culturally different. Iran and Tajikistan would be on this list if it was all of Asia!

#asia #travel #world

title: I Went to Greenland's Most Remote Town (Ittoqqortoormiit)
description:
WELCOME TO ONE OF THE WORLD'S MOST ISOLATED PLACES - GREENLAND!

Today I arrived in one of the world's most remote villages, way out here on the rugged North Eastern shores of Greenland.  It's called Ittoqqortoormiit (say that 5 times fast) and it's a fascinating place that feels like I'm on the moon!   

Very few outsiders have ever visited this village because it's so remote, and I'm lucky to be one of them on board this Hurtigruten expedition!

Ittoqqortoormiit has a population of around 350 and the nearest town is thousands of kilometers away.  The locals are called Inuits (the same ethnic group as Eskimos), and they survive from hunting and eating polar bears, walrus, seals, and whales.  

Could you ever live here? Let me know in the comments below!

#travel #greenland #arctic

title: I Tried to Exchange $100 in Venezuela. I Failed.
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

I'm stoked to have joined the Sony Alpha team (!) and I've partnered with them to GIVEAWAY 3 of their newest ZV-1 vlogging cameras.  To win: follow @drewbinsky and @sonyalpha on Instagram and comment 2 sentences below on what you'd do with the camera.  I'm also including a signed postcard from Venezuela and a 10,000 VZ banknote in each box. Yay!
------------
I recently hit the streets of Caracas with my local friends Gabo and Emmanuel to see if we could exchange $100 USD for local Venezuelan Bolivares.   At the time when I shot this video, $100 USD was about 170 Million Bolivares, but now at the time of posting, $100 USD is about 300 million Bolivares.  The currency has depreciated by almost 100%.  

We spent ALL day walking into small shops, bakeries, market vendors (etc) in Caracas and unfortunately, we were only able to exchange $62...  Yes, we really did have a backpack full of cash on our backs.  It was wild. 

The economic crisis in Venezuela is very sad and it's hard to comprehend what's happening.  And how fast it's happening.  I have empathy for the people here who are suffering to make ends meet, but instead of dwelling on the situation, it's been refreshing to see many of the locals being resilient and optimistic for a brighter future.    I made this video to give you a glimpse of real life on the streets of Caracas because I think it's important to give you an honest perspective. I love this city and country with all of my heart - it has the BEST food, hospitality and culture in all of South America üíõüíô‚ù§Ô∏è  If you're still reading this, I want you to know that I love you and thanks for supporting my channel.  I pour my blood, sweat tears into making these videos and I hope they are opening up your eyes to the world.  Happy Sunday and Mother's Day -- I love you, mom!

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from every country. https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: This Girl Can't Escape YEMEN (Sad Story)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

This is the story of a young girl named Fatima, who was born and raised in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, but was forced to move to Yemen 6 years ago.   

While most civilians in Yemen are doing everything they can to flee this horrific situation, she has done the opposite.  She went from living in a modern and peaceful country to an impoverished and dangerous one, and it's been difficult for her to adapt.  

Can you imagine being trapped in Yemen after growing up in an advanced society in Riyadh? As much as she wants to leave to study, she must wait until the situation clears up and the borders/airports reopen.  

This video also explains her perspective on what must be done for Yemen to overcome this disaster and go back to how life used to be 10 years ago.  It's a fascinating interview and I enjoyed hearing her thoughts.  I hope you do too. 

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG Stories for updates in Yemen in real-time: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

#Yemen #war #middleeast

title: Taking My Jewish Parents to a Muslim Country
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

I TOOK MY PARENTS TO TURKEY AND IT WAS AMAZING!  üáπüá∑ 

This was our 5th big international trip together, but it‚Äôs their first Muslim-majority country. Being Jewish, I knew that it would be an eye-opener for them, and it certainly was. 

We were led by our local Turkish friend, Anil ‚Äî starting in Istanbul, then heading down South to Antakya, Gaziantep, Kahramanmara≈ü, and Kilis (on the Syrian border). 

From the mouth-watering cuisine to the ancient historical sites and everything in between - Turkey is just FANTASTIC (seriously, one of my favorite countries in the world) and it was special to experience it alongside my Mom and Dad. I think that this was my favorite trip yet with my parents. 

And most importantly, they now have a different perspective on Muslims and Islamic culture!!! They can fully understand that Jews and Muslims are SO similar, and that‚Äôs a beautiful thing :)

I actually went to Cairo the first time in 2015 - way back when I was a budget backpacker and travel blogger (before I owned a video camera).  I was young and na√Øve and to be honest, I didn't have a great time here.

title: Meeting My Brother From Another Mother (in Africa)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Abdoul is a friend of a friend of a friend, and I‚Äôve had the great pleasure of staying with him in Bamako Mali over the last 3 days.  My brother from another mother!

He‚Äôs so nice that he gave me his bed to crash on and he is sleeping on the floor. Before I arrived, he went to the store and fully stocked his fridge, and bought me toiletries and even a traditional Malian shirt. He‚Äôs been driving me all around town and won‚Äôt let me spend a dime. This is hospitality at its finest.

Abdoul would literally take a bullet for me and we just met for the first time 72 hours ago. From the photo it looks like we have nothing in common ‚Äî he‚Äôs tall, black and Muslim, I‚Äôm short, white and Jewish ‚Äî but we‚Äôve deeply connected over several games of chess, eating pizza late at night and talking about American sports (which he loves).

It's people like Abdoul who keep me going in this journey to every country. Sometimes, nonstop travel can get stressful and overwhelming, but then I meet someone like him and everything becomes great again.

P.S. Abdoul would love to make some more American friends! Feel free to email him at boudoulfr@yahoo.fr

#africa #brother #travel

While wandering the streets of Kabul, Afghanistan the other day, I came across an old man named Haji, who is the last remaining person in the country (and likely the world) who still uses this ancient box camera to take portraits! ‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

My visit to the Seychelles has been underwhelming (if I'm being nice). The combination of bad weather and a public holiday has left me stranded with almost nothing to do, nobody to meet and no sites to see.

But amid all of my loneliness, I managed to find one small shop open in the capital town of Victoria, where I was kindly greeted by an Indian man, named Hari Haran, who was working behind the counter.

After speaking with him for just a few minutes and getting to know his life story (and struggles), I asked for his permission to record our talk and put it on my FB page. He agreed, and that is what you are about to watch in this video.  Can you believe that he works 365 days every year? Could you ever work 365 days in one year?

Listening to his story is a reminder to be thankful if you are happy with your job and are able to live closely with your loved ones. Unfortunately for Hari Haran, this is not the case.

Despite his tough situation, we managed to connect while having a very nice conversation. I'm telling you guys, the most rewarding part about traveling is getting to meet people from all walks of life. 

#seychelles #india #travel

title: She Was Sold from North Korea for $250
description:
When she was a teenager, Yeonmi escaped from North Korea to China.  What she experienced was horrible ‚Äî being sold as a sex slave by border officials, walking across Mongolia in the middle of winter and nearly dying of starvation.  

But Yeonmi made it out alive, and now she lives happily in Chicago.  She is outspoken about the terrible regime in North Korea and she voices her thoughts on her YouTube Channel and through various best-selling books.  I invite you to share your opinions about Yeonmi‚Äôs story and about North Korea in general in the comments below. 

Hope you had a very Merry Christmas and remember that freedom is not always free. 

I‚Äôll see you in the next year when I‚Äôm kicking off my Saudi Arabia videos!!!

title: I Went To A City Made 100% of Garbage
description:

Welcome to Garbage City in Cairo, Egypt! It's a neighborhood of more than 90,000 Coptic Christians, who have been living here and collecting garbage (to sell for profit) for nearly a century. title: What Can $10 Get in Iran? (Extreme Budget Challenge)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

It's time to bring back my $10 series for a 14th episode -- and this time, I am coming to you live from the lovely country of IRAN!!

As you may remember from my video a few days ago when I explained the confusing currency situation of Iran -- everyday life in this country is relatively cheap. I say "relatively" because as long as you can avoid the touristy hotels & restaurants, then you will be surprised by how far your money can take you in Iran! I'm talking about the same affordability level as in South East Asia (i.e. Vietnam, Philippines and Cambodia)... Yes, Iran is THAT CHEAP!

Join me today as I take you around the beautiful city of Shiraz, Iran to see how many things I can get for $10 USD (500,000 Iranian Rials).

Have you ever been to Iran? If so, what else do you think I could have bought with this money?

title: 3 Reasons I Won't Go Back to North Korea
description:
North Korea is the most isolated and interesting country in the world.  I had the chance to visit Pyongyang for 3 nights, 4 days back in April 2017 - and shortly after I left, Americans became banned from visiting.  To this day, I think that I'm one of the last dozen Americans to step foot in North Korea, and I'm glad that I'm here to tell the stories.  In this video, I share 4 reasons why I will never go back to North Korea. 

Just out of curiosity - have you ever been there, or are you planning to go (if you don't hold a U.S. passport?) Let me know in the comments down below!

title: Entering The World's Most Dangerous City
description:
Five years ago, I visited Mogadishu (Somalia) and experienced one of the most intense places I‚Äôve ever been. The city felt scary, unpredictable, and deeply wounded by decades of conflict, and to this day, I‚Äôve considered Mogadishu the most dangerous city on Earth.

So, why did I get the urge to come back?

Because I wanted to see what has changed. Is Mogadishu healing? Are things getting better? And most importantly, what do the Somali people have to say about their own future?

In this video, I return to Somalia‚Äôs capital not just to walk its streets again, but to connect with locals, ask tough questions, and share their voices with the world. This is a story of resilience, change, and hope in one of the planet‚Äôs most misunderstood cities.

Huge thanks to Young Pioneer Tours for arranging my trip and keeping me safe! If you want to visit Mogadishu, I highly recommend going with them! Book on this link: https://www.youngpioneertours.com/mogadishu-somalia-tours/

#travel #africa #somalia

title: 7-Eleven In Thailand Will Blow Your Mind
description:
It‚Äôs funny because where I grew up (Arizona), I never thought of 7-Eleven being a desirable place to visit.  The only reason I'd ever go to 7-Eleven is to fill up my gas tank and/or get a slurpee. 

But in Thailand (and many Asian countries), 7-Eleven takes on a completely new meaning.   It‚Äôs your one-stop shop for anything and everything you can think of.  7-Eleven is pretty much the World's Best convenience store in the history of mankind. 

Inside 7-Eleven, you can find (literally) thousands of unique food and beverage options ‚Äî but even beyond that, 7-Eleven is a place where you can pay your phone & internet bills, schedule mail for pick up, purchase sporting event tickets and grab all of your toiletries and cosmetics.  

Thailand alone has over 11,000 7-Eleven locations (the second-most behind Japan) and it does 500 billion Baht ($15B USD) in revenue a year.    It's hard to explain how incredible this store is unless you've been to Thailand (or Asia) and experienced it for yourself.

What are your thoughts on 7-Eleven?  Does anyone else agree with me?

#asia #japan #travel

title: I Met a Real Cannibal in India
description:
Watch the BTS of this video! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eLcg_KqGsSw&t=32s

Hi Friends! I have spent the better part of the last decade trying to meet a real-life cannibal, and I finally have completed my goal here in Varanasi, India.  For real! His name is "Baba" and he is an Aghori man who lives on the banks of the Ganges River - the site where more than 300 bodies are cremated every day and their ashes are thrown into the river.  Varanasi is the most spiritual place in India, and for Hindus, it's the holiest place to have their bodies burned. 

Baba explained to me the various reasons why he eats humans (spoiler alert: he said the heart is the best part of the body) - and what I discovered will leave you speechless. 

Thank you Shubham for taking me around Varanasi. If you need a guide to India, contact him! https://www.instagram.com/shubhxfilms

#india #hindu #asia

title: I Finally Made it to Every Country in the World!!!
description:
On October 29, 2021, at 1:31AM - I crossed the border into Saudi Arabia, MY 197th & FINAL COUNTRY which took me 11 years to complete!!! üá∏üá¶üôè 

I'm feeling lots of emotions right now, and it will take some time to digest over the next few weeks as I travel across Saudi Arabia, but I just want to say first and foremost, THANK YOU ‚ù§Ô∏è

Thank you to my better half, Deanna, for believing in me since we met 6 years ago.  Thank you to my loving parents and family for supporting me.  Thank you to all of my best friends for pushing me during the hard times.  Thank you to all the strangers and local tour guides I met, in faraway places, for keeping me safe and secure.  And most importantly, if you‚Äôre reading this, THANK YOU. 

I‚Äôm so grateful for this amazing YouTube community.  I want you guys to know that for the past 4 years, I've poured my blood, sweat, and tears into telling the best stories about people and culture.  And I am so freaking happy that you guys have been able to travel with me as I visited all 197 countries in the world.  Thank you for all your comments, questions, advice, and words of encouragement. Without you, I do not stand here right now, in tears, at the Jeddah airport. 

It has taken me 10 long years (almost exactly to the day) to achieve this goal, since I moved to Prague to study abroad in Jan 2012.  I was 20 years old back then. Now I am 30.  It‚Äôs crazy to think that I‚Äôve been on the road nonstop, roughly 3,600 days, without taking a break. 

But I made it!!! And I‚Äôm feeling as happy as ever.  I did it.  I FREAKING DID IT!!! I can now say that I have visited every single country in the world. 

This is not the end of Drew Binsky.  It‚Äôs only the beginning!  I will now be chasing the STORY, not so much the COUNTRY.  This means a bigger team that can help take my videos to the next level!  But there are a lot of exciting projects that I'm working on -- below are links to my favorite ones:

1) My 2nd YT channel is called ‚ÄúMore Travels with Drew Binsky,‚Äù where I will be telling you more inspiring stories around the globe.  Subscribe here: https://bit.ly/3vQNSFY

2) My Travel Hacking Course is live, Get the 1st Chapter FREE! https://www.drewbinsky.com/course

3) I am launching both a book and a docuseries in the next 1-2 years!   More info on the film can be found here: http://drewbinskydocumentary.com/

THANK YOU, ONCE AGAIN, FROM THE BOTTOM OF MY HEART.  I LOVE YOU!! THIS IS NOT THE END OF DREW BINSKY, IT'S ONLY THE BEGINNING!

title: Who Are The Amish People of America? (Pennsylvania)
description:
One thing I love about the USA is the diversity.  You can pretty much find people from all cultures, religions, traditions, and walks of life in this country of 330 million people.

One of the most interesting groups of people that I've come across is the AMISH.   They are traditional Christian Anabaptists who originally have Swiss German roots, and settled (mostly) in Pennsylvania in the early 18th Century.

I went to Lancaster Country, PA today to learn all about their way of life, and it's fascinating!  Have you ever heard of the Amish before?

#usa #religion #travel

title: They Make Bricks For $1 Per Day (Madagascar)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

This video takes you inside the harsh lives of brickmakers in Madagascar's polluted capital city of Antananarivo.

Over the last 3 days, I've seen several thousand people on street corners and in brickfields working their a**es off making bricks. The entire production cycle -- from digging deep in the soil to formulating the bricks, laying them out to dry, tossing them onto trucks and burning them in brick ovens. 

What I was seeing was so massive and intense that I decided to make a video about it on the spot. I went into the brick fields to interview several brickmakers in Madagascar to learn more about their strenuous lives. Special thanks to my new friends Ali, Dave, Nancy and Antonio for helping me translate -- this video (and all my others) would not have been possible without your help.

I want to get your opinion on something -- the most frustrating thing I saw today was really young kids (5-8 years old) tossing bricks for 10+ hours a day in the hot sun. Do you think it's morally right to force them to work labor-intensive jobs at such a young age? I don't. 

#africa #madagascar #travel

title: Meeting the Pygmy Tribe in Central African Republic
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

This is the hardest I've ever worked to find, plan and execute a story in terms of logistics, finances and production.  It took me 2 months to plan and 35 hours to edit.  It's also the longest video I've ever made, at 15 minutes, and I really hope you watch it all because I love this kind of storytelling.   It's the reason why I travel. 

The pygmies are a group of tribal ethnicities native to Central Africa (Gabon, Cameroon, DRC and Central African Republic).  About 900,000 of them in total are entirely dependent on the dense forest for survival.  Genetically speaking, they are the world's shortest ethnic group for unknown reasons.  

I just spent 24 hours with them here in a remote part of Central African Republic and I made this story from my experience.  Please note that I had full permission from the chief to make this story and he was very happy that I came, as you'll hear about in the interview after the credits. 

If you find this story interesting, please share it with your friends!   I also welcome your comments, thoughts and feedback!

#tribe #travel #africa

title: What Can $100 Get in World's Cheapest Country?
description:
WELCOME TO UZBEKISTAN --- Yes, it really is among the cheapest countries in the world!! I am beyond excited to be back here for the second visit, but this time is better because I'm with my beautiful wife, Deanna (it's our 74th country together!). Uzbekistan is just a magical place inside and out, with some of the most stunning ancient wonders and lovely, down-to-earth people that will just make you smile. We just spent 5 days touring around the country, visiting the cities of Samarkand and Bukhara, which date back to before the ancient Silk Road - and it has been wonderful!

Join us on a wild & spontaneous trip across the ancient land where East meets West - and we will document & show you EXACTLY how much money we spend by doing normal tourist activities.  I hope this video inspires you to visit Uzbekistan, I promise you won't be disappointed!

title: The Long Neck Tribe of Thailand
description:
I have finally met with the LONG NECK tribe of Northern Thailand - and they are truly some of the most fascinating humans on earth! 

As you probably know, my favorite thing to do when traveling is to discover and interact with the most local people I can find. To eat their food, observe their homes and experience first-hand how they survive. 

I‚Äôve spent quality time with the Himba tribe of Namibia, the Mursi tribe of Ethiopia and the Huli tribe of Papua New Guinea. But never have I seen women wearing dozens of heavy metal rings around their neck... until I came to Northern Thailand!! 

They wear the rings (traditionally) to protect from tiger bites, but also to differentiate from the other hi tribes of Myanmar/Thailand.. and of course, it‚Äôs also a beauty/fashion thing!

The long necks are actually refugees from Myanmar who crossed the border in the 18th century and never returned back home. There are some 40,000 of them remaining today, mostly up in the mountains near the Burma border. 

Have you ever heard about the long neck tribe? What do you think about their culture? Comment below! 

#travel #thailand #asia

title: Entering The 4th Poorest Country in the World
description:
The past few days in Antananarivo, Madagascar have been overwhelming, intense and eye-opening. And I apologize for the delays in posting these videos -- it's been nearly impossible to find decent enough wifi.

Madagascar, as a whole, is a beautiful tropical island with stunning greenery, giant baobab trees and unique wildlife (like lemurs!). It's also massive -- about twice the size of my home state of Arizona -- floating 250 miles off the southeastern part of mainland Africa. 

But putting the natural beauty aside, Madagascar is one of the World's poorest countries, with the 5th lowest GDP per capita. Walking on the streets of Antananarivo, I couldn't help but observe and analyze what I was seeing --- people just barely managing to survive, working labor-intensive jobs with very little pay.

My new local friends and I took a mini road trip to some outer villages, where I learned about the daily life of people working in the markets. Here's what I discovered. 

If there's any takeaway from today (and through travel in general) -- it is to appreciate the life I live. If you are reading this as well, consider yourself lucky because you have internet, which most of the people in Madagascar cannot afford.

title: I Tried Street Food in Afghanistan
description:
I've now spent over 3 weeks of my life in Afghanistan, and I have barely told you about the AMAZING food that exists in this country!   In fact, I would honestly say that Afghanistan has some of the most underrated street food in the entire world.  All of the dishes here are so delicious, so plentiful and SO CHEAP!

In today's video, I take you on the streets of Bamiyan (in the central region of the country) to try some of the best Afghan street foods - IS ANYONE HUNGRY OUT THERE?! 

Please note that this video was extremely hard to edit because just 2 weeks after I left Bamiyan, there were 2 massive blasts that destroyed the main marketplace, leaving 14 people dead and dozens more wounded.  100% of this video was shot in that exact marketplace, which is now in ruins, and I am just devastated.  

In any regard, Bamiyan (and Afghanistan as a whole) is one of my favorite places on earth -- the culture is so raw and authentic, and the people are some of the most hospitable in the world!  I am loving every second of this trip and I can't wait to tell you more stories from the wonderful country of Afghanistan. 

PS - Would you try any of these Afghan dishes? Comment below! 

Follow @Drew Binsky for more stories from every country in the world, and join my trip live on Instagram!  https://instagram.com/drewbinsky 

#DrewBinsky #Afghanistan #StreetFood

title: How This Man Got Kidnapped In Haiti
description:
Hey Guys!  So as many of you know, I went to Port-au-Prince (Haiti's capital city) a few months ago with my local friend & guide named Sean.  It was the single scariest trip of my life. 90% of the city is controlled by ruthless gangs, and going into the slums with Sean was a wild experience.  You can watch the full story of my Haiti trip here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vmM7SDGOQiQ&t=1s

About a month ago, my friend Arab @arab who makes great content about culture and street life, went to Haiti with Sean to shoot a similar story.  Unfortunately, both men were kidnapped by gangsters for 17 long days - and it spread like wildfire across international news. Thankfully, the two men made it out alive after paying a hefty bribe.  

I caught up with Sean just a few days after he escaped, and here is the full story. 

Check out Arab's channel for more of the story in Haiti: https://www.youtube.com/@UC8H9Zmx8CslalkliFegKXhQ 

#haiti #scary #travel

title: 3 Worst Travel Days of My Life
DO THEY LIKE AMERICA? (Pakistan, Afghanistan & Iraq)
description:
There seems to be a negative stereotype that Americans (and other nationalities) have against the Middle East/South Asia - specifically in regards to AFGHANISTAN, PAKISTAN and IRAQ.

And I was eagerly curious to see if it's true the other way around.

So over the last month, as I've traveled deeply into these 3 countries - I interviewed 14 random people on the street and asked them, "What are your honest thoughts about America?"

I think you will be surprised by their answers.  

Truth be told, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Iraqi Kurdistan have some of the most humble and hospitable people I've ever met, and it's about time that we chance our perception of these places!!  Share this video if you agree.

title: He's The Last Jew in Afghanistan (Crazy Story)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

UPDATE: Zablon managed to escape from Afghanistan during the Taliban takeover in August 2021. He currently resides safely in Turkey.  In any regard, I'm going to tell you one of the most interesting stories that I've come across in all of my travels.

Meet Zablon Simintov -- the last and only remaining Afghan Jew in Afghanistan.

As a successful entrepreneur in his early years (carpet trading) -- this man has suffered a lot over the last 25 years.  He was sent to prison camps by the Taliban, he got all of his carpet stolen by the Mujahideen overnight ($300,000 USD worth), and his entire family and friends left him behind for Israel, Europe, and the U.S.

But somehow, Zablon has kept up being an Orthodox Jew, and taking care of the only working Synagogue in the country.  He practices Shabbat, keeps kosher, and speaks Hebrew. As a Jew myself, this has been an absolutely amazing story to hear and we had a connection that I cannot explain.

Also FYI,  I found out Zablon yesterday and booked a last-minute flight to Kabul to try and find him (I originally wasn't planning to come to Kabul).  I am beyond happy that I did.

Join me as I share with you Zablon's full story, which I hope you enjoy hearing because this has been a VERY special experience for me.  It's one of my favorite videos that I've had the pleasure to share and it's a day that I'll never forget.

#jewish #afghanistan #religion

title: I Went to a Tiny Island That Has 24 Million People
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

I'm so happy to be back in Taiwan, one of my favorite nations in the world!  I was invited here by the Taiwan Tourism Bureau to cover parts of the island that I never knew existed, which led me down to the countryside to visit a few indigenous tribes.  Did you know that the indigenous Taiwanese were the original settlers of the Philippines and many other Pacific Islands?  I was fascinated to learn about this!

Along the 4 day journey around Taiwan with Deanna, I found it fascinating to see the difference between rural life and city life, which became the concept of this story.  We went to Taiwan's second-biggest city called Kaohsiung to uncover the differences between Taiwan‚Äôs rural areas and its bustling cities. I was mesmerized by the amazing temples and delicious food! Finally, we made our way to Taipei where I take you on a journey to understand the wacky (yet fun) culture and experience a night market - one of the singular best things about Taiwan.  

This is my Taiwan story, go create yours: https://www.mytaiwanstory.com/

P.S. - There are a few minor corrections to the video that I want to make - thank you to those who helped fact-check!

1) At 1:40: Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule from 1895 and left in 1945 at the end of World War II.
2) At 1:35: I misspoke - The Spanish and Dutch colonies were actually in the 17th century.

Thank you for watching and I'll see you next week!

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from EVERY country, and join me on https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

#Taiwan #Asia #travel

title: I Got Trapped in Pakistan For 7 Days
description:
While traveling through Pakistani Kashmir, I was caught in a terrifying moment...India launched a surprise military strike just one town over, and tragically, many lives were lost. All airports in the country shut down, and I found myself completely stuck in Pakistan for nearly a week. This video captures that intense, unexpected journey, but if I'm being honest, there are worse places to be stranded! I freaking love Pakistan! The people, the culture, the food -- this South Asian nation stole my heart yet again :)

title: 12 Wacky Things About Korean Culture
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

I love South Korea!   This video is looooong overdue.

I've spent more time in South Korea (22 months) than any other country besides the U.S.A.  I find South Korean culture to be one of the strangest, yet most exciting and fascinating cultures in the world. 

When I taught English in South Korea, I was living in a small village (called Jin-sa-ri) about 40 miles south of Seoul.  I was one of 4 foreigners in my town, so it's safe to say I know Korean culture very well... Nobody spoke a lick of English in my town, so therefore, I learned how to speak Korean conversationally.  I also trained to get a black belt in Taekwondo.  Some of my best memories in my early 20s are in South Korea. 

This video represents some of the most interesting and wacky things I find about Korean culture. 

Have you ever been to South Korea? Do you agree or disagree with any of my points?  Do you have any questions about traveling to South Korea? Let me know in the comments below!

#southkorea #korea #asia

title: I Took The World's Best Economy Class (Emirates)
description:
I've flown on more than 300 different airlines around the world, and no airline is better than the one I flew today, Emirates!!

(This video is not sponsored. I just want to share how incredible the experience is flying with Emirates!)

For many reasons, Emirates is always my airline of choice (I've flown them about 15 times) -- I'm telling you that flying Economy Class on Emirates is better than Business Class on most other airlines!

The entertainment screen on Emirates Economy has more movies, TV shows, documentaries, podcasts and live TV options for FREE than you could ever want. The food is as fresh as it gets. The flight attendants' hospitality and overall service on Emirates flights are on another level (especially when compared to any American-owned airline). 

Has anyone reading this flown Emirates before, and can agree that they are the best? If you don't think they are the World's best airline, then what do you think is?

#airplane #travel #emirates

title: They Don't Know Their Birthdays (Seriously)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

I have been shocked to find out that the vast majority of Yemeni people I've met on the streets over the last 5 days do not know their age or birthday.   

In the Western World, it's second nature to celebrate our birthdays and keep a close eye on our age... but none of these things matter in Yemen, and it's unbelievable to witness!

What I've come to realize (and my reason for making this video), is that life in Yemen is simple.  They don't have (or need) materialistic goods like fancy houses, cars, TVs, and phones.  They are perfectly happy with minimal things and spend their days with family and friends.  

This video represents a bigger lesson that I've picked up from my travels in general -- that the less money someone has, the happier they are.  Yemen is a perfect case study to prove my point.  

I am loving it here so far and I can't wait to see more from Yemen!

#yemen #birthday #travel

title: Could You Eat This Stinky Fruit?! (Durian)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Ladies & Gentlemen, it is my pleasure to introduce you today to the world's most polarizing, bizarre, and stinky fruit called DURIAN.

If you've ever been around it before, then you cannot forget the pungent aroma that you can smell from 50 feet away, and if you've ever tasted it, then that flavor sticks in your memory for eternity. But for all the lovers of this fruit, and believe me, there are MANY -- it's almost like a 'cult following' where people are extremely addicted to eating it. 

Durian is only found in Southeast Asia, where it naturally grows, and MALAYSIA is known to be the birthplace of the fruit. In other words, the durian you will find in Malaysia is the best in the world. 

Today, I met up with a wonderful Malaysian family in K.L. (whom I met 10 months ago in Seoul) and they took me out to their favorite durian 'warehouse' -- the mecca for durian eaters. To be honest, I enjoyed durian a lot more this time than my previous 6 or 7 times eating it! 

Have you ever tried durian before? Did you like it or hate it? Please share your thoughts below, I'm curious to know!

#travel #food #durian

title: He Makes $3,000/Day Mining Gold (Solomon Islands)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Somewhere in the Solomon Islands, a giant gold mine was discovered in 1997.  At the time, the locals had no idea how to properly mine gold... and now, about 3,000 people are making a VERY healthy living doing it.

From what I have seen today, digging for gold all day in this humidity (and heavy rain) is EXTREMELY difficult, but the best ones are making up to $3,000 a day.   For all you math wizards, that's over 1 million dollars a year.

Here is the full story of the gold miners in the Solomon Islands. Enjoy!

title: Why I've Eaten McDonald's in 60+ Countries
description:
Today I ate McDonald's in Uruguay - the 60th country I've eaten at McDonald's since I started traveling in 2012. 

Not only do the menu items change from country to country, but you'd be surprised by how much of a cultural experience it is across borders. Also, McDonald's always has clean bathrooms, A/C, strong wifi, outlets to charge my phone, and the McCaf√© is a nice working environment. 

Let me make one thing clear -- when I travel, I eat local foods 99% of the time. But when I'm overseas for months and months at a time, I get sick of the local food, and I resort to McDonald‚Äôs. And every time, it hits the spot. 

Have you ever eaten at McDonald's abroad? Do you agree or disagree with the points I made in this video?

Music : Audio Autix

title: World's Tallest & Smallest People (are neighbors!)
description:
Did you know that the world's tallest people (Dinka tribe of South Sudan) are living directly across the border from the world's shortest people (Pygmy tribe of Central African Republic?)

I find this to be one of the most fascinating things in all of mankind! 

I have been lucky enough to visit both groups of people over the last few months, and I wanted to share with you how fascinating it is that they are literally neighbors!

In many situations around the world, whenever you hop over a border, you'll find the culture/traditions/language/people to be quite similar, but in Central Africa, it's a totally different world!

This video proves that Africa is, unquestionably, the most diverse continent on earth, with so many unique stories to tell.  I can't wait to go back again soon!

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG Stories for more stories like this one! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: Traveling to the 14 Most Isolated Countries on Earth
description:
I think that the Pacific Islands (also known as Oceania) is the most underrated continent on our planet - it's full of life, beauty and culture!  I traveled to all 14 U.N.-recognized nations in the region over the last few years, and in this video, you are going to learn the most interesting things about EACH country - from Papua New Guinea to Nauru! I hope you enjoy meeting the amazing people and learning about the incredible wonders of the Pacific!

title: 4 Times I Felt The Most Unsafe When Traveling
My Honest Thoughts on INDIA (After a 3 Month Trip)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

I've recently been getting a lot of questions about India, and why I haven't recently been there... So I put together this video with my honest thoughts and opinions of the country after a 3-month solo backpacking trip in early 2015. 

I have a love-hate relationship with India, as it is a very complex and intense country to visit. The colors. The smells. The tastes. The feels. A complete sensory overload. Seeing the Taj Mahal was as amazing as tragic from the fatal bus crash I was involved in. 

India challenges you in every possible way, both physically and mentally. It brings out your true colors, your emotions, your thoughts -- and I learned more about myself in those 3 months than I have over the last 3 years. 

Luckily, I just discovered a ton of GoPro footage that I took on that trip (which I haven't ever seen until now!) Join me as I reminisce about this trip from exactly 3 years ago.

If you've been to India, I'd love to get your thoughts and feedback on my video. Can you relate to my experiences? What were your favorite parts and biggest challenges?

#india #asia #travel

title: What Can $10 Get in Kazakhstan?
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Kazakhstan is a fascinating country and one that is not often visited by tourists.  

Despite the freezing cold weather of -18C (-1F) when I visited, I managed to have a great time in the capital of Astana, and I was shocked to see how modern it is.   It is Kazakhstan's newly designated capital (1998) which moved from Almaty, and over the last 20 years, it has rapidly developed from basically nothing into an international hub with many skyscrapers and futuristic buildings.    

In this video, find out which strange new foods I ate in Kazakhstan, and what else I got for $10!

Please Note that this video is over a year old (I am reposting the entire '$10 series' as I only shared it on FB and not YT).  As you'll notice, the editing is not great and it moves way too fast, but I still wanted to share it with you anyways. As always, thanks for watching my videos!

title: Surviving the World's Most Expensive City (Luanda)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

WHO KNEW that the world's most expensive city for expats and tourists is Luanda, Angola?!  

That's right -- it's not New York or London or Singapore or Dubai.... Not even close. It's Luanda Angola --, and if you don't believe me, you can ask BBC News, CNN and The Guardian.

I am not kidding you that I just saw a 13'' Macbook Pro listed at $4,200 at an electronics store Luanda -- I just bought the exact same computer in Arizona for less than half that price! 

After spending the last 3 days in Luanda,, I've been surprised in many ways... but none more than the outrageous prices. You can learn all about it in this video. 

Just curious -- Did anyone about this before watching this video? Or is this totally news to you?

title: How I Got DETAINED Sneaking into North Korea üá∞üáµ
description:
This was the single scariest travel moment of my life - getting detained on the border of North Korea & Russia. Sitting in that military compound for 3 hours, alone, without my phone or my friends, was absolutely terrifying. 

As many of you already know, I am fascinated by North Korea. I spent 4 days in Pyongyang in 2017 and I can even speak the Korean language (I lived in South Korea for 2 years).  Not a day goes by where I don‚Äôt ponder about life in North Korea - the strangest and most isolated country in the world.

But Americans have been banned to visit North Korea since 2017 - a few months after I left. In fact, I think that I‚Äôm one of the last few Americans to step foot in the country. 

So I wanted to attempt to go back while traveling in Siberia.  And what happened to me is something that I‚Äôve never experienced and I‚Äôll never forget.

This is the full story of how I got detained on the North Korea / Russia border. The journey starts in the far Eastern city of Vladivostok.  

Thank you so much to my local friend Natasha for joining me on this wild adventure. Follow her YouTube videos to learn more about Eastern Russia! https://www.youtube.com/c/natashasadventures

PS - This video was shot 4 weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine. I do NOT support this unprovoked war, and my thoughts go out to our friends in Ukraine. We love you. 

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from EVERY country, and join me on https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: This Airport Turns into a Playground (Every Day)
description:
Welcome to Tuvalu! One of the world‚Äôs smallest and least populated countries in the world, located somewhere between Hawaii and Australia.  Less than 200 tourists visit Tuvalu every year, and it‚Äôs a special experience to be here and witness one of the most lively scenes in this world... which takes place at the airport every night around 5PM!

The one and only airport turns into a massive playground for kids and adults to play their favorite sports like soccer, basketball, volleyball, and rugby! 

Why?  Because the island is so small and there is literally no other place to play besides this airstrip!  

In every other airport around the world (that I've seen), it‚Äôs illegal to even walk inside the airport ground at ANY time‚Ä¶ but here in Tuvalu, it‚Äôs encouraged!

#airport #travel #tuvalu

title: Muslims vs. Jews | Are We The Same?
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Muslims and Jews... Islam and Judaism.  What do you think when you hear these words together in the same sentence?  If you're like most people, you will think of hatred and negativity...  But from my experiences traveling in Muslim-majority countries and openly telling everyone I am Jewish, I've had the opposite experiences.

I love Muslims.  They are amazing souls.  I've made many great Muslim friends over the years and I will continue to do so.  Growing up Jewish, I've realized that Muslims and Jews have SO MANY of the same traditions and values.  

I've been wanting to make this video for a while as the message is strong.  Please watch to the end, and share it with your friends if you agree that Muslims and Jews are the same.

Follow @drewbinsky on Instagram for daily travel stories. 

Thank you Umar for the incredible hospitality and Michael (@affinityadventure) for the shots.

title: The Smoking Problem of Indonesia (300,000 Deaths/Year)
description:
Did you know that 76% of Indonesian men are addicted to smoking cigarettes? 

Not only adults but some 30% of Indonesian children are reported to have smoked a cigarette before age 10.  THIRTY PERCENT BY AGE 10.

As a result, tobacco-related deaths are around 300,000 every year among Indonesians, and it's rapidly growing at a scary rate.

It's my 6th time in Indonesia and I can't help but notice how SO MANY people have cigarettes dangling out of their lips.   So I decided to make this video to raise awareness -- and maybe, hopefully, someday, the Indonesian government will see this and cut back.

What are your thoughts on cigarette smoking and how it affects your health?  Personally, I think it's a much bigger deal than I made it sound like in this video.  

#smoke #indonesia #asia

title: He's Going to Every Country Without Flying!
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Thor is one of the most ambitious and courageous human beings on this planet, and I'm glad to have finally caught him in Bangkok after 4 years of being internet friends!

This Danish man left his home in October 2013 with the goal to visit every single country in one continuous journey without flying on a single airplane.  So far, he's made it to 174 countries by means of container ships, trains, buses and taxis -- and he's done it all on $20 USD per day!

Just wait until you hear the rest of his story -- it's one of my favorites yet. 

Share this video with all of your travel friends, and let's root Thor onto the finish line!  

#travel #adventure #africa

title: I Visited World's Most Dangerous Slum (in Venezuela)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Thank you for making these travel videos possible by supporting my clothing brand, JUST GO.  Shirts & Hats available: https://shop.drewbinsky.com/

I JUST VISITED THE WORLD'S MOST DANGEROUS SLUM IN VENEZUELA and it was one of the craziest experiences of my life.  It's called Petare, and it's basically a sub-district of Caracas with a population of over 1 million people who live on the top of a mountain.  

None of my local Venezuelan friends ever had the courage to venture deep inside Petare before, but together we decided to give it a try and it was eye-opening to say the least.  We ended up making a local friend, Marquito, who showed us around, invited us into his home, and introduced us to his family & friends.  

There was one moment on the street where things got pretty tense, but other than that, it was safer than I expected and it was a humbling experience to meet with the people and feel their energy.  Even though they may not have much, they are very friendly and welcoming people and I would go back in a heartbeat. 

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from every country, and join me on Instagram: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: I Brought a North Korean to South Korea
description:
Ever since I took a class in college about ‚ÄúThe History of North Korea,‚Äù I have been obsessed with the country. In April 2017, I had the rare opportunity to be one of the only Americans to spend 4 days in North Korea‚Äôs capital city of Pyongyang. There's no question that it's the most isolated and interesting place on earth.

In my early 20s, I spent 2 years living and teaching English in Seoul (South Korea) and I fell in love with Korean culture.  To this day, I have a strong admiration for the entire Korean peninsula - its people, cuisine and lifestyle. 

When I heard about a North Korean refugee named Munho - who escaped only a few years ago and found asylum in Thailand, I immediately contacted him.  All of the 10 North Korean defectors that I've met in my life are female, with similar stories - so I knew this one would be special.  Munho and I chatted on What's App for more than a year before this story was actually filmed. 

Munho is an amazing guy and we had a BLAST wandering around Seoul together - comparing and contrasting life between North Korea and South Korea.  

This is the very first time that Munho has publicly shared his escape story, and I'd like to thank him for being so kind, humble and open.  He will be reading all of your comments, so please let us know your thoughts and reactions to this video, and to Munho's personal story!  Thanks for watching and see you next week!

#Korea #travel

title: I Made it to YEMEN (Crazy First Impressions)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Hello to all my friends, family, and followers -- I have arrived safely in Yemen and I will be exploring deep into the country by myself and one local guide over the next week.

Yemen is (by far) the most difficult country in the world to visit in terms of logistics (getting a visa, planning, etc) and staying safe.  I'm sure you are aware that since 2011, Yemen has been in a constant state of war.  Tourists are not welcome here, and it's extremely risky for any traveler to visit at this moment -- especially as both an American and a journalist. I am double at risk.

That all being said, I am beyond excited to have this rare opportunity to take you inside one of the most hidden and raw cultures left on earth.  My first 24 hours have already been one hell of an emotional ride (as you'll see in this video) -- and you will be hearing lots more over the coming week. 

You won't want to miss this series, trust me!

#yemen #travel #middleeast 

If you're on Instagram, join me on IG Stories for more updates: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: What It's Like Living in an Experimental Community
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

Have you ever heard of an "Experimental Community" before?  In short, it's a free-spirited residential area where its members follow an alternative lifestyle.   These communities offer a sustainable place for people to work freely on their skills, while sharing resources and having a common perspective of the world.

I've visited a number of experimental communities over the years, and in this video, I share with you my favorite three which are:

1. Auroville in India
2. Arcosanti in Arizona, USA
3. Sacromonte in Spain

What are your thoughts on experimental communities? Could you ever live in one?

title: I Made it to a Secret Country in the Amazon
description:
My last visit to Guyana (back in 2016) was not enjoyable, to say the least. I vividly remember my hotel receptionist locking the door at 7pm and saying that I couldn‚Äôt leave because it was too dangerous! 

But back then, I was young and naive, so I decided to give it another chance with new perspectives.  And this time around was a lot more enjoyable! Not only did I get to fully enjoy the street markets and tasty cuisine of Georgetown (the capital), but I also got to head down into the Amazon to meet an indigenous tribe and go hunting for anacondas at night!! 

I hope you learned a thing or two about the only English-speaking nation in South America, and I would love to hear from you in the comments down below.  Seriously - I read every single comment and your feedback is greatly appreciated so I can continue to improve the way I tell stories!

title: Is Pakistan Safe? I Went There to Find Out
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Top 100 Travel Pics FREE! https://bit.ly/3Fsk0qo

"Watch out for terrorists" ... "Why would you ever want to go there?!"...

These were some of the many reactions I received from my friends, family members and followers when I told them I was coming to Pakistan.

And all I can do is shake my head and laugh!!

I've been in Pakistan for almost a week already, and there has not been one instance where I felt unsafe.  The people of Pakistan are incredibly warm and hospitable, and they will literally break their backs to make sure that I am enjoying myself in their country.  

I've never experienced this kind of hospitality in my life. 

Am I saying that Pakistan is 100%?  Not at all.  You need to take normal precautions, just like you would do anywhere else in the world.  But what I am trying to tell you is that the reputation you've heard in the media about Pakistan is completely and utterly false.  

I am absolutely LOVING Pakistan so far, and I can't wait to see more over the coming 8 days!  

P.S. -- For the record, nobody told me to make this video and it is not sponsored by anyone.  These are my 100% honest feelings from my experience in Pakistan so far.  The truth is that I can never say enough about how amazing Pakistan is.  More coming soon!

#pakistan #asia #travel
