title: Panama's Native Tribe (Ember√°)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

This is the reason I came to Panam√°!! To witness the beautiful life inside one of their only remaining indigenous tribes called the Ember√°s.  

There are roughly 33,000 Ember√°s left in Panam√° and another 50,000 living just across the border in Colombia.   While they are not as remote as other tribes I've visited (such as the Pygmy tribe in Central African Republic or the Himba tribe of Namibia) -- the Ember√°s have a fascinating and humble lifestyle that is completely dependent on the rainforest. 

I just spent 24 hours living with one community of 24 families and I had a wonderful time.  Most of them can speak Spanish, so it was easy to communicate with them, and they were very kind, open and friendly!

No Coronavirus paranoid out here -- just complete bliss and happiness!

Stay safe out there everyone, and wash your hands.  We will get through this.

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram for more stories like this one! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: BANGKOK IS ON HIGH ALERT (air pollution)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky

Deanna and I moved to Bangkok 7 months ago for many reasons, such as the affordability, central location, great networking and tasty food.  There‚Äôs a lot that I love about this city and I‚Äôve been happy to call it my home‚Ä¶ until this past week. 

The city has been ENGULFED in the worst toxic smog (air pollution) in its history, and it‚Äôs causing massive health concerns among the 15 million+ residents.  

The air is so contaminated that many of Bangkok‚Äôs public schools have been closed down for the past week.  A few days ago, it was so smoggy that I could not see 10 meters in front of me.   

This is not a joke and it needs to be taken seriously.  We (humans) created this problem, and now it‚Äôs up to us to prevent it from happening again.

title: Qatar on a Budget: What Can $10 Get You?!
description:
HELLO QATAR! It‚Äôs great to be back in this Middle Eastern country, in the wake of the World Cup! 

Qatar is a country known for its luxury and opulence, but in this video, my local Qatari friends and I are going to show you that you don't have to break the bank to enjoy all that Qatar has to offer. We've scoured the country to find the best deals and hidden gems that you can experience for just $10 or less.

From the bustling streets of Doha, to the souks and bazaars, we take you on a journey to discover the most surprising and budget-friendly options in Qatar. You'll be amazed at what you can find for just $10. From traditional Qatari cuisine to local handicrafts, and even a remote fishing village!

We also take you to some of Qatar's most iconic landmarks and tourist spots, such as the Museum of Islamic Art and the Souq Waqif. We show you how you can enjoy these places without spending a fortune.

And if you're looking for some outdoor activities, we take you on a desert safari and show you how to experience the natural beauty of Qatar without breaking the bank.

This video is perfect for budget travelers, backpackers, or anyone looking to experience Qatar on a budget. 

P.S. - If you visit Qatar, then check out the One Pass: https://www.qacreates.com/en/qatar-one-pass-offer. It‚Äôs an access pass to museums, restaurants, events, concerts and more!

title: I Met The Famous Street Bartenders of India
description:
Have you ever heard about the street bartenders of India?! Tonight around 9PM, while I was walking on the streets of Kochi in the Southern Indian state of Kerala, I heard extremely loud banging sounds.  It sounded like people were banging glass on an aluminum plate. 

And that's exactly what was happening.

I turned the corner to see about a dozen street bartenders, all between 16-25 years old, making drinks on the street.  The beverages are not alcoholic, mostly juices and shakes, but their bartending skills were SO DAMN IMPRESSIVE that I couldn't not share it with you.

India is one of the coolest, most vibrant places I've ever been.  I'm completely overwhelmed, in a good way.  Every place I look there is something interesting to see.  Something to smell or eat.  Thousands of things, everywhere! 

What's your favorite thing about India?

title: I Went to India's Scariest Festival
description:
‚úÖ  Don't forget to SUBSCRIBE to my channel by clicking here ‚ûû   https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0Ize0RLIbGdH5x4wI45G-A
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Watch my favorite videos ‚ûû https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLhiP3P44ul3Y8LDbhXJmhVsVWcpe-7O4O

I just attended India's most extreme festival and I've never seen anything like it before in my life - even after visiting every country in the world!  It's a 10-day festival called Dussera, and even though it's celebrated around India - no region is more intense than Tamil Nadu. 

It's hard to comprehend what I just experienced - people having exorcisms and going into an unconscious state of trance.  And the craziest part? I was the ONLY non-Indian at this festival of 100,000 + people, and this event has hardly been documented - by anyone! Also I appreciated that everyone at this festival was sober - that's how spiritual it was. 

What do you think about Dussera? Would you ever attend it? Let me know in the comments down below!  

Watch the BTS of this story here! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lBwCNv-2lmc

title: How North Korea Changed In 7 Years
South Asia's Oldest City? (Peshawar, Pakistan)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

From the moment we arrived in Peshawar, my eyes have been glued out the window and my heart has been beating fast.  I am in love with this place.

Peshawar is an ancient city in North West Pakistan -- almost on the border with Afghanistan -- that has a recorded history dating back to 539 BCE.

The culture of Peshawar is unique to anywhere else in Pakistan (and the world for that matter).   The way that people dress is different.  The cuisine is different.  The buildings are different.   

They get such little tourism that the people are extremely curious and welcoming.   

Peshawar is my kind of place, and I can't wait to show you more of this city over the coming days :)

title: MEXICO IS NOT WHAT YOU THINK (misconceptions)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I've spent 3 out of the last 5 weeks in Mexico and it has been truly AMAZING!! Before this trip, I had only been to the touristy coastal cities but the people and culture in this country are what makes it so special.

Unfortunately, Mexico has received a bad reputation over the last decade after some tourists went missing on their vacations combined with the uprising of drug cartels. 

Listen, there's no denying that some parts of the country may be a bit sketchy, but there are 129 MILLION PEOPLE living inside this nation and it's a lot more spectacular than you think.

In today's video, I debunk 8 common misconceptions about Mexico and tell you why this country is now ranked in my top 10 favorites in the world üá≤üáΩ

title: BIG ANNOUNCEMENT (Drew Binsky Documentary)
description:
Dear Friends,

I am very excited to announce that I will be making a 90 minute documentary, which will be shot from May-July during my final 6 countries (Palau, Saudi Arabia, Ghana, Ecuador, Venezuela, Jamaica).   

This is a project that I've been wanting to create for years, and after pitching it around to some top documentary filmmakers, I have teamed up with an awesome guy named Chris Wedding, who is based out of L.A.   Chris is the perfect fit to bring this idea to life.  He and another cinematographer will be traveling with me as I complete this ambitious journey to every country. 

This documentary will NOT be anything like my daily travel videos, nor a compilation of my travels.  You've already seen that through my videos. 

Instead, the film will take you behind the scenes of what it's really like to visit every country.  It will be personal.  You will hear from my family and close friends.   It will discuss things that I don't ever tell you, like my severe anxiety.  We will discuss how dedicated I am to work 15 hour days, 7 days a week for 3 straight years to create these videos, which have amassed 1.1 billion views.  We will talk about how social media (video making) has not only allowed me to finance my trips, but has let me connect with amazing locals -- and how I rely on their generosity to introduce me to their homeland.  We will dive deep into this 'every country' culture, as there are only ~200 people who have done it and many more on the way.   And LOTS more! 

If you want to stay up to date on our project, please follow us on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinskydocumentary/

Chris will be sharing a lot of BTS on his Instagram as well: www.instagram.com/look_see_do

I will be investing a lot of my time, energy and money into this project throughout 2020, and I couldn't be more excited to share it with you!

THANK YOU!!

title: The Unhealthy Life of a Full Time Traveler
description:
Constant travel is a lot more unhealthy than you think.  I am the most overweight, unhealthy and lazy I've ever been in my entire life. You might not realize this happening 'behind the scenes' -- but life as a nonstop traveler surely has its downfalls. 

This unhealthy travel lifestyle has come as a result of constant jet lag, changing time zones, climates, cuisines, frequent cases of food poisoning (like right now), a lack of working out, and most of my meals being either airplane food, hotel buffets or street food.

I've tried to start working out countless times, but it's almost impossible because I don't have a consistent routine when I travel. And it leads to a very unhealthy life.

Do you have any tips for me to stay healthy on the road? I would really appreciate it!

title: I Visited the 'Pakistan' of IRAN (Balochistan)
description:
I can't believe that I finally visited BALUCHISTAN! It's a region that spans Iran, Afghanistan, and Pakistan - but the majority of the area is completely off limits for tourists to enter. I had the rare opportunity to visit Iranian Balochistan with my local friend Amin, along with his friends Hamzeh and Shaquib. The 4 of us spent 72 hours meeting locals, eating delicious food, and seeing the natural wonders of Baluchistan. And all I can say is that it was FANTASTIC. It's definitely my kind of place and a trip that I will remember for a lifetime.  

As I get older and visit more places, I can tell you that life is far more interesting the further off the beaten path you go.  Baluchistan is as good as it gets.  Thank you for watching! 

If you want to come to Iran, then DM Amin and he can organize your trip! https://instagram.com/amin.riasati

title: The 5 Worst Traffic Cities on Earth...
description:
In the wake of the student protests for safer streets that's happening right now in Bangladesh, my mind has been stuck on traffic and unsafe road conditions.  Traffic is no fun for anyone -- it's huge time killer and in some places, sitting in traffic is extremely unsafe.  

While I strongly consider Dhaka to have the most dangerous traffic roads on earth -- there are many other cities around the world with overly congested and alarming streets. 

In this video, I share with you the 'Top 5 Worst Traffic Cities on Earth' from my own personal experiences. 

5. Delhi, India
4. Bangkok, Thailand
3. Kampala, Uganda
2. Manila, Philippines
1. Dhaka Bangladesh

Do you agree with my list? Which other cities do you think have traffic as bad as the ones I discussed here? Would love to get your thoughts.

And to all my friends in Bangladesh, we are still keeping you in our thoughts. I hope this violence nonsense ends soon, and that safer roads/laws will finally be implemented to better your society.

title: How to Visit IRAN? 10 Travel Tips
description:

Ever wonder how you can visit IRAN? Newsflash: Yes, you CAN visit as an American! 

In this video, I give you some inside tips and advice for how you can visit Iran (whether you hold a U.S. passport or any other) -- From getting your visas, to choosing the right season to go, and how to deal with the confusing currency (cash only) situation -- this video will answer all your questions about traveling to Iran. 

I have been on this group trip to Iran with G Adventures (the only way for Americans to get a visa is by going on a group trip) -- and I highly recommend them as the itinerary was fantastic. In my opinion, a group trip is a great way to maximize your time, especially in such an unfamiliar place, and you don't have to deal with any stress. Iran is truly an amazing country and I really hope you get the chance to experience it like I did!

Please comment below with any questions you may have about visiting Iran, and I will do my best to get back to you :)

title: The Real Life Burning Man... (Auroville)
description:
The biggest reason I came to India was to visit Auroville and make this video so you all can learn about this bizarre experimental community.  It's like burning man on steroids.

I seriously cannot believe what I just experienced.  A town of complete unity and togetherness, with 3,000+ residents who come from 57 countries around the world.   A cashless society that has no religion, no laws and a 0% crime rate.   A place where anything is possible, and encouraged, with the most laidback lifestyle I've ever seen. 

This is the real life Burning Man... and it's been around since 1968!

Have you ever heard about Auroville? What are your thoughts about it?

Instagram @drewbinsky.  Thank you Michael (IG @affinityadventure) for the shots & edits.  

PS - This video probably won't get the most views, but I had the most fun shooting it and putting this story together.  I love telling unique stories, such as Auroville, which are happening around our world.  If you have thoughts or comments on Auroville, please share below! I will be reading them all :)

title: I Found a Venezuelan Paradise Hidden from the World
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

I just spent 24 hours in the remote Venezuelan island called Chuao, tucked away somewhere on the beautiful Caribbean Sea.   Chuao was SO unexpected and beautiful... I am still pinching myself if this was a dream or if it was reality.

In this video, I take you on the journey to discover Chuao -- from the pristine, untouched beaches to the friendly, hospitable locals and the world famous cacao (which is soooo delicious!) This island is a paradise unlike any other I've seen through 194 countries, and I will absolutely be returning back here in the future.

Honestly speaking, Venezuela is NOT as scary as you've heard about on the news - especially when you get outside of Caracas.  Yes, there is a devastating economic crisis and massive hyperinflation, but that doesn't mean that you will get robbed or shot at by walking around on the street.  It doesn't mean that there are no restaurants to eat at or things to do.   Life does exist, somewhat normally, in many parts of the country just like here in Chuao. 

If you're still reading this, I want to say thank you so much for tuning into my videos in Venezuela.  I'm having a lot of fun on this trip and making these stories, and the best are yet to come!

Follow @drewbinsky on YT for more travel stories from every country in the world, and join me on IG Stories for live updates: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

title: He's the Master of DOODLING
description:
I'm very excited to share with you the story of Kerby of Sketchy Stories. 
 He makes a living from doodling with a pen and is one of the most talented artists you will ever see.

His doodles are so impressive that they've landed him gigs with Nike, Netflix, Warner Bros (among dozens of others).  His coloring books are sold in bookstores across 40+ countries and he is a NYT best selling illustrator.

But the focus of this story is not about his talent, fame or success.  It's about two things.. HARD WORK and PATIENCE.  Both of these things  led him to do something professionally that he loves.

Kerby does not come from a big city -- he comes from a very small town in the Philippines called Oas, which has only 67,000 people.  He did not attend a top University in Manila -- he went to Bicol University out in the provinces.

But he figured out a way to turn his passion into a career through hard work and patience.  Kerby is not "lucky" by any means for his success. 
He earned it.

If you feel inspired, then share this story with your friends to spread the message!  Because the truth is that anyone reading this right now CAN turn your passion into a career, and not the other way around.

Instagram @drewbinsky.  Thank you Michael (IG: @affinityadventure) for the assistance.

title: Why I'm at the SYRIAN BORDER
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

We have made it to Southern Turkey, and I am instantly obsessed with this place!!  It contains everything I love about the world -- amazing hospitality, delicious food, mind-blowing history and beautiful ancient wonders. 

My friend Anil and I have been exploring the ins and outs of Antakya and the Hatay province, which reminds me a lot of Syria given it's close proximity. 

Some of you guys may remember that about 10 months ago, I spent 2 incredible weeks in Syria -- and considering that the border is just a 1 hour drive away, I had to spontaneously go there and see what I could discover.  My curiosity led the way. 

It ended up being a really special experience to spend time in the border town of Yayladagi, where I was fascinated at the mix of Turkish/Syrian culture.    

Here is the full story from today, I hope you enjoy!

title: 1 Step Closer to PEACE w/ ISRAEL & PALESTINE üáÆüá±‚ù§Ô∏èüáµüá∏
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

**I made this video 3 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

Regardless of your views on Israel and Palestine, this video will widen your perspectives.

The tour that I just had of Jerusalem, by two natives ‚Äî Yuval (an Israeli Jew) and Samer (a Palestinian Muslim), was life changing to say the least. It's extremely rare to get a duel-narrative tour of Jerusalem, and I learned more than I ever thought I'd know about the history and politics of Israel & Palestine.

From hearing their real-life stories of growing up in segregated Jerusalem, which challenges they've faced, and how they connect to certain parts of the city ‚Äî to witnessing them being friends and colleagues today, treating each other equally and with respect ‚Äî is very humbling and reassuring, and this experience has restored my faith in humanity.

I know there are more Yuvals and Samers out there, either living in Israel/Palestine or elsewhere in the world, who treat each other equally and respectfully, despite their religion and/or differences. Maybe ‚Äî just maybe ‚Äî this video will spark a light that will start a movement towards peace for Israel and Palestine. I sure hope so.

This video was by far the most challenging one I've made - from the planning stages, to the on-site shooting (i.e. security checkpoints) and especially, the tedious editing process which took me pretty much 2 full days. I am proud of how it turned out, and I truly hope your perspectives have been opened, or you've learned something new by watching this video. 

I don't ask you to share my videos often, but I will kindly ask if you enjoyed it, to please share it with your friends and family to help me spread this message of peace.

I welcome your thoughts, opinions and constructive criticism (which I know this will get a lot of)‚Ä¶ But I'd like you to think twice about how you say things... If you are going to be an online troll ‚Äî full of hate and ignorance, and someone who causes further conflict through foolish comments ‚Äî then please turn your attention elsewhere.  I will only be responding to carefully thought-out comments, reactions and questions in this thread.

#DrewBinsky #Israel #Palestine

title: The Safest Country in the World? (MALDIVES)
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

It's a great day to be in THE MALDIVES, my 136th country!  I bet you never realized how safe this country is until you watch this video :)

The Maldives has been a dream destination for both Deanna and I since we met, and we are thrilled to finally be here and witness this natural beauty with our own eyes.

The Maldives is made up of roughly 1,200 islands in the Indian Ocean, of which ~200 are inhabited by locals and an additional ~100 are exclusive private resort islands, like where we are now at Kurumba Maldives.

Chances are, if you come to this country then you'll be staying at a safe private resort (they make up nearly half of all inhabited islands) -- And you will never have to worry about safety as a tourist  in the Maldives because crime on these islands is virtually unheard of.

I have not yet been to the densely populated capital of Mal√©, but I can imagine that it's not as dangerous as other capital cities of the world! 

Have you ever been to the Maldives? Did you enjoy it? More to come soon!

title: This Guy is SO IMPRESSIVE | Clicking Language
description:
Today, somewhere in the Namibian desert, I met an impressive guy named Frans. His native dialect is the clicking language!

He was born and raised in this dry, windy climate of stunning red sand dunes and wild-roaming zebras. And leopards. And wildebeests. And snakes. 

I was so impressed by Frans's desert survival skills and knowledge of 11 (ELEVEN) languages fluently -- including his native dialect of the 'clicking language' -- so it was impossible for me not to share his story with you.

One of the biggest motivators for me to continue my journey to every country in the world is meeting unique people and getting a glimpse into their daily lives. Frans is a perfect example of this. 

Music: Ben Sound

title: She's The QUEEN OF AFRICA (Wiyaala from Ghana)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I have just spent the last 3 days in a tiny village in North Western Ghana called Funsi and IT WAS SO AMAZING!  My buddy Wode Maya and I were invited up here by a local singer, songwriter and all around superstar named Wiyaala, and she was kind enough to show us everything around her beloved hometown.   

Wiyaala is on another level of inspiring and sincere -- after coming from humble beginnings, she achieved massive international fame after winning a popular singing contest in Ghana several years ago... and now her songs are played from speakers all over the world.  But aside from her musical talents, Wiyaala has the kindest heart as you will see in this video.  Despite financial success and freedom, she chooses to live here in Funsi with her family and friends.  After traveling to 192 countries, I can say with confidence that the people in this village are the some of the friendliest and most hospitable on this planet -- and this has been an experience that I will never forget.

Thank you Wiyaala for hosting us and for being such a blessing to this world.   I encourage all of you to listen to her music, just search for it on YouTube! 

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from every country in the world, and join me on Instagram:  https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: Taking the TRANS-SIBERIAN TRAIN With Strangers
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

This video was shot 4 weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine. I am devastated by what is happening and my thoughts and prayers go out to the victims of this war.  If you want to help, my friends @YesTheoryare currently in Poland and have started a GoFundMe to help Ukrainian refugees with food, water, and necessities. They have already raised $500,000, and 100% of proceeds are going directly to help save lives: Donate here: https://bit.ly/3N5jQGJ

Okay, now onto the description of the video... Riding on the Trans-Siberian Train has been a bucket list adventure for me for as long as I can remember (8 years?). The train starts in Moscow and then travels 10,000 kilometers Eastbound across Siberia until it ends in Vladivostok.  I was lucky enough to catch Trans-Siberian train for a 30-hour leg ‚Äì from Irkutsk to Novosibirsk ‚Äì and it was one of the wildest travel experiences of my life.  Even in the middle of winter, where temperatures were around -30C, I couldn‚Äôt believe how scenic the views were out the window. It felt like a dream! 

On the Trans-Siberian train, I met two incredible characters ‚Äì Gregory (the train conductor) and Sacha (the drunk passenger) who I shared the entire experience with.  I will never forget this train ride.  It was the journey of a lifetime, and I can‚Äôt wait to (hopefully) finish the rest of the adventure someday soon.  Siberia is truly a remarkable place.  Thank you for watching.

title: The Most INSPIRING MAN (Millionaire Mindset)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I've spent the last 3 days in South Sudan with Bashar and this guy is truly one of a kind.  We got connected through Instagram about a month ago, and I didn't know much about him or his story until I slowly discovered it as we've been roaming around Juba (the capital city).

Long story short, he grew up very poor without ever stepping inside a school, taught himself IT from YouTube videos and worked his way up the chain to run a multi-million dollar business in South Sudan.  

Not only that, but he gives back a large amount of his wealth to fully support his parents and 14 siblings back home.   

Special thanks to you, Bashar, for showing me around your city and I can't wait to meet again sometime soon!

title: I Went To The Seychelles And Had A Terrible Time
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Today, in the Seychelles, has been a complete disaster. Nothing has gone right. And I am very frustrated.

This morning, I woke up at 5AM ready to explore Mah√© island (the main island of the Seychelles), but a rain storm came rolling through which forced me to delay the morning start until 9:30. When I hopped on the bus to the beach, there was a bad car accident in the road, causing another hour delay and everybody freaking out. Finally, I made it to the beach, only to discover everything being closed because it's a National Holiday today in the Seychelles. So I went to the capital town of Victoria, which was more like a ghost town as no restaurants or stores are open. I managed to find a small shop to get snacks, and while I was inside the store, I witnessed a bad street fight happening between two drunk people outside.  That's what I call a disaster in the Seychelles.

Despite being really frustrated and upset, I realized that none of these events have been in my control -- and that's why I should not hate the Seychelles.

This also is a reminder not hate ANY place based on unexpected events that happen out of your control (bad weather, breaking your arm, public holidays, etc).

Similar unfortunate events have happened to me in other countries, like Bulgaria, Brunei and India -- and when these situations happen, we need to be mature and move on. It's all part of the travel experience.

While 95% of my videos are positive and happy, I think it's important to show you the negative (more realistic) side of travel like my experience in the Seychelles... Because truth be told, for every good experience that happens on the road, something bad happens. I never tell you about all the travel delays, missed flights, and scams that I constantly deal with!

Can anyone out there relate to what I am saying in this video? Please comment with your thoughts and/or share your experiences of unfortunate events that have happened to you while traveling. I'm curious to know!

Music: Epidemic Sound

title: I Survived a Fatal Bus Crash in India (full story)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE to my UNSEEN Channel! https://bit.ly/2Oq6fjX
üìù Join my Newsletter & Get a Secret Video of my 3 Best Travel Hacks! https://bit.ly/3ebkR0Y

In today's video, I tell you my craziest travel story in full detail.  6 years ago, I was in a fatal bus crash in India during my 3-month solo backpacking adventure across the country.  It happened to me when I was en route from Udaipur to Jodhpur in the Rajasthan state.  I was the only foreigner on the bus, and the only English speaker.  The bus crashed around 1AM local time, in the middle of nowhere.  It was the only time that I had to put my hand over my pulse to see if my heart was still beating.  2 people did not make it out alive.   I get anxiety just thinking about what happened. 

I do not hate India - I have had some incredible experiences around the country.  The bus crash could have happened to me in any place, but unfortunately it happened in India.  I am happy that I made it out alive and thankful to continue traveling. 

What's the scariest thing that has ever happened to you on your trips? Please comment below (I read all of them)!

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from every country in the world, and join me on Instagram: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: I Took an EXTREME RUSSIAN BATH and I Lost My Mind
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

This is the final video in my Russia (Siberia) series, and I think it‚Äôs the most entertaining! In the city of Novosibirsk, I walked into a traditional Russian bathhouse (called a banya), and I was greeted by a giant man named Herman. Herman ordered me to take off all my clothes and enter a 160-degree sauna (70C). I was then beaten by thorny Russian birch trees as well as a thick wooden stick. Then, I went outside to get an ice-cold bucket of water was poured on my head. 

The Russian banya experience took me back to the time when I did a Turkish bath, but this one was more intense! I absolutely love doing these activities - it‚Äôs the reason why I love traveling - to experience new cultures and learn about how other people spend their days. And truth be told, I felt very clean and relaxed after this bath ‚Äî despite the pain that I went through!

Lastly, I want to thank you for tuning into the last 5 weeks of stories in Russia/Siberia.  All content was filmed a month before Russia invaded Ukraine, so it comes with a very heavy heart.  I decided to share these videos because I strongly believe that the Russian people are NOT a representation on their crazy, evil dictator.  Please keep our friends and loved ones in Ukraine in your thoughts. It is absolutely horrible what they are going through, and I hope that this war ends soon. Thanks for watching. 

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from EVERY country, and join me on https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: $10 Budget Challenge in Palau (Stunning Island)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

OMGGG I am having the time of my life in this tiny Pacific-island nation called Palau (my 195th country visited!) Have you ever heard of Palau before?  It's one of the most beautiful countries in the world in terms of beaches and nature -- but it's also one of the most expensive because almost everything here needs to be imported.  With that being said, find out how many things I could purchase around the island for $10.  

Watch this video until the end, it takes an emotional turn when I get to Pelileu. The island where my Grandpa Jack fought in WWII and got shot in the leg.  Before he passed away a few months ago, I was able to hear his harrowing Palau battle stories and I traced his footsteps. Thanks for watching, it means a lot to me.  RIP Grandpa ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Why Are There So Many Cows in India?
description:
Did you know that India has about 283 million living cows?  If these cows were counted as a human population, it'd be the 4th most populous country in the world.

When traveling in India, it's impossible not to notice the extreme amount of cows roaming the streets, blocking traffic and going about their daily lives.  

I will admit that I saw far more cows in the North than I've been seeing in the South, but nonetheless, this video will explain why there are so many cows in India.

What are your thoughts on this?  Do you think it's problematic?

title: How Many Countries Are in the World?
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

One of the most debated questions in the travel world is "HOW MANY COUNTRIES ARE THERE?" 

And truth be told, you will get a different answer depending on who you ask... There is no right or wrong answer; everyone is entitled to their own opinion about what they think qualifies as a 'country.' 

The topic of 'how many countries are there' is a very complicated and touchy subject (especially when people from almost every country will see this video), but I have done my best to reason why I side with the U.N.'s list of 193 countries. 

It's pretty surreal to think that my goal of visiting every country is now within reach. I have just 54 left! And after this year (if all goes as planned) I will have 37 left. 

What are your thoughts on how many countries there are in the world? Do you also side with the U.N. and myself at 193? Please share your thoughts below!

title: World's Largest Gathering of GINGERS (WTF?!)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for More Travel Videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

As a proud ginger, I was THRILLED to attend the world's largest ginger festival/gathering a few months ago! It was the 12th consecutive year of Ginger Fest, held in a small town in Southern Netherlands called Tilburg.  And what a blast it was!

More than 1,000 gingers, from all over the globe, came in for a weekend of music, activities, picnics, bar crawls and just old-fashioned FUN.  

But I must admit.. it was pretty strange to spend 2 days exclusively with other members of the ginger community.  Why?  Because we have nothing else in common other than our unique genetic mutations. Most festivals/gatherings around the world are centered around a common INTEREST, such as music, sports, arts, etc -- but this one?  It's just a bunch of redheads taking over a small Dutch town!  

That being said, I will say that it was a fun time, and I made several new redhead friends who took me around UTRECHT (my new favorite city in Europe). It's a mini-Amsterdam, without all the tourists - as you'll find out in this story! 

Thanks for watching and stay tuned for next week, when I visit the bizarre town called BAARLE which is literally stuck in between two countries: Netherlands and Belgium. 
#ginger #redhead #netherlands

title: I Just Left Russia. My Thoughts on Invading Ukraine
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I love Ukraine. I‚Äôve always said that it‚Äôs one of the most underrated countries in Europe. The historical sites and monuments are breathtaking. The people are very humble and friendly and I have nothing but incredible memories during my 10 day trip to Ukraine in 2015.

I just spent 3 weeks traveling across Eastern Russia (Siberia) and while I really enjoyed my trip, in terms of culture and adventure ‚Äî the politics just don‚Äôt make sense to me. I just woke up to the news that Russia invaded Ukraine, and I don't understand why anyone wants to start another war.  This is devastating. 

My heart aches for the 44 million people living in Ukraine, many who are currently listening to the sounds of explosions and don‚Äôt know what tomorrow will bring. I wish nothing but health and safety for all of my Ukrainians friends out there. We are keeping you in our thoughts and prayers üíîüá∫üá¶

My first Russia video goes live on Sunday (two days from now) and then for the next 4 consecutive weeks, you will see episodes from my Russia (Siberia) series.  I want you all to know that the filming of these stories took place BEFORE the war has started, so I will proceed with sharing them as planned.  Thank you for your understanding, and I will see you guys on Sunday.

title: His Job is Hiking Volcanoes (making $4/day)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Yesterday in the Congo, I hiked Mt. Nyiragongo -- Africa's most active and dangerous volcano.  After a 6 hour journey up to 3,500 meters, we slept overnight at the stunning crater, and admired the world's largest lava lake.  

It was, without question, one of the best travel days of my life.

But this story is not so much about the volcano itself.  It's about a guy named Elias, who since 1991, has been a porter and chef to cater for tourists who want to hike to the top.

I was randomly paired up with him, and was so astonished by how he carries up to 55 pounds of things with him up and down this volcano, three times a week.   For the last 29 years.  And he makes roughly $4 a day. 

Elias deserves every bit of credit for his determination and hard work.   It's people like him who make the world go 'round.

title: How AMERICAN are the MARSHALL ISLANDS?
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

IAKWE (HELLO) FROM THE MARSHALL ISLANDS üá≤üá≠Life is wonderful out here in country #157!

It was already expected that the Marshall Islands would be absolutely stunning (and it certainly is)... but it was unexpected how AMERICAN it feels here!

- They use U.S. dollars.  
- They speak (American) English.  
- They play basketball. 
- They drink Bud Light. 
- They use miles and Fahrenheit and feet.  

I haven't been home in 6+ months and it is so amazing (and refreshing) to experience this "home" feeling in the middle of the Pacific Ocean - the Marshall Islands! 

WHY are the Marshall islands so Americanized?  Find out in today's video!   

Just curious -- how many of my American friends had no idea about this?  We all know of Hawaii and Guam, but did you honestly know about the Marshall Islands? Comment your thoughts below!

title: The Forgotten PYRAMIDS OF SUDAN (better than Egypt)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

WOWOW - TODAY WAS A TOP 10 TRAVEL DAY OF MY ENTIRE LIFE. 

I made it to SUDAN, country #173 and one that I've long desired to visit for many reasons, but none more than to see the ancient (forgotten) pyramids.  There are more pyramids (200+) in this tiny section of Sudan than in all of Egypt, and they are just as old and impressive!

My Sudanese friends and I took a camel ride to explore around the area and we were the only ones around.  Not another soul in sight.  

If you ask me, this experience was about 10X more enjoyable than the Pyramids of Giza in Egypt, which is now flooded by tour bus after bus.   Add this place to your list!

description:

‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Today I have the pleasure of introducing you to a brave, smart and courageous 6 year old boy named Koshyar.  He lives in a small village in North Eastern Iraq, and he was born without arms.

You'd think that being born armless would hinder your abilities to live a normal life, but not for Koshyar.   He plays, eats, studies, draws and enjoys life the same as his peers, and it's incredible to witness.

Share this video if you feel inspired from this amazing boy with no arms!   Thank you VOA/Rebaz Majeed for the extra footage and thumbnail photo.

title: What is VOODOO? (West African Religion)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Bonjour BENIN, country #176 and I'm very excited to be here!  

When I was in Togo last year, I learned all about the religion of Voodoo -- the oldest religion in Africa.   I found it fascinating,

As soon as I got to Benin, I found out that the city of Ouidah is the center and birthplace of the religion, so I jumped in a car and took a 2 hour drive here to investigate and see what it's all about!

The best part about today was visiting the PYTHON TEMPLE, which is filled with hundreds of pythons! They are considered sacred around here.  Very interesting stuff!

title: I Went to Thailand's Floating Market With Mark Wiens!
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Have you ever heard of a floating market before? If not, you're in for a real treat (literally, wait until you see how much we ate)! 

In Thailand, some markets are "floating" -- meaning they function entirely on narrow canals with small boats moving up and down . You pay a small price to hire a boat driver for an hour (or longer), and then choose which delicious meals to eat from dozens of vendors (on boats) with elderly women cooking up something unique. It's all cheap and delicious and this is debatably the best experience you can have in Thailand. 

This morning, my buddy Mark Wiens from Migrationology and I headed 2 hours outside of Bangkok to a floating market called Damnoen Saduak, where he introduced me to some of Thailand's best dishes. We had a blast shooting this video and I hope you enjoy what we have to share! 

Also -- If you don't already know, Mark makes some of the best food travel videos out there, so check out his page below for more deliciousness.

title: A Country Without Birthdays?!
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I've come to Bhutan. I've asked several people when they were born, and they couldn't give me an answer... because they don't know. 

Why?

The Bhutanese genuinely believe that leading a happy life is more important than how many years you‚Äôve been alive (birthday). If that doesn't make you smile, then I don't know what will :)

Instead of recognizing individual birthdays ‚Äì they decided that all citizens turn 1 year older every Jan 1st. So everyone celebrates a birthday on New Year's Day! 

While this system is more prevalent in the older generation (younger kids living in cities do know their birthdays) -- it's still proves how fascinating this country is. I've never been to a place where people don't know their birthdays, and don't care to know. They just want to life in peace.

The sun rises everyday. The sun sets everyday. Life happens. Age doesn't matter. That's Bhutan in a nutshell. And I love this country.

title: The World's Most Interesting People?
description:
Today I spent 3 hours, alone, with the nomadic Himba Tribe of Northern Namibia.  I think they are the world's most interesting people.

The Himbas 'initiated' me into their tribe, by splatting my face with their red clay, teaching me how to do their traditional dance and plenty more which you will see in this video.  

By the end of the day, they invited me to sleep in their huts with them, but I respectfully (and regretfully) declined (because I have a 5AM wake up tomorrow morning, and I don't have a big jacket as it gets freezing overnight). 

I've made over 400 videos now, and this is my favorite one yet by a long shot.   As you probably know, I love going to far away places, interacting unique groups of people and find ways to connect with them.  It was a completely surreal, out-of-body experience, that I am so excited to share with you.  Hope you enjoy!

title: MYANMAR HAS CHANGED üá≤üá≤(so happy to be back!!!)
description:

HAPPY VALENTINE'S DAY FROM MYANMAR! ‚ù§Ô∏è

I'm so happy that I FINALLY made it back to Myanmar after 5 loooong years, and I am shocked my how much this country has evolved.   

5 years ago, there weren't any ATM machines and now there's about 10 on every street.  5 years ago there was a huge shortage in hotels, and now there are hundreds to choose from.  5 years ago the domestic airport was a tiny shack and now it's as modern and glorious as the one in Bangkok.  

All I can say is that I am thrilled to be back in this incredible country, and I hope you're ready to hear some of Asia's most unique stories here over the coming 5 days!

title: He Teaches Poor Kids FOR FREE (Islamabad, Pakistan)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Every day for the last 37 years, Master Ayub has been teaching poor children from the slums of Islamabad, Pakistan FOR FREE in a public park. 

It started with one kid, then two came, then hundreds, and now he has educated tens of thousands of kids by HIMSELF.  Master Ayub's kind heart and dedication has landed him many awards in Pakistan and beyond, including one from Queen Elizabeth herself, and he does not plan to stop teaching until he dies.  

This man is a class act who has a heart of gold. He has sacrificed his life so much that he moved his home to the neighboring slum just to be at the kids' service 24/7. Can you imagine how much better the world would be if everyone was like Master Ayub?

title: How This Phone App Saved Zimbabwe
description:
Have you heard about Zimbabwe's economic crisis lately? If not, then you might be surprised by what I'm about to tell you.

In 2008, a loaf of bread in Zimbabwe would cost you more than a TRILLION Zimbabwean Dollars. This extreme hyperinflation led to the collapse of their currency, which in turn led Zimbabwe into a huge economic crisis.

In 2009, they adopted the U.S Dollar, which is still the main currency today, but with such high demand for dollars and such a limited supply, the cash in simply running out.

But don't panic yet, because an innovative solution has been introduced to fix this currency crisis. It's called ECO CASH, and it's a way to make payments by sending a TEXT MESSAGE on ANY functioning mobile device. It basically turns cash into a digital currency (not like Bitcoin or PayPal) -- and you can buy anything with it (from groceries to taxis to street food). No banks or apps are involved... just text messaging. I am shocked how efficient it works.

I met about a dozen Zimbabweans over the last few days, and they all told me that Eco Cash is the only thing holding their economy together until a new currency is created or a new system is put in place..

Do you think Eco Cash would be useful for other countries to adopt? I surely do!

title: THE JUNGLE TRIBE (Mexico's Most Remote Culture)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I've spent the past 72 hours living with Mexico's most remote indigenous tribe called the Lacandones, and it has been absolutely breathtaking!!!  I've been on such a high over the last 24 hours as I've been editing this video nonstop, and I think you will really enjoy it. 

There are less than 1,000 Lacandones remaining in 4 separate villages, all of which are deep in the Lacandon jungle in the state of Chiapas - about 10 miles from the Guatemalan border.   

They dress themselves in white as a symbol of peace, grow their hair out as long as possible and speak one of the world's most unique languages called Hach t ºan.

The Lacandons aren't always open to visitors, by my friend Diego and I were able to get special permission to observe their fascinating culture. 

This is the 5th tribe I've spent quality time with around the world and it's something I really love doing.  It's like hitting the 'refresh' button on life.  It allows me to see a different perspective on our existence and have a new appreciation for our beautiful planet.

title: This is Why Public Transportation Sucks in Manila
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

There are a lot of things I love about the Philippines, but there's something I can't stand... THE TRAFFIC IN MANILA. 

Manila ranks in my Top 5 worst traffic cities on earth (along with Delhi, Dhaka, Bangkok & Mumbai). It's a nightmare to get around this city, especially during rush hour, when it can take 3+ hours to drive 5 miles. Something needs to be done to fix it. 

You'd think when a city has traffic this bad, there would be an EFFICIENT public transportation system in place (i.e. metro) to get people from point A to point B. But that's not the case in Manila. 

There is a functioning metro (MRT) in Manila, which has been around for 20+ years, but it's miserable to ride. Most other big Asian city that I've been to have enjoyable metros - like Bangkok, Taipei and Hong Kong - but in Manila, it's the opposite of enjoyable. It's overly crowded, beyond dirty, extra noisy and steaming hot. 

In case you were wondering, funding ($$$) is NOT the issue - as the government subsidized several BILLION Pesos to fix the MRT a few years ago by building new stations and 48 new coaches... But thanks to technical difficulties & faulty designs, that project has gone to waste until now.

Does anyone have any solutions for how to fix the traffic/public transportation issue in Manila? Because if it can be fixed, then this city would be a lot more enjoyable to live in and visit for tourists.

title: World's MOST TRAVELED MAN? (Lee Abbamonte)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/
‚ñ∫ Lee's Insta: https://www.instagram.com/leeabbamonte/

This is the inspiring story of my great friend Lee Abbamonte, who has just flown out from NYC to meet me here in Ethiopia.  We are heading to Somalia, next!

Lee is one of the world's most traveled people.  He has been to every U.N. member state, U.S. state, U.S. national park, both the North and South poles, and 321 unique territories overall.  

He finished all of the countries in 2011, about 9 years before I will do it, and those 9 years made a lot of difference in terms of how we each approached this mission.  In short, Lee wasn't able to leverage social media to lower his travel costs and get paid to travel...  because it wasn't popular back then.  Instead, he had to work and save his own money the old fashioned way -- making the journey significantly more expensive than what it's costing me.    He actually started his travels before the internet took off, back in 1998!

I hope you enjoy hearing Lee's story as he's a great friend and mentor.  We are both about to go on one of the craziest trips of our lives to Mogadishu, Somalia tomorrow -- so stay tuned!

title: What is IBOGA? The African Psychedelic Drug...
description:
Are you ready to get your mind blown?

Today, in Gabon, my local friend Patrick introduced me to the wild world of IBOGA -- a psychedelic drug that is found in the roots of a special tree that only grows in Central Africa. It's so potent that a single trip can last up to 7 days. 

Patrick drove me an hour outside of Libreville to a tiny village, where we met a lady (who he calls Mama), who is known as the "Queen of Iboga." She hosts people from all over the world to "initiate them" in a bizarre ceremony -- which I participated in.

P.S. - If you are wondering, I only ate a small bite to taste it and did not feel any effect... I am not the type of person who would enjoy completely tripping out for days with no control. But I really enjoyed the rituals and learning all about it.

title: Our Troubles in GUINEA (Conakry)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

After a rough few days in Sierra Leone, we have made it onwards to the next West African country of Guinea (Conakry).

It's been a wild 2.5 days here so far, from the challenging roads to the (once again) disgusting corruption and bribery that we had to deal with.  But we made it, after 11 LONG hours of driving 150 miles, to the capital of Conakry.

Initially, we had a great time exploring the fish market at sunrise and then getting secret access inside the 2nd biggest mosque in sub Saharan Africa -- but then things quickly turned bad when thousands of policemen (armed with AK47s, helmets and bullet proof vests) stormed the streets in preparation for the riots which have been destroying the city.   

We quickly ran (literally) back to our hotel and called it a day.  We didn't leave the hotel anytime afterwards.  

This region of the world is tough to travel across, especially in your own vehicle.  At each of the dozens and dozens of police checkpoints, we are always pulled over to show our car papers/insurance, and even after we do correctly, the corrupt police will find ANY reason to pick on us (often times, making up some random law) until we pay them off.  It makes me sad. 

BUT I HAVE SOME GOOD NEWS (in case you missed yesterday's video)!  THE SIERRA LEONE GOVERNMENT SAW MY VIDEO ABOUT US GETTING SCAMMED AND THEY WENT TO THE BORDER TO ARREST THE 3 GUYS AND NOW THEY ARE IN PRISON!  One step closer to making this region a safer place to visit for everyone.

title: TURKEY'S BEST CITY (Diyarbakir)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

HI GUYS!  I'm still on this incredible 3-week road trip around Turkey, and today we unexpectedly found ourselves in an AMAZING city called Diyarbakir -- in the South Eastern part of the country. 

We did not originally plan to come here because of recent events and security issues that (we thought) would be unsafe... BUT it turns out that Diyarbakir is my new favorite place in Turkey!   The culture is so raw and authentic -- it really feels like I've traveled back in time.  Nothing is modernized. Nobody is seen on their smartphones, or in a rush to get somewhere.  Everything is seemingly the same to how you would find it hundreds of years ago, and I really love that! 

And the best part about Diyarbakir are the medieval city walls that are the longest in the world after the Great Wall of China!  WHAT A PLACE!

title: The PROBLEM with MYANMAR... (no seat belts)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I've never told this story publicly, but now is the time to share.  The last time I came to Myanmar (5 years ago), I became really good friends with a local tour operator named Sai, who sponsored my trip in exchange for a blog post (back when I used to be a blogger). 

The post I wrote went viral, and gave him a lot of new clients which he was really thankful for.  We remained close friends until I got a devastating email several years ago from a lady (who was on a tour with Sai after reading my blog post).  She told me that Sai got in a car crash and passed away.  He was not wearing a seat belt. 

This memory has haunted me for a long time.  Every time I came across the word "Myanmar," I instantly thought about Sai.  

And now I'm back here, and enjoying my trip overall... but I can't help but notice the unsafe situation these streets.  I took 4 taxis over the last few days and all 4 didn't have seat belts in the back seat.  To make matters even more frightening, many drivers on the streets of Yangon are reckless and I was terrified as I sat in the back seat without a seat belt on. 

I hope the government of Myanmar sees this video and does something to implement a change.  We've already lost Sai, and I hope that nobody else passes away from something that is easily preventable. 

That's all I want to say.  I do love Myanmar and I will certainly be back again someday, hopefully when I will feel safer getting around town.

‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

It's a beautiful day in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo -- country 188!   While there are many interesting things about this city, nothing is more fascinating than the SAPEURS!

"La Sape" is a cultural movement among Congolese men, who dress themselves as dandies and put great emphasis on their style and physical appearance.  They wear the fanciest suits, ties, hats, shoes and accessories all around town! 

At first, I thought it was just a hobby or a passion, and it certainly is both of those things, but sapology is more of a cultural movement among the (mostly) poor men on the streets of Brazzaville, and it's really cool to learn about!

Have you ever heard about the sapeurs before?  Share this with your dapper friends!

title: WOMEN OF AFGHANISTAN (6 inspiring stories)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

When traveling around Afghanistan (and other Muslim-majority countries), I receive many comments about why no women appear in my videos.   

The reason is because these societies are largely dominated by men -- and men are the ones who are commonly seen on the streets, driving cars, working in shops and eating in restaurants.   For the most part, women stay  at home to watch their kids, clean the house, prepare food, etc. This is how the culture has been functioning for thousands and thousands of years, especially right here in Afghanistan. 

BUT, that doesn't mean that there aren't as many women as men who are doing inspiring things!   In general, women are shy of the camera and they don't want to be exposed for cultural reasons, which is something that I always respect and honor.   This is why I do not show many women in my videos. 

However, over the last few weeks as I've traveled around Afghanistan, I've been able to sit down with 6 incredible women entrepreneurs to hear their stories.   They all have amazing things to say!! 

I really enjoyed making this video and I hope that you guys enjoy listening what they have to say, because as we all know, women make the world go 'round!

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from every country in the world, and join me on Instagram! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

THIS RESTAURANT IS UNBELIEVABLE!

Did you know that the world's oldest restaurant is in Madrid, dating back to the year 1725? It's even verified by Guinness World Records!

I had no clue that this place existed until someone commented on my Instagram post this morning telling me, so I walked in the door this evening and was welcomed with open arms and access to film all of the hidden gems inside this 16th century building.

Aside from being so ancient, the food was absolutely spectacular -- roast suckling pig was almost as good as the lechon in the Philippines!

Yes, they've had rough times in the past -- just like dozens of other countries in the region and around the world.  But Sudan has moved on to be a VERY SAFE COUNTRY, with some of the friendliest people I've ever met.

title: From Broke to Millionaires at 22 (DIGITAL NOMADS)
description:
I met Mac and Jess a week ago in Bangkok, and I couldn't believe my ears when they told me their story of going from $50,000 in debt to generating $1.5 million by working online.

So I decided to share their journey with you as an inspiration that there ARE so many opportunities are out there to be successful and you CAN follow your dream life, whatever it may be. 

As millennials, sometimes it's hard for us to convince our parents (trust me) that we can make a sustainable living online.  The internet simply wasn't around when they grew up. 

But it's 2019 now, and times have changed.   A recent study by CNBC found out that 70% of people globally work remotely at least once a week and 53% work remotely for at least half of the week.  

I just get so happy when I cross paths with people like Mac and Jess, who are taking advantage of the opportunities around them, and crushing it!

Share this video if you feel inspired :)

title: Entering The City That Never Sleeps (Seoul, South Korea)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

They say that New York is the "City That Never Sleeps" -- but that's until they come to SEOUL and realize that this place is truly buzzing 24/7.    After then sun goes down -- regardless of which day it is -- neon signs illuminate the busy roads, bars and nightclubs stay crowded until 6AM, and the magnitude of street food vendors and restaurants are serving sizzling Korean BBQ throughout the night.

I'm thrilled to be back here in South Korea -- the country that I moved to straight out of college to teach English for 2 years.   It's nostalgic to be roaming around in my old stomping grounds, and it's going to be fun to show you around this megacity over then coming 5 days.

Have you ever been to Seoul?  What kind of content would you like to see me cover? Please comment below!

title: The MANHATTAN of YEMEN (SHIBAM)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

THIS IS FASCINATING!

Before I came to Yemen, I had NO IDEA that I would be seeing the most incredible desert landscapes of canyons and valleys, along with the most unique indigenous cultures who live inside them!  

Welcome to Wadi Dawan in the Hadramaut Governorate (region) of Yemen.  This place is made up of 32 small villages, entirely made from mud bricks!  Some of the settlements, like Shibam, are over 600 years old which has awarded them to be a UNESCO World Heritage Site.   Shibam is actually considered as the "world's first skyscraper city" and best example of urban planning based on vertical construction.

I felt 100% safe as I wandered around these villages, meeting people and seeing their humble way of living.  I was lucky enough to randomly join a wedding celebration as well!

I bet this isn't what you thought Yemen was like.  For me at least, it sure wasn't.  And this is absolutely amazing!

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG Stories for live updates from this trip: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

title: The N Word
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Is the N word a bad word?

Travel forces you to step outside of your comfort zone and change your perspectives of the world-- and this video is a perfect example of what I'm talking about.

Growing up in the states, we all know the the 'N word' is a derogatory word towards African Americans.  It's one of the most offensive words that you can say... But in the West African country of Niger, it's just the opposite.  In fact, you are just saying the name of the country!

What are your thoughts on this?

Are you on Instagram? Join me for more travel stories @DrewBinsky

PS - I made this video because I received about 50 messages on Instagram/Facebook with people saying the N word because I was in Niger.  And I was fed up with it.  Thanks to my friends Boubs and Aminata for having this conversation with me.  It really has a strong message.

title: I CAN'T BELIEVE THIS (Leptis Magna, Libya)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

LIBYA.. WHO KNEW?  Today was one of those days where I truly can't believe what I saw with my own two eyes.  

Located in Northern Libya, Leptis Magna is widely considered to be (one of) the world's most preserved ancient Roman cities.   

I had the entire place to myself and I have been in a constant state of shock by how impressive this is.   By now, I've had the chance to thoroughly explore 5 or 6 Roman cities -- and Leptis Magna is by far the best.

I'm struggling to explain any further in words.  Just watch the video and you'll understand what I'm saying!

title: I Met The Voodoo Grandmas of Hong Kong
description:
This is one of the strangest stories you will hear in a while -- the Voodoo Grandmas of Hong Kong.

In Hong Kong, you can go under a random bridge in Causeway Bay -- one of the busiest areas of the city --  to find about a dozen voodoo grandmas over 75 years old.  

These grandmas are there to help you get rid of evil voodoo spirits from someone that you hate (i.e. an ex-lover or mean boss).  All you have to do is arrive with a photo of their face, and the grandma will beat it down to pieces with a shoe while saying nasty things and then light it on fire.  You have to see it to believe it. 

Fun fact: I actually did this while filming a pilot for a TV show in Hong Kong in 2015, but unfortunately that never got aired so I am happy to share this story with you today for the first time. 

Just curious, do you believe in voodoo stuff like this? Share your thoughts below!

title: The Black Market of Gasoline (Yemen)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Yemen is having many problems at the moment, but the most obvious to me so far has been the shortage of gasoline.  We've driven over 14 hours so far from the Oman/Yemen border to the city of Mukalla, and it was a wild experience every time we had to stop at the gas station.

Instead of using normal gas stations (which are mostly out of gas), there are young kids on motorbikes who track you down on the road and offer to fill up your car with "illegal" gasoline.  The price has increased 300% over the last few years because of the short supply. 

What's ironic is that Yemen does sit on an abundance of oil reserves, but unfortunately, they are being taken advantage of by their neighbors and are unable to use much of that gas for themselves.

title: Thoughts on IRAN After 6 Months...
description:
Iran touched my heart in more ways than I ever imagined.

6 months ago I was on a 2 week journey around Iran, and not a day goes by where I don't think about the fun times I had in Iran.

In my mind, Iran is still the most misunderstood country in the world. It has THE MOST humble & hospitable people, delicious foods, ancient history and a culture that feels like you've traveled back in time.

And should I mention that Iran is one of the world's safest countries? I felt safer traveling in Iran than I do in my own country -- this is not a joke.

And just in case you are wondering ‚Äî nobody told me to make this video. It is not sponsored. I made it out of pure joy because I want to share with you my 100% honest thoughts and feelings towards Iran. I can't wait to visit again soon (hopefully 2019!)

Have you ever been to Iran? Do you agree that it's the most misunderstood country in the world?

Instagram @drewbinsky :) Thanks Michael (IG: @affinityadventure) for the intro sequence.

title: The Truth About Venezuela's Gas Crisis
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ üìù Join my Newsletter & you'll be sent a secret video of my 3 best travel hacks! https://bit.ly/3ebkR0Y

As many of you may know, Venezuela has been experiencing the worst economic downfall in the history of the world.  It's more than twice as severe as the U.S. Great Depression, and I simply cannot ignore this sad reality as I am visiting the country...  

The main driver for this economic crisis is oil. 

Nearly a century ago, massive oil reserves were discovered off the Northern coast of Venezuela, which is why the country used to be the wealthiest in Latin America (in the 1960s and 1970s)... But sadly, a series of poor decisions, mismanagement and (recent) U.S. sanctions has crippled its economy to pieces.  Nowadays, despite having one of the world's largest oil reserves, there is a HUGE gas shortage and the locals have to wait in their car HOURS or even DAYS just to fill up their gas tank.  It's a very sad reality and I've never seen anything like it before in all of my travels to 194 countries.  My heart is with the people of Venezuela and I sincerely hope that the situation gets better so the country can thrive again like the olden days. 

Join me in this part-documentary, part-adventure vlog as I educate you about the devastating gas crisis in Venezuela.

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from every country in the world, and join me on Instagram! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: What Can $10 Get in Azerbaijan?
description:
Azerbaijan, and its capital of Baku, probably isn't on your list to visit -- but I hope to change your mind because it truly is a unique and affordable country! It has modern skyscrapers like Dubai and hectic traffic like Bangkok -- but Baku really has a special charm that I love.  If you go here, don't miss out on the old city walls in Azerbaijan's capital city - they are like stepping back in time!  In this episode of my $10 series, find out how far I could stretch my money in Baku, Azerbaijan (a cup of tea, a kebab... and what else)?

Please note that this video is about a year old (I am reposting the entire '$10 series' as I only shared it on FB and not YT).  As you'll notice, the editing is not great and it moves way too fast, but I still wanted to share it with you anyway. As always, thanks for watching my videos!

title: The Country of (too many) Babies...
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

This country has too many babies.

The West African nation of Niger has the highest annual growth rate in the world, at 3.8%.  The average Nigerien women has 7.2 babies.

If they continue reproducing at this speed, then their population is expected to TRIPLE by the year 2050, from 21 million to 63 million people.   Right now, more than half of the society is under 15 years old. 

These statistics are alarming.

What are you thoughts about overpopulation?  Did you even know that this is happening in Niger (and all over West Africa?)

Are you on Instagram? Join me on there to follow my journey in real time. @DrewBinsky

title: THE DESERT WARRIORS (Bedouin Tribe)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Growing up in Arizona, I've always been fascinated by the desert.  That's why I am particularly interested in the BEDOUIN TRIBE of North Africa and the Middle East.  Believe it or not, there are over 8 million bedouins (nomadic Arabs) living across 21 desert nations. 

Over the years, I have had some incredible experiences with bedouins in countries like Yemen, Oman, Sudan, Algeria, Mauritania, and Jordan ‚Äî and today, I finally got around to telling you the story of the Bedouins while here in the Sinai peninsula of Egypt.

All I have to say is that bedouins are some of the most open and hospitable people on earth -- they will force-feed you and serve you copious amounts of hot sugary tea.   I really admire their lifestyles and I'm excited to share this story with you. 

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram for more stories from every country in the world: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

**I made this video 2.5 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

CYPRUS is a very interesting country, with a diverse history, and one that isn't often talked about on a global scale.

Did you know that since 1974, Cyprus has been split by a thick-walled border into two sides, the South (Greek) and the North (Turkish)? The capital city, Nicosia, is the only capital in the world to be in two continents, and it's bizarre how the culture drastically changes when you step over a border within the same city.

My goal in making this video is to educate you on the history of Cyprus, as well as share my unbiased opinions as I visit both the Greek & Turkish sides of the island.

Please refrain from starting a Greek vs. Cyprus political debate. That's not what this video is about. Any rude/nasty comments will be deleted.

This video was NOT easy to make.. it took me 2 hours just to find a place to say the opening lines... Police on every corner stopped me from taking photos around the walled border. And it was SO hot outside that I almost passed out.. but it was all worth it!!

#DrewBinsky #Cyprus #Europe

title: What's Happening in Bangladesh? (Student Protests)
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I woke up this morning to more messages & emails than I could count, all from Bangladeshis crying for help.  Telling me about the disaster situation happening right now in Dhaka, which is as simple as students demanding for safer roads after 2 people were recently killed by a speeding bus. 

I was in Dhaka, Bangladesh 16 months ago, and I have never seen a more dangerous, unregulated and hectic road situation in my life.  I was scared to death everytime I crossed the road.  I feel for these students and all people of Bangladesh, and I wish the government will listen to what they are saying, instead of blocking the internet and cellular service in fear of the word being spread.

I am spreading the word, and I hope you will too.

This is a video that I've been wanting to make for a while.  It's about the the first, the original, the indigenous, the NATIVE AMERICANS of the United States of America.  

The Native Americans are the ones who settled on this land around 15,000 years before European colonization, forming hundreds of distinct tribes with their own unique traditions and languages.  I find this stuff fascinating!!

Here's the story of a Native American man named Donovan, who comes from the Navajo tribe of Arizona.  He gives us a glimpse into his culture and lifestyle, which I think is important for us all to know about.

title: She Has Coronavirus (what it's like)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Through social media, I was able to get in touch with someone who has coronavirus.   Her name is Samira.  She is an amazing girl from Iran, and is courageous enough to open up and tell me what the last 3 weeks of her life has been like. 

The moral of the story is to TAKE THIS VIRUS SERIOUSLY but NOT TO PANIC.  In her case, it was a sickness that has been cured, and now she feels happy and almost back to normal.  Coronavirus is not a death sentence for the vast majority of the people who get it.  We must prepare, not panic.  

I hope that everyone reading and watching this is staying safe at home.  Please quarantine yourselves.  Wash your hands.  Clean your phone screen.  Don't touch anyone and keep a distance.  We will get through this, together, however long it takes to pass.

Thank you, Samira, for being so kind and strong to share your story with us.  I hope to visit your country again once life returns back to normal.

description:

I don't often talk about the negatives of travel, because there is so much positivity to share!  But truth be told, life of a full time traveler is not always rainbows and ponies.  Not at all.

In this video, I open up to you a bit and share why AIRPORTS are the most stressful part of the travel experience for me. title: My First 24 Hours in MADAGASCAR
description:
What a whirlwind the past 24 hours of my life have been in Madagascar!!

I decided to come to Madagascar with absolutely no plan. It's fun being spontaneous sometimes. 

I arrived in the capital of Madagascar called Antananarivo early this morning with no hotel reservation, no plan and no idea what I'd be doing... Just seeking adventure!

Through Facebook, I got in touch with a local girl named Ali, who picked me up at the airport with her 2 classmate friends, Dave and Nancy. Not only have they been AMAZING tour guides around Antananarivo, but Dave volunteered to let me sleep at his house with his family -- who cooked me a delicious dinner of Madagascar food called Vary Amin‚Äôanana. Life doesn't get any better than this!

Today is a day that I'll never forget. I am so happy to be back in Africa and so thankful to be able to find people like Ali, Dave & Nancy from social media. I can't wait to see more of Madagascar over the coming days!

title: HE LOVES THE PHILIPPINES (from Syria)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Today I caught up with Basel (AKA The Hungry Syrian Wanderer) and heard his touching life story. 

In 2013, when he was a teenager, he was forced to leave his home in Syria due to war.  His neighborhood was completely destroyed from bombings.  His parents pushed him to move to the Philippines to start a new life, and although it was difficult at first to immerse into Filipino culture, he has become a successful vlogger and entrepreneur and has a very bright future ahead. 

This is a story of courage.  A story of determination.  A story of bravery.  

Hands down to Basel for all that he's done, despite not seeing his family in the last 7 years.

title: I Slept in a Strangers Home in Iraq. It Was Wild
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù MY TRAVEL HACKING COURSE goes live on Aug 12!  Sign up for my newsletter to get 50% off within the first 24 hours: https://bit.ly/3CDsZRA

Dear Friends: This is my favorite story from Iraq.  I hope you will watch to the end so you can learn about the unique lifestyles of the 'Marsh Arabs.'

Iraq is famous for their "Iraqi Marshlands" (also known as Mesopotamian Marshes).  It's a rare, aquatic landscapes in the desert, stretching hundreds of miles across Southeastern Iraq into Southwestern Iran. 

In fact, these marshes were one of the largest wetland ecosystems in the world until sadly, they were drained in the 1980s and 1990s under a former presidents' rule.  However, in recent years, the marshlands are back to higher water levels and it was awarded as a UNESCO world heritage site in 2016.

I visited the Iraqi Marshlands with my buddy Alvaro for 24 hours, and I documented the entire adventure for you to see.  I hope you enjoy this story.  I will never forget how amazing this experience was! 

Follow me on Instagram Stories to follow my travels in real time! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky
