title: The FILIPINO JEWISH Rockstar (Mike Hanopol)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

This is one of my top 5 favorite stories I've ever told you since I started making videos 2.5 years ago, so I hope you enjoy!

It's about a 74 year old man named Mike Hanopol, who comes from a  beautiful island in the Philippines called Leyte.  In his early life, he found out (from his father) that he has Jewish ancestry, so he spent 15 years living between the U.S. and Israel to learn more about his religion.  

To this day, he remains Orthodox, keeping Shabbat and eating kosher -- which is not as easy as it sounds here in the Philippines, a country that's 85-90% dominated by Catholicism. 

Oh yeah, and he's also a super famous rockstar from the 1970s, with several big hits around the country like "Laki sa Layaw."  I didn't mention in the video that he opened up for Led Zeppelin in the 1970s in Tokyo, which is my favorite band of all time!  

If you enjoyed this video, it would mean a lot to me if you shared it with your friends because I spent 3 days putting it together :)

title: THE WHISTLE LANGUAGE (most unique language earth!)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Would you believe me if I told you that somewhere in the mountains of  Turkey, there's a small village called Kuskoy where ALL of its residents can speak a language that is entirely made up of WHISTLES?  And every single word in the Turkish language can be translated into these unique sounds?

I recently visited Kuskoy and was completely blown away by how cool and unique this vernacular is!   You really have to hear it to believe it. 

As the locals told me, this whistle language was invented around 500 years ago by local farmers, who needed to communicate with their peers over the steep hills...  Amazingly, the whistles can be heard up to 3 kilometers away!!

Share this video with your friends if you enjoyed!

Follow @drewbinsky for more travel stories from every country in the world, and join me on Instagram: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: AMERICA: I'm Struggling to Fit in...
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

This is the most honest video I've ever made, but I feel the need to share my feelings with you. 

I feel like an outsider in my own country. The United States of America.

Having spent about 11 months of each year overseas since 2013, it may not be that surprising that I feel more comfortable in foreign countries than my own... But it's just weird. It's off beat. It messes with my mind.

I am an extrovert in just about every country but my own. While I've been in America the last month, I find myself avoiding people instead of talking to them. It's been really hard for me to make videos in the states -- to find topics that I think are interesting. 

Don't get me wrong, I love my country -- but something just feels off whenever I am here.

Can any other travelers out there relate to me and how I'm feeling when you return to your home country? Or am I battling this internally? Please share your thoughts below!

title: Entering The World's Smallest Airport (1 Passenger)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

This story is amazing! I've been to over 700 airports around the world, and Angaur Terminal in the Pacific island nation of Palau is by far the SMALLEST!!!  

My local friend Sachi and I took a propeller plane down to Pelileu, but we decided to take a pit stop in Angaur, only to see this terminal.  It has so much charm and character!  There are no walls, no bathrooms, and no electricity. There's no TSA Pre-Check or security lines.   Just a tiny bench to sit on while you wait for your plane to arrive.  For aviation geeks like me, this was really special to experience and just another reason to love Palau!

REAL LIFE UPDATE:  I am touching down in Saudi Arabia in 4 days -- MY 197th AND FINAL COUNTRY!!  Stay tuned for a huge video drop when I arrive, which explains my biggest realization from visiting every country in the world, and what's next for Drew Binsky. In case you're wondering, I already spent 11 days in Jamaica (that content will be shared soon), but I just want to give you a current life update because this is the most exciting week of my life! 10 years of nonstop travel and FINALLY, I am about to be one of ~300 people in history to visit every country in the world! title: REFUGEE TO SUPERMODEL (Halima Aden)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Today I had the pleasure of spending an evening with Somali Supermodel Halima Aden.  If you haven't heard of her already, I know you will find her story extremely inspiring! 

Halima was born in a refugee camp in Kakuma, Kenya, because her family was forced to to flee Somalia due to the civil war in the early 1990s.  When she was 7 years old, her family migrated to the USA (Minnesota) where she found herself in a culture shock and couldn't speak English... But that never stopped her from finding her voice! 

Fast forward 11 years and not only did she become a semi-finalist at Miss Minnesota USA, but she was the FIRST PERSON in their 65 year history to wear a hijab and burkini on stage.  It wasn't intentional, it was just Halima staying true to herself and her beliefs -- but it essentially got the attention of the world and now she has been on the cover of Vogue Magazine, Allure, highlighted in Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Edition among dozens of others.  She travels all over the world doing photoshoots, being a UNICEF ambassador and collaborating with brands that she loves.   And the craziest part? She is only 22 years old! 


The sky is the limit for Halima as she continues to be a leader and role model for people in her community, and I can't wait to see what's next!

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram for more inspiring stories like this one! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

#HalimaAden #Somalia #Beauty

title: My Thoughts on CORONAVIRUS
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

What is happening right now? Should you stop traveling?  Is life cancelled?

The world is in pieces right now.  The coronavirus has infected over 150,000 people in 151 countries, taking the lives of 5,800 innocent people.   

In this video, I share with you my thoughts, reactions and suggestions for how to live through this horrible pandemic, as well as how you should approach travel right now.    

To sum it up:  Don't travel, stay home, wash your hands with soap 10X a day and try to stay away from crowded places.   There are many unknowns right now, but if one thing's for sure, it's that human beings are resilient.  We will get through this together -- how long it takes is up to our cooperation.    

I will admit that my stance on COVID-19 has changed.  From the beginning of the breakout (January), I have been on the road traveling.  While it hasn't disrupted my travel plans, I have now realized the seriousness of this pandemic and we need to take it seriously.   Luckily, I am home with my family and friends now in Arizona, and I will not be moving for (at least) several weeks. 

I would love nothing more than to hear your opinions on coronavirus -- how has your life changed?  Have you personally been affected by it?  What do you think the future holds?

description:
The next 6 days of my life are going to be amazing, as I take you inside the hidden country of ANGOLA!

Angola has been notoriously known for being one of the most difficult African countries to visit, as it was nearly impossible to get a tourist visa. But a few months ago, they released an online e-visa to Angola and now it's easier than it's ever been to get inside. 

I have spent the last few days in Angola's capital city of Luanda with a social media friend, Jos√©, and WOW, this place is bizarre and eye-opening.  Everywhere you looks is something different.  Angola is full of contrasts and surprises.

title: Should the USA Lower the Drinking Age to 18?
description:
The vast majority of the world has a drinking age limit of 18 or younger. In these countries, drinking alcohol is not considered a 'big deal.' It's a part of life. Kids grow up around liquor at a younger age and don't make it such a big deal to get wasted every weekend. 

But in the USA, the drinking age limit is 21 and it's strictly enforced. In fact, it's the most strictly enforced I've seen out of ANY country in the world. We make drinking a huge deal, and therefore, teenagers have to sneak it in which can be problematic. 

I just cannot understand how AMERICANS at 18 YEARS OLD can LEGALLY vote, marry, gamble, serve in the military, buy cigarettes, marijuana -- but not a beer? Something is not right here, and I think the age limit should be lowered to 18. 

Do you agree or disagree with me? Please let me know your thoughts in the comments below - I will be reading them all

title: He Walked Across Pakistan... TWICE
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Before I came to Pakistan, dozens of people reached out and told me that I had to find a man named Naveed Khan -- AKA the guy who walked across Pakistan TWICE.

So I found his Instagram (@hunzaonfoot), sent him a message, a lucky we happened to be in Islamabad at the same time (he's usually in the Hunza Valley mountains).   

I was amazed to hear his story. 

Join me as I tell you how Naveed got inspired to walk 5,100 kilometers across Pakistan, Afghanistan and India.  If you are ever planning to visit Northern Pakistan or the Hunza Valley, then Naveed is your guy!

And also, for all of you out there who still thinks that Pakistan is "unsafe" -- then hearing Naveed's story will prove you wrong!

Join me on Instagram @drewbinsky, and also join Naveed on Instagram (@huzaonfoot).

title: A HIDDEN PARADISE in South America
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Join my Newsletter & Get a Secret Video of my Best Travel Hacks! https://bit.ly/3ebkR0Y

Admittedly, I had no idea that the town of CUENCA existed before my trip to Ecuador, but I'm SO HAPPY that we made a spontaneous decision to come here on our final days in the country.

Cuenca represents everything that I enjoy about South America - charming cobblestone streets, tasty street food, historic churches and hidden wonders on every corner.  Sometimes when you just take a spontaneous trip, they turn out to be the best decisions -- and that's exactly how I feel about Cuenca.

The next time you find yourself in South America, or Ecuador in specific, I highly recommend giving Cuenca a visit!

title: What is Soju? (World's Best Selling Liquor)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

WHAT IS SOJU IN KOREA?

I've never experienced a more wild and energetic drinking culture than in South Korea.   It's honestly hard to believe until you see it with your own eyes!

The most popular drink, by a long shot, is called SOJU and it comes it these green glass bottles, which you'll see in every restaurant/bar in Korea.  Soju is a rice-based liquor and only half as strong as vodka, but don't let that fool you because it will make you very drunk.  Last year, almost 4 billion bottles of soju were sold, making it the world's #1 selling liquor by volume.

Have you ever tried soju before in Korea? Do you like it?

Join me on Instagram @drewbinsky.   Special thanks to @MichaelMakesFilms for the help, and to @GSMGlobalSeoulMates for hosting us!  Check out their awesome parties if you ever come to Seoul.

title: Married at First Sight?
description:
The way people fall in love in India is not common in the Western World.    It's marriage at first sight!

Most weddings in India are 'arranged marriages,' where a marriage broker matches you with someone who meets your qualifications and social status (age, religion, etc).  In a sense, marriage brokers in India function the same way as Tinder does in the West.

Then, the person seeking love proceeds to go on several dates (5-10 minutes) until they find 'the one.'   Once both parties agree that they want to spend the rest of their lives together, they decide to get married on the spot.   The next time they meet is usually on their wedding day, where hundreds (or thousands) of friends and family members celebrate.

If anyone reading this had an arranged marriage, please share your story below because it'll be interesting to hear more success stories!

Follow Drew Binsky for daily travel videos.  Instagram @drewbinsky.   

Thanks to my buddy Anto for letting me share your personal story of how you met your wife!  And thanks to Michael (IG@affinityadventure) for the edits.

title: This is Why 7-Eleven in Japan is Next Level
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

**I made this video 3 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

You've never experienced 7-Eleven until you've been to Japan... Seriously, they put the "convenience" in convenience store and it will blow your mind what you can find inside. 

7-Eleven, which is actually co-owned by the Japanese, has MUCH more than just snacks, drinks and slurpees (in fact, slurpees don't even exist here!) 7-Eleven in Japan is almost like a mini Walmart -- a one-stop-shop for anything you could possibly need on the go. And believe it or not, 7-Eleven is Japan's #1 food product retailer, with a large assortment of fresh and tasty meals!!

In this video, I explore the ins and outs of 7-Eleven in Japan, and why I think it's so amazing. Does anyone else agree with me? I think it's just one of those things where, "if you've been, then you know..."

title: He Lives With 20,000 Rats
description:
‚úÖ  Don't forget to SUBSCRIBE to my channel by clicking here ‚ûû   https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0Ize0RLIbGdH5x4wI45G-A

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Watch my favorite videos ‚ûû https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLhiP3P44ul3Y8LDbhXJmhVsVWcpe-7O4O

I just got back from a place called Bikaner, in the Rajasthan province of North Western India -- and I found myself at a temple where a man worships 25,000 rats.  Not only does he (and all people in his community) live among these rats, but they actually believe that they are the reincarnation of their dead family members.  Aunts, uncles, parents, grandparents and cousins - in the form of dirty rats!! 

Join me on an adventure in this small corner of India to hear the bizarre story of the Rat King. 

#india #animals #travel

title: I Just Spent $7,000 on Flights to Africa...
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I just spent the most money I've EVER spent in one single day. Seven thousand United States dollars ($7,000 USD). I'm so full of emotions right now (excited, nervous, happy, anxious) that I'm not sure how to react...

The $7,000 was spent on flights to less-touristy countries in Central and West Africa which I will be visiting by myself in Sept/Oct: Namibia, Angola, S√£o Tom√© and Pr√≠ncipe, Gabon, Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea, Chad, Mali and Mauritania.

The most nerve-racking part about all of this is that I need to have these flight confirmations to start applying for 4 visas right now (Angola, Cameroon, Chad & Mali) -- and if any of those 4 African visas get denied, then I will have to cancel a portion of the trip and I will not get reimbursed for the flight costs. High risk, high reward!

In case you are wondering, I made this video for a few reasons:

A) I like to be honest & transparent with you in all my videos, and budgeting is very important for any traveler

B) I think it's often overlooked how expensive traveling to Africa is, so I want to tell you (again) the reality of traveling on this continent. Sure, you CAN do it on the cheaper side, but I don't have the time to go overland or the energy to sleep in dirty hostels. I also need access to (the best) wifi everyday so I can work and upload videos!

Truth be told, I am really excited for this trip and to witness the hidden cultures in these African countries first-hand. Have you ever been to any of these 9 countries in Africa? I will gladly take some tips/advice or any local connection!

title: How Diverse is MALAYSIA?!
description:
HELLO MALAYSIA! 

I am beyond excited to be back here for a third visit! Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia is a LOT different than I remembered it back in 2014 (when I was here as budget backpacker...) It's bizarre to see how much a city can evolve in just 4 years.

Anyways, the thing I love most about this fascinating country of Malaysia (along with the food) is the extreme DIVERSITY of its citizens. Just walk down any street in K.L., and you'll see all different faces in every different color, with each person uniquely identifying themselves as Malaysian. I say "uniquely" because no two people in this country have the same blood - it's all mixed (mostly with some combination of ethnic Malay, Chinese, and/or Indian!)

This video will explain a little bit more about Malaysia‚Äôs spectacular diversity. 

Stay tuned over the next 3 days as I rediscover Kuala Lumpur's lifestyle, sites, cuisine and people -- I can't wait to show you what's next! And THANK YOU to everyone who came to my meet up. That was amazing. 

Have you ever been to Malaysia?

title: THE CRAZIEST TACO JOINT in MEXICO üá≤üáΩ
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

The country of MEXICO seemingly has a taquer√≠a (taco restaurant) on every corner and it can get overwhelming... but this one called El Borrego Vuido might just be the craziest one of them all. 

My local Mexican friends took me here after a night of drinking, and you won't believe the scene that was unfolding at midnight.  Lines and lines of cars in the parking lot full of hungry people, and the waiters run full speed with tacos in their hands.  The most popular tacos here are made from cow head, tongue and armpit and it's about $0.50 per taco. 

This restaurant was quite the local experience and the service is efficient as it gets.  I give this place a 5 star review and I will be back on my next trip to Mexico City!

title: THE MAN OF MOGADISHU (why he never left)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Today I have the pleasure of introducing you to Bashir Osman, who in my opinion, is THE man of Mogadishu.  He is the owner of the hotel I am staying at, called Peace Hotel, and the reason why I find his story to be so inspiring is because he has never left his home to live elsewhere. 

As you probably already know, Mogadishu has been in a constant state of civil war since 1991, and many Somalis have left for a safer life abroad. But not Bashir.  He has toughed out the most dangerous days in Mogadishu, and is very optimistic what the future brings to his city. 

This is my last video in Mogadishu, and I would like to say on a personal note that this has been an incredible trip and I will certainly be coming back here very soon.  The people that I've met over the last 4 days -- every single one of them -- was so friendly and welcoming to me and I have nothing but good things to say in the future.   Thank you guys for watching my videos here and I will see you tomorrow in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo!

title: This Country Didn't Have TV Until 20 Years Ago
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Could you imagine growing up, 20 years ago, without having TV or the internet?!

In Bhutan, they didn't introduce TV or the internet to its citizens until the year 1999 -- making them the world's last country to do so.

While that may seem like torture to many people reading this, the Bhutanese see it in the opposite way. 

They simply don't want to be a victim of modernization. They are afraid of globalization. They are happy with their traditional way of life that has been practiced for centuries and centuries. 

And as a result, they are ranked one of the happiest and greenest countries in the world. Anyone else see a pattern here?!

title: How He Lost 1/3rd of His Skull (Inspiring Story)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Join my Newsletter & Get a Secret Video of my Best Travel Hacks! https://bit.ly/3ebkR0Y

In today's video, I want to introduce you to my friend Esteban who comes from Ecuador.   As soon as he found out that I was coming to visit his country, he reached out on Instagram and offered to show me around, alongside his brother Gustavo. 

I didn't know much about Esteban before we met, but after spending 12 days getting to know him across Ecuador, I learned that he is one of the strongest and most optimistic souls that I've ever met. 

Several years ago, his friend threw him out of a moving car and he lost 1/3rd of his skull.  Doctors weren't sure if he would make it.  He had to completely relearn how to speak Spanish and English from scratch.  

But through perseverance and positive thinking, Esteban has gotten back on his feet and is now living a normal life.    Here is his full story. 

Thank you, Esteban and your brother Gustavo for showing me an incredible time around Ecuador.  I can't wait to be back again sometime soon!

title: Cleanest City in Africa? KIGALI, RWANDA
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

You will not believe how clean KIGALI, RWANDA is until you watch this video. I am beyond shocked -- as I had no idea it was this clean and safe until coming here!!

For a brief history lesson - Back in 1994, Rwanda suffered one of the bloodiest genocides in modern history. Within 100 days (April 7 - mid July), roughly 20% of the population, or 1 million people, were slaughtered due to tribal conflicts of land ownership. It was devastating, and feels realistic to me when I learn about it because it happened within my lifetime.

Fast forward 24 years, and the capital of Kigali has done a remarkable job reconstructing and rebuilding itself to be a leading African city in terms of modernity, safety, cleanliness and tech (the wifi here is the strongest I've seen on the continent!)

The streets are so clean here in Rwanda that I could eat off them... I'm being serious! I am having flashbacks to walking around Singapore - especially when I went to a swanky rooftop infinity pool over looking the city (reminds me exactly of the Marina Bay Sands).

Have you ever been to Kigali?  Or Rwanda? Do you agree with me?

Music: Epidemic Sound

title: The Horrific Plastic Problem of Bangkok
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I've now been living in Bangkok for over a month, and something that has been on my nerves is the extreme amount of disposable plastic being used EVERYWHERE in this city. 

In fact, more than 600,000 plastic bags are used EVERYDAY in Bangkok alone. 

When I buy something as small as a pen at 7-Eleven (which comes in a plastic wrapper) I am given a plastic bag when I check out. When I buy a tiny orange juice from a street vendor (which I drink in under 5 seconds) -- I am given a plastic straw (in a plastic wrapper) and a plastic bag. FOR A FREAKING ORANGE JUICE! 

Admittedly, I never took action against single-use plastic until I came to Thailand and saw how bad the problem has gotten. But it‚Äôs time to change my habits. 

Too much is too much, and the problem needs to stop (not only here in Bangkok, but the rest of the world). Because the more plastic that gets used, the more plastic ending up in our oceans, the more fish that eat plastic, the more plastic that humans eat (because we eat those fish). 

The road to a cleaner, greener earth starts with you and me, so let's pledge to cut back on single-use plastic right now (grocery bags, water bottles, straws, etc). Who‚Äôs with me?

title: The Art of Head-Carrying Women in Guinea-Bissau
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

No matter where you go on the African continent, you can see women carrying heavy loads of goods on the top of their heads and it's fascinating!   Many of them can carry up to 70% of their body weight, which is nearly impossible to do with just your two hands. 

I'm here in Guinea-Bissau, the tiny Portuguese-speaking West African nation, and I wanted to dedicate this video entirely to these strong women who have an impressive sense of balance.  

I tried to walk 5 steps with 30 kilos of rice on my head, and it's a LOT harder than I thought...

description:

title: AMERICA'S GERMAN TOWN üá∫üá∏üá©üá™
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Welcome to LEAVENWORTH, WASHINGTON -- I had no idea that this place existed until 3 days ago, but now I'm here and I'm loving what I'm seeing!!

Leavenworth is a small town of 2,000 residents tucked away in the beautiful Cascade mountains.   The entire town was modeled after a village in Bavaria (southern Germany) and to this day, it remains almost IDENTICAL to what you can find in Germany.  Everything from the architecture to the food, attire, beer, shopping, lifestyle and overall vibes -- it's basically like you are visiting Germany while in the USA!

Have you ever heard of this town before?  If not, then add it to your list because it's 100% worth it!

title: Are French People Actually Rude?
description:
The country of France has no shortage of beautiful nature, historical landmarks and delicious foods... but it's also known for the stereotype of having unfriendly people. 

While this may be true for Paris, my entire world has opened up ever since I came to the stunning region of Normandy.   I'm telling you that some of the warmest people in Europe are right here!  

The last 4 days in Rouen, the capital of Normandy, has given me a deeper appreciation for the French, and I made this video to explain why :) 

Have you ever been to France?  What do you think about the people?

title: The CORONAVIRUS Teacher (he can't go home...)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ Jake's Channel: https://bit.ly/2TQBEuB
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Today, in Panama City I met a young traveler named Jake Braymiller.   He is currently teaching English in Yangzhou, China. 

On January 19th, he had a trip scheduled to Bali for vacation, and as soon as he departed China, the coronavirus outbreak had just been announced.   On the exact same day.  

So for the last 6 weeks ago, Jake has not been able to return home to his apartment where he has all of his belongings.  His teaching job is currently on hold, and will likely be cancelled overall, while his school is paying him a measly $30/day.  And for now, amid all of this uncertainty, Jake is traveling the world -- which I applaud him for doing so!

This video explains Jake's full story.  I will be sharing my thoughts and opinions on the coronavirus outbreak, how it's impacting travel, and what precautions you should take (etc) in a video very soon -- but for now, I'd love to get your thoughts on this giant mess.  Do you think the media has over exaggerated this illness? Please comment below. 

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram for more stories like this one: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: AFRICA'S HIDDEN TRIBE (they live with crocodiles)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I have arrived in a place called ASWAN, in the South of Egypt! Despite the fact that it's 47C outside (117F), it's SO AMAZING here because we are right on the Nile and everything is incredibly peaceful.

As we took a morning boat ride across the Nile, I noticed a really unique village on the shore, consisting of a bunch of blue and white circular buildings.  We spontaneously stopped, checked out the village, and I realized that it's home to the NUBIAN TRIBE (which if you can remember from my videos in Sudan last year, it's the same people!).

This story is all about the Nubian way of life (yes, they really have crocodiles in their living room). I hope you enjoy!

title: What is a SIESTA? (Spanish Culture)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

I've really been enjoying my time in Madrid over the last week -- it's my first time here!!  While there are many things I admire about Spanish culture, nothing stands out more than the SIESTA CULTURE (or short power naps after lunch).

Have you ever heard of a siesta before?

All of the stereotypes are true (especially in the summer months) -- people really do take siestas here and it's magnificent!  Why can't we have a siesta culture in the U.S. as well?  It makes a lot of sense!

title: I Went To Europe's City With No Cars (Venice, Italy)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

It's my second time coming to Venice, Italy -- and I am still blown away by how this city functions!  Of course, the streets and buildings are all amazing, but what I find most fascinating about Venice is that there are NO CARS because there are NO STREETS!

If you want to get around Venice, your only options are by walking or by boat through one of the 400 canals...  I finally caved in and spent $120 for a private gondola ride -- and it was totally worth it!

Have you ever been to Venice? Did you like it?  Overall, I have mixed feelings because it's SO BEYOND TOURISTY that it basically has turned into a theme park.

title: THE ORGANIC PHARMACIST (100% natural products)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

WOW!! I've spent the last 24 hours living with Dr. Ahmed Salah at his home in a remote part of the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt.  You guys are going to LOVE his story!!!

After getting inspired from meeting an Austrian tourist in his village 25 years ago, Dr. Ahmed has spent the last two decades educating himself on natural remedies to cure (almost) any kind of sickness.  He grows EVERYTHING himself in his backyard -- I'm talking about hundreds of plants, vegetables, fruits, herbs and spices -- and crafts these 100% natural products into care packages to sell in his beautiful pharmacy.   The craziest part about all of this is that we are in the middle of the desert!

Share this video with your friends if you feel inspired by Dr. Ahmed Salah -- I think the world could use a little bit of his positive energy these days.

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram for more travel stories from every country in the world: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: Asians Spend $20 Billion Per Year To Have White Skin
description:
This may come as a surprise if you've never been to Asia before... but in many countries on this continent (especially Eastern and Southeastern regions) -- the Asian women are obsessed with becoming as white as possible. 

Sometimes Asian men as well -- and collectively, Asians spend $20 billion USD every year on whitening creams, pills, lasers, injections, surgeries and various other ways to make their skin appear more pale. 

This white skin fashion trend is believed to have escalated in South Korea, with the K-pop movement, and has spread like wildfire around Asia.

I made this video to educate you about this phenomenon, because even after living in Asia for 5 years, I still cannot wrap my head around how massive of an impact is has on their culture. Here in Bangkok, you can't turn a corner without seeing a giant bilboard with a white face smiling back at you.

What are your thoughts on Asians craze for whiteness? Do you think it's a good thing for their society? Or perhaps long-term side effects may come as a result from taking whitening products? Please share your thoughts below.

title: Why I'm Frugal...
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Regardless of how much money I make, I don't like spending it on things I don't need. Plain and simple -- I am frugal.

Even if I made $10M a year, I'd still eat street food, sleep in budget hotels, book the cheapest flights and take the metro over a taxi. I don't ever see the need to spend crazy amounts of money on a fancy car or a giant house.  I am frugal.

But please note that being "FRUGAL" is not the same as being "CHEAP." Frugal means that I choose to prioritize my spending so I can have more of the things i love ‚Äî like travel and golf. Cheap simply means that I'd be is afraid to spend money on anything, thinking everything is overpriced.

So as a frugal person, I will always tip generously if the service is good and I will happily spend a few extra dollars if it means I‚Äôll be saving time. 

Like Warren Buffett -- the 3rd richest man in the world and someone I look up to -- I plan to give away a significant amount of my future income to charities and/or organizations who could benefit from it more than me. 

Does anyone else choose to live a frugal life? Or would you rather live in a giant mansion with a Ferrari in the garage? Comment below!

title: I Bought a Camel & Gave it to a Village (emotional)
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Get My Best Flight Hacks FREE! https://bit.ly/32sVpQV

Wow - what a bizarre and emotional adventure this was!  I can't wait for you to hear this story. 

I'm back here in the West African country of Mauritania for a second time.  It's a really special place with one of the most beautiful and unique cultures in the Sahel region (Sahara desert).  If one thing is important to the Mauritanian people, it is the CAMEL.  For thousands of years, that animal has been one of the largest sources of food and transportation.

So I had an idea.  I wanted to give back to the lovely people here because they have been so hospitable to me. 

I went to a camel market, purchased a camel for $450, and surprised an entire village with it.  

Words can‚Äôt describe the feeling and emotion after I saw the look on their faces.  It was a special moment that I will never forget. 

Thanks for watching and share this video if you enjoyed!

title: Thoughts on North Korea After 1 Year...
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Last year at this time, I was in Pyongyang, North Korea. It was the most eye-opening and surreal trip of my life. And the fact that I can speak Korean after living in Seoul, gave me a deeper understanding for what was happening around me, North of the 38th parallel.

One year later, I cannot stop thinking about my trip to North Korea --especially after all of the events & controversies that have happened since then. It's surreal to know that I'm one of the last Americans to visit the country, as the U.S. government issued a travel ban on all Americans to visit the DPRK effective last July.

I just put together this video to recap my thoughts and realizations about North Korea, as I take you back on my interesting journey around the most isolated country in the world. 

What are your thoughts on North Korea? Would you ever go there if you had the chance? If you are considering a trip, let me know and I can connect you with my friends at Koryo Tours, the amazing company I went with.

description:

Meet Niels - he is from one of the world's most isolated towns (Ittoqqortoormiit, Greenland).  He grew up alongside polar bears and massive glaciers inside the largest national park and fjord system on earth.   He knows all 350 residents in his town by name and the closest city is thousands of kilometers away.

Despite traveling and studying overseas, he chooses to remain back home because he loves his hometown.  That's very admirable!

It was a pleasure spending the day with Niels in one of the most fascinating places I've ever been.  I hope to go back again another in the wintertime!

title: This Religion Survived ISIS (YAZIDIS)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

A story about the Yazidis and the genocide of Yazidism by ISIS.

This is a very sad story, but one that I feel needs to be told because of the lack of international attention that the Yazidi people have received.

In short, the Yazidis -- who are both an ethnic group and religion -- were targeted and attacked by ISIS in 2014.  On August 3rd of that year, ISIS stormed in one of their beloved towns called Shingal, killing men by the thousands and forcing women into sexual slavery.   And those women who didn't follow their rules (including converting to Islam) were killed.

Today I went to the tiny mountainous village in North Eastern Iraq called Lalish -- which is the site of the holiest temple in Yazidism.  Is it their "Mecca" equivalent. In Lalish, it is forbidden to wear shoes to acknowledge the purity of their religion.  

I met some people who survived the genocide and I asked them a few questions.  This is what they have to say.

This content is not my favorite to make. It's difficult.  It's raw.  It's depressing.  But once again, I feel like it is extremely important to raise awareness -- especially in this case, as it just happened 5 years ago.

Join me on Instagram @drewbinsky.

I've made it safely to my 134th country - PAPUA NEW GUINEA! The last 48 hours here in PNG have been nothing short of incredible. I am truly amazed by how culturally and linguistically diverse Papua New Guinea is -- 12% of all the world's spoken languages are here! It's like an unexplored wonderland, and I couldn't be happier to be here right now!  Papua New Guinea is the world's last frontier.  

I got in touch with a friend of a friend, Bruce, who has let me crash at his place and he has driven me all over the country. This video gives you an inside look at my perspectives of Papua New Guinea and some of the interesting things I've learned so far about this remote country.

title: WHAT'S HAPPENING IN LEBANON? (Lebanese Revolution)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I‚Äôm so excited to be back in LEBANON for the 3rd time! This country is, without question, one of my favorites in the world for so many reasons.  

... But things here right now are not how I remembered them in the past.  

For the last 48 days, there has been a revolution happening where people of all ages, religions and political parties have been on the streets protesting for a better Lebanon. 

I wandered around downtown Beirut to interview random locals and hear their thoughts, because their voices want to be heard.  Loud and clear. 

If there's one takeaway I have from today, it's that the vast majority of people in this country are coming together as one.  I've never seen or experienced anything like it.   It's beautiful to witness.

TEACHING ENGLISH (or your native language) OVERSEAS IS THE BEST OPPORTUNITY TO GET PAID TO TRAVEL THE WORLD --- and I'm here to be a resource & help you get on your way to have the best experience of your life.

Two months after I graduated college, I packed my bags and moved 10,500 kilometers over the Pacific Ocean to a small village outside of Seoul, South Korea to teach English. It was my first time in Korea and in Asia, and I was instantly hooked.

My salary in Korea was $2,000/month -- which doesn't sound like a lot -- but when paired with amazing benefits like free housing, reimbursed round-trip flights, covered health insurance, 2 weeks paid vacation, $5K in year-end bonuses & free every day lunches.... I was able to live very comfortably.

During my 1.5 years teaching English in Korea, I visited 18 new Asian countries, partied every weekend, and ate Korean BBQ 3 nights a week and STILL had money left over to save. Sound like a dream? YOU can do it too!

In this video, I give you details about my experience teaching english in Korea and provide exclusive tips for how you can also teach your native language abroad.

title: How Portuguese is Mozambique?
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75

HELLO from MOZAMBIQUE, my 124th country!!

I had no idea what to expect before arriving here... and right off the bat, I have been shocked to see everyone speaking Portuguese!! Did you know they speak Portuguese here in Mozambique? It's exactly like Brazil!

Moreover, walking the streets of Maputo (the capital city) feels like I am back in India -- with the loud rickshaws, colorful markets and overall chaos on the streets... It's safe to say that I draw a LOT of attention here as there are very few foreigners (and the #GingerBeard isn't helping!!)

Have you ever been to Mozambique? What are your thoughts?

title: HE DOES EVERYTHING!
description:
Patrick is one of the coolest and nicest guys I‚Äôve met in all my travels. He's the definition of an entrepreneur, a workaholic and a hustler. He really does everything!

When he saw that I was coming to Gabon, he immediately reached out on Facebook and offered to show me around his hometown of Libreville. Not only did he pick me up at the airport, give me a room in his house to crash at and take me all over his town of Libreville, Gabon ‚Äî but he wouldn‚Äôt let me spend a dime. 

I tried and tried and tried to pay for food, gas, etc, but he wouldn‚Äôt let me. What did he expect in return? Absolutely nothing.

It‚Äôs people like Patrick who make me really appreciate the people all over the world. He will be in all of my upcoming Gabon videos so stay tuned!

title: In This Country, KFC Turns Into A Proper Nightclub
description:
On weekend nights in Luanda, Angola -- every KFC turns into a nightclub!! I could not make this stuff up!

Angolans, in general, love to party and they take their nightlife very seriously... People make parties on sidewalks outside of convenient stores and makeshift bars on street corners. But the scene at KFC is so unique that I had to share it with you! 

There are about 8 KFCs in Luanda, and they each hire a DJ to play tunes in the evenings to a young beer-drinking crowd. Can life get any better than this?!

description:

Exactly 4 months ago today, I anxiously crossed the border from Lebanon in to Syria -- my 183rd country.  

Saying that I was nervous on the morning of November 20th is an understatement.  As a Jewish, American journalist -- I was petrified.  

But it turns out that I had one of the most inspiring 2 weeks of my life traveling independently around Syria, and not a day goes by where I haven't reflected on my trip.   I've never experienced kindness and hospitality like I have in Syria, and that has left a lasting impression on me to return.  

Not that I've had 4 months to gather my thoughts, I wanted to share them with you in today's video.

title: The PLASTIC MAN (Dakar, Senegal)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Meet Modou, one of the most inspiring people in Senegal!  

Nearly every single day, he walks alone in the hot streets of Dakar, dressed in a plastic suit from head to toe.  

Why does he do this? 

To protest against the severe plastic waste, and urge people to care more for the environment.   

He got inspired to do this after serving in the army some 20 years ago.  Not only did he protect his fellow citizens, but he also learned about the importance to protect our mother earth.  

West Africa, much like other regions of the world (I'm looking at you, South East Asia) have a horrible problem of overconsumption of single-use plastic.  Thanks to people like Modou, we can educate the local population about the issues that plastic brings, and force them to alter their lifestyles.   

Share this to help spread the word!

Follow @Drew Binsky on Instagram for more stories! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: The Rise of Women in Pakistan
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Much like its neighboring countries in South Asia, Pakistan's society has always been dominated by men.  Men are seen in the office , in the government chairs and walking around the streets. 

Gender equality is essential for a country to develop both economically and socially -- and thankfully for Pakistan, it's starting to change.

In recent years, there's been a huge uplift in women's empowerment and women's role in Pakistani society.   More women are being employed at higher jobs positions, more women are voting in the elections and more women are getting their voices heard.

Since I've arrived in Pakistan, I made it a mission to find and interview Pakistani women who are doing inspiring things and changing the game.  Here are 5 of them that I've met so far, who are carving the path for hundreds of millions of women in this country.

I'm on Instagram, too! @drewbinsky

title: ISFAHAN (Iran) is "HALF THE WORLD?!"
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Ladies & Gentlemen: I have found my new favorite city in Iran and one of the coolest places on Earth -- ISFAHAN!

Our G Adventures tour continues in this UNESCO World Heritage city that has so much beauty, the locals turned in into a Persian phrase "IsfahƒÅn nesf-e- jahƒÅn" meaning "Isfahan is half the world."

If you want to see how magical this city is, just head over to Naqsh-e Jahan Square (the 2nd largest city square in the world) right before sunset, have a picnic in the grass, and observe the beautiful 17th Century Mosques and Palaces overlooking thousands of people going about their daily business in Isfahan. Then, try to imagine all the trading and sporting events (i.e. polo) that unfolded here 400+ years ago!

Join me as I explore the ins and outs of Isfahan, and prove that it really does live up to its title of "half the world."

If you are planning a trip to Iran and only have one place to visit -- I would highly recommend Isfahan! Have you ever been here before? Can anybody back me up on this?

This is the amazing story of talented beatboxer Neil Llanes, who comes from the city of Davao in Southern Philippines. 

He first discovered his talent from the young age of 12, but it wasn't until he became a finalist on the hit show "Asia's Got Talent" when his career really took off.    Since then, Neil has performed gigs all over the world.  He has earned income to buy his family a new house, to buy himself a fancy motorcycle and to open up 2 businesses in town... but through it all, he remains incredibly humble and is always giving back to his community.  

I discovered Neil through his "Asia's Got Talent" video on YouTube (which has over 100M views!) and it's been a pleasure to spend the day with him in Davao (watch until the end to see us eating durian together!)    He is truly the unbelievable beatboxer!

title: BAGHDAD STREET FOOD TOUR (5 Dishes for $15)
description:
üåç GET 50% OFF MY TRAVEL HACKING COURSE by using discount code YOUTUBE:  https://www.drewbinsky.com/course
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

This is my final video from Iraq.  I've had the time of my life traveling through this country and I hope you've enjoyed my stories here over the last 9 weeks. 

On my final day in Iraq, I met up with my long time Iraqi friend, Baderkhan, who you might know well from the many videos we shot together in Iraqi Kurdistan.  We hit the streets of Baghdad (his hometown), and tried all of the best street food that the city has to offer!  We were able to eat 5 dishes for just $15USD total, now that's a bargain!

Little did we know how scary this video would be to shoot -- I left my passport in my hotel room (which is a BIG no-no in Iraq), so we tried to dodge the police the entire day.  If you can remember last week, I was thrown into a police station in the marshlands for using my GoPro... Find out if we made it to the end without any police encounters!

Also - it's with a heavy heart to explain that 24 hours after we shot this video, there was massive attack in the exact same market, on the exact same street, during the exact same time of the day.  I was devastated to hear the news, and I couldn't believe our luck - we escaped it by just 24 hours.   My deepest condolences go out to all of the loved ones that were lost in this horrible act, and I hope the city will return back to its glory days.

Thanks again for watching my videos and I look forward to sharing my next stories in Dubai and Mauritania!

Follow @drewbinsky for more stories from EVERY country, and join me on Insta! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

This morning in Mexico City, I met up with Jonathan who is the creator of MOM, I'M FINE.   You probably have come across his viral posts on Instagram -- his concept is amazing and I really admire his work!

But I came to discover that Jonathan's mission goes much further than just holding up a sign...  He is the only person I have met who is using his social media followers to collectively build a school made out of recycled plastic.  They already have 200+ architects working on this project, along with countless engineers and creative minds.  And this is only one of his many projects in which he is using his online community in all the best ways!

It has been an absolute pleasure meeting Jonathan today, and there were some amazing synergies between us.  You will definitely see us traveling together and working on some exciting projects in the near future.

title: Eating a Live Octopus (IN ONE BITE)  in Seoul!
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Check out my travel blog for more: http://thehungrypartier.com/

I ate a live octopus in Seoul, Korea.  I ate the entire thing it in one single bite at the Noryangjin Fish Market.  It was a crazy, awesome, and SLIMY experience!

I probably will never do this again, because it was not good.  Apparently you are suppose to dip it in oil so it doesn't suffocate you and kill you (this happens several times a year).  But I didn't know!  

Eating a live octopus in seoul is actually a common thing, and I am happy that I tried it.  Next time, I will dip the octopus in sauce!

title: World's BEST DRUMMERS (Burundi) üáßüáÆ
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

This is one of my favorite stories that I've ever told you!! 

Welcome to BURUNDI, country #186.  This East African nation is overshadowed in many ways by its neighbors of Rwanda, Tanzania, DRC and Uganda -- but there is SO MUCH life happening on these streets, nothing more impressive than their insane drumming skills!

Today, I drove 3 hours from the capital of Bujumbura to a small village called Gishora to witness the drumming culture where it all started.  In fact, they claim to have invented the drum here way back in the day (made of wood and cow skin), and they are expert drummers to this day.  It's a full production of dancing, singing and ... carrying drums on their heads?  It's much harder than it looks! 

Here is the full story, which I hope you enjoy -- I stayed up all night editing this one cuz I am so excited to share :)  

This is Africa at it's finest.

description:

First off, I want to say THANK YOU for all your kind words and messages these past few days. It feels surreal to be able to say the sentence, ‚ÄúI have been to every single country in the world!‚Äù There will be many incredible stories being made these next 2 weeks as I travel across Saudi Arabia. 

But let‚Äôs not forget about Palau! This is my last video from this beautiful Pacific-island nation, and it‚Äôs one of my favorites!  Palau has a population of less than 18,000 residents. For comparison, my University (Wisconsin-Madison) was two times larger than that! 

I challenged myself to see if I could throw the biggest meet-up/party that this country has ever seen. In order to do that, I had to get permission from the Palau‚Äôs Visitors Authority as well as the President himself.  

Let‚Äôs just say that it was one of the most fun events I‚Äôve ever thrown!!!  I hope you enjoy this story, and thanks for watching my Palau series.  It‚Äôs one of the most beautiful countries in the world and I can‚Äôt wait to go back!

title: WHAT IS JOLLIBEE? (Philippines)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

**I made this video 3 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

HAVE YOU EVER HEARD OF JOLLIBEE, or seen the dazzling red bee mascot in your country?

If not, then find out why Filipinos are going ABSOLUTELY CRAZY over this unique fast-food chain.  In the Philippines, Jollibee is way more popular than McDonald's, Burger King, Taco Bell, Wendys or any other fast food chain you can think of.  They have the strangest menu items, such as a sweet spaghetti with red hot dogs and a pineapple burger, but I will have to admit that Jollibee hits the spot every time.  It's on every corner in the Philippines (and in over 30 countries around the world).  You have to give it a try if you ever pass by one!

title: Entering Macau | The Las Vegas of Asia
description:
If you think Las Vegas his the gambling center of the world, then think again!

WELCOME TO MACAU ‚Äî this Chinese owned, former Portuguese colony and semi-independent nation will leave you absolutely stunned.

It's my 3rd time in Macau over the last few years, and I get more and more fascinated with each visit. 

Macau is not only the "Las Vegas of Asia" ‚Äî it is home to 8 of the 10 largest casinos in the world, which take in over 5 times the annual revenue as Sin City.   Let's just say that the Chinese love to gamble, and it shows when you walk around this place called Macau. 

Gambling aside, Macau is a great place to walk around and enjoy the European architecture while eating delicious Portuguese snacks.  

Have you ever been to Macau? What are your thoughts on Macau? Comment below, and please let me know if you need any advice for Macau!

title: Speaking 20 Languages in 90 Seconds!
description:
HOW MANY LANGUAGES CAN YOU SPEAK?!

Here's a fun video of me speaking 20 languages in 15 countries! How many languages can you speak?! I am conversational in Spanish and Korean, semi-conversational in Czech and Russian, and I know many words/phrases in Tagalog, Hebrew, Vietnamese and Thai. 

Learning languages is one of the most rewarding parts about travel. It allows me to experience a culture through a new lens, and gives me a deeper understanding of the people's lives and what's happening around me. When I was recently in Equatorial Guinea, I spent a few minutes talking to the owner of a restaurant in Spanish -- and then, I already felt comfortable with my surroundings!

Before I visit any new country, I always try to learn a few basic words (i.e. yes, no, please, thank you, one, two, three) -- and in many countries, I try to learn a bit more. 

I had a lot of fun making this video last year over 2 months in 15 different countries -- THANK YOU to all my friends who helped translate these sentences for me in their respective languages. I am sharing it now on YT because until now, it has only been available on FB!

title: 4 Reasons I Love Islam and Muslim People
description:

At this point in my life, I‚Äôve spent more than 1 year traveling across Muslim-majority countries.  And many of them (like Iran, Afghanistan, Tajikistan, Syria, Indonesia) are my favorite nations in the world! 

Growing up as a Jew in the USA, I was told by many that Muslims are bad people‚Ä¶ but that can‚Äôt be farther away from the truth!   There is a huge misconception about Muslims.  They are some of the most respectful, hospitable, and friendly souls on the planet, and I learned this from experience.  

As I reflect here in Nouakchott, Mauritania on the last day of 8 months on the road, I wanted to share some of my honest thoughts about Islam.

title: My Thoughts on Tipping in the USA
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

For better or for worse, tipping is a huge part of American culture.  You must tip all bartenders, tour guides, restaurants waiters/waitresses, and anyone else in the service industry.   

The rest of the world, with the exception of a few countries, doesn't have much of a tipping culture.  In some countries (i.e. Japan), tipping is considered rude and will confuse the waiter/waitress!

Every time I come back home to the States after a long trip abroad (like I am now), I get frustrating with tipping.  I never know how much to give or how little to give.   

Why is it the customer's choice to decide the salary of the worker?   In my eyes, it makes a lot more sense to pay the service worker a higher salary so tipping is optional.  

What are your viewpoints on America's tipping culture? I'd love to hear your thoughts below!

title: 70 YEARS Making Mosaics (2 Syrian Brothers)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I have just discovered the most adorable, humble and friendly brothers -- Antonio and Ibrahim -- who own a mosaic shop on the side streets of Damascus, Syria!

My friend Ghaidaa and I randomly walked inside and were so impressed by their artwork and hospitality, that it was only natural to make a video on their story!

They've been working right here, in this exact shop, for the last 70 years without taking any time off -- even during the height of the war a few years ago.  It's beyond my imagination how much dedication and resistance these men have, and they do it all with a sense of humor.

Antonio and Ibrahim are a perfect example of the kindness of Syrian people -- nearly everyone I've met so far on the streets have welcomed me in the same ways that they have.

Can you see why I'm loving Syria so much?!

title: CRAZY COVID TRAVEL STORY (trapped in ANTARCTICA!)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ Fatima's YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/Toomzielicious
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

My good Kuwaiti friend Fatima AlMattar, who is a fellow world traveler and content creator, has the most bizarre travel story that happened to her about 2 months ago.   I just caught up with her on Zoom this morning and here is our conversation!  

Long story short, Fatima was on a 11 day cruise to Antarctica when the Covid-19 outbreak began.  When she departed Ushuaia, Argentina (March 9th) things were quite normal... then she lost phone signal for 7 days as she enjoyed the beautiful wonders of Antarctica, but when she finally got internet, the world was not the same. 

The Argentinian government would not let them dock back in Argentina, so they were forced to go to Montevideo, Uruguay and get on an immediate flight to Los Angeles because the Kuwait airport was closed. 

Then you won't believe what her journey was like to fly back home (a few weeks ago) during the heat of the pandemic. 

Thank you Fatima for sharing your courageous story, and I am so glad that you're safe at home!  Follow her Instagram and YouTube to keep up with her travels:

https://www.instagram.com/hello965/
https://www.youtube.com/user/Toomzielicious

title: What is Ramadan? My Humble Experiences as a Jew
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I was born and raised Jewish, yet I have spent the entirety of Ramadan in Muslim countries the past 3 weeks -- The Maldives and Iran.  (**Note, this video is 2 weeks delayed**)

To be honest with you, the more I travel in Islamic countries and surround myself with Muslim people, the more amazed I am by how humble and hospitable they are. 

Similar situations have happened to me in Oman, Tajikistan, Kuwait, Morocco, Bahrain, Qatar, UAE and Jordan (to name a few). I openly tell people in these countries that I am Jewish, and I've never had a single person discriminate against me for my religion. 

Ramadan is the month-long Islamic holiday where billions of Muslims around the world fast from sunrise to sunset every day. It has been a pleasant surprise to learn about this holy month of Ramadan, which is about to end this weekend, so I wanted to make this video to give you an inside look of how I've discovered Ramadan.

Going back to the religion thing -- there is a big misconception that being "Jewish" is unsafe for traveling around the Middle East or Arabic/Islamic countries. I don't know why people think this way, because from my experiences of telling people I am Jewish, the opposite happens -- they become more curious and want to get to know me! 

What are your thoughts on this?

title: COVID RELATIONSHIP (How We Manage Long Distance)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

For anyone who is in a long-distance relationship, especially if both partners come from different countries, then you know how difficult the past year has been during covid. 

Deanna and I have only see each other two times in the past 4 months, once in Turkey and now we are in Tanzania.  We are forced to keep meeting in 3rd party countries, because the Philippines is completely closed and they are not allowing any foreigners to enter for any reason.   Even though our apartment, our puppy and our lives are set in Manila, I am unable to go back home and it really crushes me. 

This is a video that Deanna and I wanted to make to share with you some of our struggles during this time, and we hope that some of you out there can relate to us.  If you are in a long-distance relationship and you've faced similar problems, we'd love to hear from you in the comments below!

Stay strong everyone, we will get through these dark days together ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: The FOOD WASTE MAN (Myanmar)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Today on the outskirts of Yangon, Myanmar, I met an amazing guy named Inda who started Bokashi Myanmar.   His vision is to create a cleaner and greener Myanmar by turning everyday FOOD WASTE into rich soil including plants, fruits and vegetables.  

All you have to do is store all of your food waste at home into little bins to ferment for a week, then add the magical Bokashi bran and after 6-8 weeks, your food waste transformers into living soil.

It's such an easy concept -- almost too simple to believe -- but it really works as I saw with my own eyes, and and everyone can do it at home!

Bokashi can be purchased online and shipped to anywhere worldwide, so SHARE this video to help spread the word and inspire others how easy it is to live a more sustainable life.

title: Behind the Scenes of My Life (Daily Video Making)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Today, I'd like to take you behind the scenes of my daily life as a video creator.  

Long story short, IT'S A LOT MORE WORK THAN YOU THINK.

It takes me roughly 15 hours to make each 3-4 minute video that you see pop up on your newsfeed every day (idea creation, scripting, scouting locations, meeting locals, shooting, editing, uploading)...

I work 7 days a week, 365 days a year -- even on holidays, days when I'm flying over an ocean (like today) and when I am sick.  I guess you can call it an addition, and I am not planning to stop making daily travel videos until I step foot in my 197th country (hopefully in January 2020!).

If you are also a video maker, then you will feel me on constant struggles and pressure that we go through to deliver compelling stories.   It's not easy, and it does take a certain person who is able (and willing) to push themselves mentally and physically on a daily basis.    

And while it may seem like I am complaining -- that is not the case.  I love my job and I cannot imagine doing anything else!  I have found my niche, my voice, and my happiness with showing you all the world through my lens!

If you are reading this right now, I want to say thank you for joining me on this wild adventure.  Bigger and better things to come, I promise!  #Pakistan #Afghanistan #Iraq

Instagram @drewbinsky.  Thank you Michael Makes Films for helping me shoot this video together.

title: The LGBTQ+ LANGUAGE of the PHILIPPINES (Gay Lingo)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Believe it or not, there is an entire language in the Philippines that is spoken, written and understood by members of LGBTQ+ community and those who associate with them.    

It's known officially as "Swardspeak," unofficially known as "Gay Lingo," and in a nutshell, it's a mixture of Tagalog, English, Spanish and random celebrity names or random objects which means specific things when used in certain contexts. 

In my opinion, gay lingo is one of the most uplifting and admirable things about modern Filipino culture, and as someone who can speak Spanish and understand basic Tagalog, it's a very unique blend to my ears.   

Have you ever heard of Gay Lingo before?  What are your thoughts about it?

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG Stories for more stories like this! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: THIS TOWN IS CALLED TEQUILA (seriously!)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Everyone has heard of the alcoholic beverage called TEQUILA, but did you know that it's actually the name of a lively town in MEXICO?!

...Either did I, until I came to the state of Jalisco and learned all about it!  The town of Tequila is everything you'd imagine it to be and more.  It's where the main production of tequila takes place in Mexico and the entire region is surrounded by blue agave plants - the main ingredient that the drink comes from. The landscape is so beautiful that it has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Share this video if you also love TEQUILA!

title: Where is His Home? Slovakia or Thailand?
description:
WHERE IS HIS HOME? SLOVAKIA OR THAILAND?

I'd like to introduce you to my good friend, Juraj.  We met last year while living in his (current) home of Bangkok, and now I am visiting his (original) home of Myjava, Slovakia.  He has been living abroad for the last 11 years.

It's very interesting to see how Juraj's perspectives have changed so much after living overseas for so long, but when he comes back home, it's all the same as he remembers.

The same feeling happens to me every time I go home, and I'm just curious how many of you guys can relate to this situation?  Comment below, I'd love to hear from you!

title: Traveling to 50 Countries... with 2 Kids!
description:
Hi Guys! I have a really exciting video to share with you today.  Meet the traveling Goy's (AKA the Wonderlusters) -- I bumped into them this morning at a temple in Sri Lanka, and after speaking with them for a bit, I decided to make this spontaneous video of their inspiring journey. 

Long story short, this family of 4 sold everything back home (Quebec, Canada) to go on a 15 MONTH trip to 50 COUNTRIES for LESS THAN $70,000 USD TOTAL. 

I caught them half way on their journey, and I was very impressed to hear about their adventures. I know how tedious it is to plan long trips (as a solo traveler), and I could not imagine doing it for 4 people... not to mention, the patience they have to constantly watch over a 9 and 7 year old!

The Goy's use all sorts of travel hacks to minimize their expenses (i.e. 16 credit cards to collect points) and they homeschool their youngsters on the road.   If you ask me, no kids on this planet are getting a better education right now than Mateo and Luka, as they experience first-hand the wonders of the world.

Share this video if you feel inspired (and if you wish your parents would have taken you to 50 countries before you turned 10)!

Follow @drewbinsky on Insta for daily travel stories.  You can follow the Goy's journey on Facebook @The Wonderlusters around the world and on Instagram @wonderlustrs.

title: THE LAND OF BASEBALL ‚öæÔ∏è(Dominican Republic)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

The DOMINICAN REPUBLIC and BASEBALL go together like peanut butter and jelly.   It is (by far) the most popular sport in the country, and they have sent more players to the big leagues than any other country besides the United States.   That is beyond impressive for a country of just 11 million!

Baseball is seen as a gateway for many families to escape poverty, as teenagers as young as 16 years old have the chance to sign multi-million-dollar contracts.   

Each one of the 30 MLB teams have a baseball academy in the D.R., and I was lucky enough to be invited to the Arizona Diamondbacks facility and was very impressed by the talent of these young kids.  

As a former baseball player and huge fan, I truly had a blast shooting this video over the last few days around the Dominican Republic and I hope you enjoy watching!!

title: INDIA (Kerala) NEEDS YOUR HELP
description:
The state of Kerala in India is currently undergoing one of the biggest natural disasters in the country's history, yet, nobody is talking about it. 

Massive storms and flash floods have been causing landslides, collapsing buildings and destroying houses -- killing 350+ people (so far) and forcing nearly a half-million people to evacuate their homes with minimal (or no) food, water, shelter and electricity. 

These innocent people are hopeless. 

If you'd like to donate supplies to help the people who are going through this catastrophic event, please do so on this Amazon link:
https://amzn.to/2nNsz67

You will be able to purchase items (food, toothpaste, towels, etc) that Amazon will deliver to the flood victims in correspondence with NGOs on the ground. 

If you are unable to donate, then sharing this video will help the chances that someone else will donate. At the very least, join me in keeping Kerala in our thoughts and prayers.

title: Why I HATE Politics...
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I couldn't wait any longer to make this video.

I hate politics. With a burning passion. This is something that I haven't discussed much, but I feel very passionate about. 

In my eyes, politics = negativity, turmoil & greed. Nearly all politicians in this world are obsessed with 2 things: money and power, and I've witnessed and/or heard stories about this happening in each of the 140 countries I have visited.

Sure, politics is important for putting necessary laws in place, for assuring people can live safely in their country and for understanding how the world works... But I don't understand why it always has to revolve around negativity when there is SO MUCH MORE POSITIVITY happening around us!

I guess what I am trying to say is that I am a very positive and optimistic person, and politics is exactly the opposite -- so I choose not to involve myself in politics in any way, shape or form.

I'd love to get your thoughts and opinions about this - do you also remove yourself from politics? Or are you one of those people who can't get enough?

description:

I just spent the most incredible day with the most inspiring dude in Saman√°, Dominican Republic.  His name is Bartolo, AKA the Tree House Dude, because he made his childhood dreams come true by building the most epic Tree House Village in the middle of the jungle.   You have to see it to believe it!

It wasn't always easy for Bartolo, as he grew up in a very poor household in Boise, Idaho.  To pay for his college, which took him 13 years to complete, he was scrubbing toilets and running a commercial cleaning company...  Then when he graduated, he went on vacation in the Dominican Republic, where he found his "true calling" as he says, and he has never left since then. 

Here is the full story of Bartolo.  If you ever go to the Dominican Republic, then do me a favor and stay at the Dominican Tree House Village!

Special thanks to "That Jungle Life" for the extra footage.

title: SYRIA IS MOVING ON... (Bright Future Ahead)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/
‚ñ∫ SOS: https://soschretiensdorient.fr/index.php/fr/

Syria has been in a constant state of war since 2011, and as a result, an estimated 400,000 lives have been lost, $250 billion of damage has been done, historical monuments and important buildings have been demolished and the economy is struggling to get back on its feet. 

But the Syrian people remain strong, and that's the focus of this video.  They are the most resilient people in the world.  You can see the hope and desire in each and every one of their eyes to get back to the life they used to live. 

Today in Aleppo, I visited several ordinary people who lost their loved ones, their homes and all their belongings. Here are their stories. 

I want to send a huge thank you to SOS Chr√©tiens d'Orient for allowing me to join your program and for your mission to help Syria rebuild and get back to its shining days before the war.   Check them out on the below website if you are interested to volunteer in Syria, or donate to the victims on the ground: https://soschretiensdorient.fr/index.php/fr/

title: 3 FRIENDS, 3 RELIGIONS (Jew + Muslim + Christian)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

The last 4 days of my life in Central African Republic have been spent with David, who is a Christian, and Fore, who is a Muslim.  I am Jewish. 

These guys are some of the best local hosts and friends I've made around the world.  Despite having 3 separate religions, it never held us back from getting along.  In fact, just the opposite happened -- we became curious about one another's beliefs and we had many great conversations.  Especially right now, in the midst of the holiday season!

There is a bigger message here that I hope you can all realize.  All 7 billion human beings on this planet should not be divided by our beliefs.   When it comes down to it, we are all the exact same. 

Thank you David and Fore for showing me an incredible time in your country, which my country's government currently issues the following travel advisory: Do not travel to Central African Republic (CAR) due to crime, civil unrest, and kidnapping.

title: Women Dominate This Nation
description:
In most of Asia, especially here in South Asia, the societies are heavily driven by men... It's not very common to see a majority of women working on their job, or even walking outside on the streets. 

But that's not the situation here, in Sri Lanka.  This country is ruled by women -- and it has been remarkable to witness.  

Everywhere I look, I am seeing countless women in the workforce -- at both white and blue collar jobs -- contributing to society as they should be.

It's amazing to see how the Sri Lankan government is rural women to get involved with entrepreneurship.  There's a popular restaurant chain all over this country called Hela Bojun, where women (and only women) are given a place to cook and sell their tastiest local dishes.   

And then you have Sthree, initiated by the Women‚Äôs Development Center, which empowers women through the eco friendly production of clothes and hand crafts, among several other innovations.  

Women's equality is just one of the many reasons to love Sri Lanka, and I can't wait to tell you more tomorrow!

Follow my trips on Instagram @drewbinsky - I am posting lots of content there too!

title: Visiting 1,900 Year Old Roman Ruins in Algeria
description:
Are you ready to see the most impressive Roman Ruins in the world?

Welcome to Djemila in Northern Algeria.  I bet you've never heard of this place before, and that just makes me even more excited to share this experience with you :)

It truly blows my mind that the Colosseum in Rome has 138,415 reviews on TripAdvisor, whereas Djemila has just 51... And if you ask me, the ruins in Djemila blow away any ruins I've ever seen before in my life.   

I had the entire ancient city to myself (along with my knowledgeable guide) for the 2 hours that we wandered around.   I became lost in time exploring the temples, theatres, houses, baths and markets because there wasn't any sound except for the wind.  

Have you ever heard of this place before? If not, then add it to your bucket list!

Join me on IG Stories (@DrewBinsky) to travel with me across Algeria in real time.
