title: Inside The Syrian Refugee Crisis of Lebanon
description:
Did you know that 1.5 MILLION Syrian refugees have settled in Lebanon since 2011? That's equivalent to 125 million refugees flooding into the United States over the last 7 years.

Syria's civil war has resulted in a horrible situation for its innocent people, but it's remarkable to see how Lebanon has opened their arms beyond their means to host these refugees.

Today, my friend Georgio and I contacted an NGO (The Humanitarian Foundation for Social Welfare & Education), who escorted us to a refugee camp with about 100 families living inside. I sat down with several families to hear their life stories and see how they have been impacted by the war.

I was so nervous before going in because I had never interacted with a Syrian or a refugee before, but I quickly found my comfort zone when I realized they are all people like you and me. They were all so friendly -- insisting that we stay in their houses longer for tea and coffee and enjoying our time spent together.

It was a very touching and emotional day for me, and I sincerely hope that these Syrian refugees get to return home soon.

If you'd like to donate for the Syrian refugee's food, health and life (anything will help) -- please do so on the following link üá∏üáæ‚ù§Ô∏èüá±üáß  https://bit.ly/2NqayoY. Thanks for watching, and please share your thoughts and comments on Syrian refugees below.

title: ONLY 2 PEOPLE LIVE on THIS ISLAND
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

**I made this video 3 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

Can you imagine living ALONE on an isolated island, that's freezing cold and windy all year-round? These two folks, John and Charlene, do just that!!!

Today, we arrived on the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas), our second stop of this Hurtigruten expedition. The Falklands are an archipelago of 740 islands in the South Atlantic Sea -- and we've landed on a tiny one in the Western part called 'New Island'... It's the most remote place I've ever been in my life, with some of the most incredible nature & wildlife I've seen (Rockhopper penguins, giant albatross, humpback whales, dolphins, black fur seals, wild rabbits and more). I felt like I was watching the Discovery Channel in real life!

I interviewed both John and Charlene about their lifestyles on New Island, why they decided to move here, etc -- because I find it fascinating... And I think you will too...

Could you ever live in complete isolation like they do? I don't think I could.

Music: Audio Autix

P.S. -- I had no idea that this island had inhabitants until we landed ashore today and were greeted by John and Charlene... so everything in this video was spontaneous and unplanned!

#DrewBinsky #Travel #Remote

title: THE SILVER CITY (Taxco, Mexico)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

What a pleasant surprise!!!  I took a 3 hour road trip from Mexico City a lovely small town called Taxco, which looks like a fairy tale! 

There are so many things to enjoy about Taxco, but it's most famous for having the purest silver in all of Mexico.  

Mining here began in the pre-Hispanic period with natives extracting a stones for ritual purposes. Then the Spanish came along and discovered silver in the early 16th Century, and they started commercial mining in the area and built an amazing church in 1758 which still stands today.  Even though mining has stopped in the region, the town of Taxco has remarkably carried on its silver tradition.  The streets are filled with hundreds of shops, markets and open air venues selling all kinds of fine silver jewelry and they still make every piece by hand.

If you come to Mexico, don't miss out on Taxco!

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram for more content from every country in the world: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

description:

The scariest situation of my entire life happened to me a few days ago. My main YouTube channel (this account) was hacked by a crypto scammer in China.  He changed the name of my account to ‚ÄúArk Invest‚Äù, changed the profile picture, deleted all of my videos, and was live-streaming a Bitcoin video featuring Elon Musk's face on the thumbnail.  When I found out the news on a golf course in Wisconsin, I blacked out for 2 hours and couldn‚Äôt speak... Seriously. Thankfully, YouTube has been SO responsive and amazing to help me recover my account, and now it's back in full health.  

THIS IS A PSA REMINDER TO CHANGE ALL YOUR PASSWORDS AND DON‚ÄôT CLICK ON RANDOM LINKS FROM RANDOM EMAILS.  HACKERS ARE EVERYWHERE, AND THEY ARE SMARTER THAN YOU.

Lastly, I want to say THANK YOU to this incredible community for all of your messages and support. I love you all!!!  I‚Äôm back!

title: How VIETNAMESE is PRAGUE?
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

Vietnamese people in Prague?  

Don't get confused by this title, there is actually a massive Vietnamese community in the Czech Republic -- especially right here in Prague!

I remember when I lived in Prague 7 years ago that there was a lot of Vietnamese restaurants, but I never really dug deeper to find out why they were here.  And now, I've realized that many of them came to Czechoslovakia during the communism period to work or study, and then when communism fell in the early 90s, they never left.

Here is the full story of the Vietnamese influence of Prague, which I find to be fascinating and incredible.

title: A Deep Teeth Cleaning for $18?!
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Today, I walked into a random dentist office in Bangkok, without an appointment or health insurance, paid $18 USD (600 Baht) and immediately saw a fantastic dentist, who gave me a deep teeth cleaning for an hour. Completely spotless. 

Back home, if I want to see a dentist for the same general teeth cleaning, I must make an appointment 3 months in advance AND pay 6X the price that I just paid in Thailand. For the exact same teeth cleaning!

The topic of this video goes beyond dental work -- it's health care in general. Thailand has one of the best overall health care systems in Asia (highly skilled doctors, incredibly modern hospital facilities, technologies, etc) -- and it's very cheap. Especially if you need to get any medications (prescription or over-the-counter), it's maybe 10X cheaper than back home. 

Many of you are going to bring politics into this video, but I am steering clear of that. I am only making this to introduce you to the world of health care in Thailand because many of you may not realize!

title: THE SOUTHERN END OF THE WORLD
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

**I made this video 2.5 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

HELLO FROM THE SOUTHERN END OF THE WORLD -- Cape Horn, Chile!

Cape Horn is the second-to-last stop on our Hurtigruten Expedition (I really don't want this trip to end!). It's the Southernmost point in South America, and the place where the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans meet.

Cape Horn is widely considered to have the most dangerous seas for sailors to cross, as thousands of lives have been taken since it was first discovered in 1616 by Dutch explorers. The hazardous year-round weather produces strong ocean currents, gale force winds and massive waves... Not to mention, the remoteness of these islands, far away from any civilization, make it very difficult to escape or call for help in an emergency situation.

Most attempted landings to Cape Horn have failed because of the wind & rain, but today we got EXTREMELY lucky with sunshine and moderate winds. I was told that this day is 1 in 100 by some of our crew members who have been to Cape Horn dozens of times.

Have you ever heard about Cape Horn? It's a great place to add to your bucket list! Also Chile is awesome!

Music: Kevin MacLeod

title: YOUR PERFUME GROWS HERE (60% of global supply)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Did you know that over HALF of the global supply of perfume comes from jasmine flowers in a small village in Northern Egypt?

The village is called Shubra Blula, and I came here today before sunrise to learn all about the process, which is fascinating! 

During the peak season (which is now), thousands of local residents spend their entire nights hand picking these beautiful white jasmine flowers directly from the plants.  Then, they are sent to a nearby factory to extract the liquid which is then sold to Paris, New York, Hong Kong and all around the world to be bottled up into perfume. 

Who knew that Egypt is the king of the perfume world?  I surely didn't before this trip!

title: MY UNFORTUNATE BIRTHDAY (thoughts on turning 29)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Today is my 29th birthday, and it's certainly one for the record books... 

In late March, I was certain that I'd be on a 9-week trip visiting my final 6 countries, while filming a 90-minute documentary along the way.  I was supposed to be in Palau in this very moment.

Well, clearly, that isn't happening... yet.  I'm stuck right now in L.A. and I have no idea when I'll be on the road again.  That is a very scary sentence to say. 

In today's video, I set down my camera and spoke my thoughts for 9 minutes straight.  

Thank you in advance for the birthday wishes, and more importantly, I want to thank YOU for all of your support over the years.  Without you guys, I would probably be working a 9-5 somewhere and even more depressed with life at the moment.  

We will get through this mess.  It will end.  Life, as we knew it, will return.  We must keep these positive thoughts and affirmations going in our heads.    

Thanks for listening.  Wash your hands.  Stay 6 feet apart. Love you all and have a great day!

Follow @DrewBinsky on Instagram more (happier) travel stories: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

description:

**I made this video 3 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

IT'S ALL SMILES HERE FROM AMMAN, JORDAN üáØüá¥ 

Today was fantastic. We toured all around Amman -- visited ruins and museums, learned about the ancient history, ate lots of hummus and falafel, and I hosted a meet up with lots of likeminded travelers!  There is no doubt in my mind that this is the safest city in the Middle East.  Heck, it's safer than anywhere I've been in the USA!

Also, I literally haven't slept a wink in 35 hours since leaving Manila and spending all last night editing videos in the Dubai airport... I'M COMPLETELY DEAD. Especially after editing this video. My brain hurts. Going to sleep now, and gotta wake up at 6AM to visit Petra!

Has anyone else been to Amman, Jordan, and can back me up on the fact that it's extremely safe?  I want to hear from you in the comments below!

P.S. - I love the Middle East ‚ù§Ô∏è Every time I come here, I am overwhelmed by how welcoming and friendly the people are. I've never experienced hospitality like this in any other part of the world.

title: I Went To Every Country & Here‚Äôs My 7 Favorites!
The Power of Hard Work
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

THE POWER OF HARD WORK AS A VIDEO MAKER!

As I approach 2 million Facebook friends and 1 billion overall views, I'd like to recap how I got here and share with you some of my realizations from this crazy journey to every country in the world.

It hasn't been easy making daily videos and my job is quite stressful, especially when you get food poisoning or when your flight get cancelled or when you don't have strong enough wifi to upload -- but in the end, I love my job.  I am simply addicted to traveling the world and moreover, giving you guys a glimpse of different cultures as I experience them myself.  I do this for you. 

Lastly, if you are reading this, I want to say THANK YOU, from the bottom of my heart, for your endless support and encouragement.   If there's one thing I'm sure of... it's that this party is just getting started.

Join me on IG Stories (@DrewBinsky) where I share all of the best behind the scenes travel moments.  See you tomorrow from Slovakia!

title: World's Largest Primate (MOUNTAIN GORILLAS) ü¶çüá®üá©
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

TODAY WAS AN AMAZING EXPERIENCE IN THE DR CONGO!!

I went trekking in the middle of the Congolese rainforest (Virunga National Park) to witness the incredible mountain gorillas in their natural habitat.  If you can remember about 2 years ago, I did something similar in Uganda, but to be honest, it's 10X better in the DRC because we were the only ones here in this remote setting.   I just can‚Äôt believe how human-like they are!

In other positive news, the world population of mountain gorillas has risen from about 600 to over 1,000 in the last decade, moving them from "critically endangered" to just "endangered."

title: THE ORIGINAL HIPPIE (on Lamma Island, Hong Kong)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Nick is what many people call as the "original hippie" on Hong Kong.  

Yes, he's from Hong Kong, but not from the hectic business districts -- he's from an outer island called Lamma Island.  It's a completely different world than Hong Kong Island, and it's just a 20 minute ferry ride away.  I've been to Hong Kong 8 times, and this is my first time on Lamma and my mind is completely blown! 

This is the story of Nick's peaceful life, and why he's never shaved his beard nor left Hong Kong since 1984.  What a guy!

title: You Won't Believe This Market!
description:
Seriously though... you won't believe what happens in this market in Thailand (MAEKLONG MARKET)!  It's like a scene straight out of a movie.  About 100 km west of Bangkok is the "train market," where several times a day, a massive TRAIN cuts directly through the market! All of the vendors quickly move their fresh produce, wait for the train to pass, and then set up again.  It's one of the craziest scenes that you will ever witness.

Have you ever been to or heard about Bangkok's train market before?  Share this with a friend who you'd take with!

title: Smart People Exist Beyond the USA?
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I realize the title & subject of this video may seem extremely obvious to many of you. 

But half of the people following this page are Americans, and along with the 330 million others who make up my country, a large amount of them probably wouldn‚Äôt realize my points in this video. 

One of my biggest issues with American society is that many of us are so trapped in our own 'bubble' and rarely look outside our borders to gain any value. We turn on local news instead of world news. We think the American dream is the only dream. We travel domestically and are scared to go abroad. 

The truth is, that I am constantly meeting smart, innovate and successful people EVERYWHERE I go -- even in the smallest of countries. 

What are your thoughts on this? Do you also think Americans are trapped in a bubble? 

P.S. This video is in not hating on the USA or American culture. I am a proud American and I will always support my country. I just felt the need to raise awareness that we aren't the only place with smart people and good colleges. The entire world is.

title: WHY I LOVE SANTIAGO, CHILE üá®üá±
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

**I made this video 2.5 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

I'm not kidding when I say that SANTIAGO, CHILE is one of the most underrated cities in South America!! The last 4 days here have been absolutely perfect!

Santiago often gets overlooked by other South American cities like Buenos Aires, Rio de Janeiro and even Lima -- but don't let that fool you, because Santiago truly has it all, and it surely caught me by surprise.

Chile, as a whole, is the longest country in the world (4,300 km) from North to South, and it has a lot to offer (especially for all you nature lovers). From the Atacama desert in the North, to the fjords in the South and the spectacular landscapes of Patagonia in between.

Also, did you know that Chile has the most stable economy and government in all of Latin America? I could certainly notice this by the hustle and bustle on the streets, where so many people here have small businesses and are hustling to make an extra buck (as opposed to begging or making money in illegal ways). Pretty impressive stuff, if you ask me.

I'm looking forward to exploring more of Chile over the coming days (heading to Valpara√≠so tomorrow!)

What's your favorite city in South America? Let me know - I am curious what you all think!

#DrewBinsky #Chile #Santiago

description:

**I made this video 3 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

Let's talk about long layovers!

In my opinion (from years of travel experience), I can tell you that long layovers are THE BEST way to break up long travel days and have the chance to explore a new city for cheap.  I've had great experiences on long layovers in cities such as Istanbul, Doha, Dubai, Tokyo, Frankfurt, Addis Ababa, Nairobi and tons more! 

Did you know that at most major cities in China, you can get a FREE 72 hour transit visa if you have proof of an onwards flight? It's a great way to save the time & stress of applying for a Chinese visa.

This video documents my recent 18 hour layover in Beijing, as well as gives travel tips if you do the same.

In which city is your most memorable experience on a long layover?

title: How Do Time Zones Actually Work?
INSANE CASTLE of SYRIA (Krak des Chevaliers)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

WOAHHH!  I am so impressed by what I experienced today in Syria!  

Welcome to the Krak des Chevaliers -- it's considered as the world's most preserved medieval castle that sits in the South Western region of the country near Homs. 

It was built almost exactly 1,000 years ago, and despite being damaged a few years ago in the Syrian Civil War, it remains remarkably in tact.  It was a pleasure to explore the ins and outs of this castle today -- I was the only tourist here! 

The historical landmarks are just one of the MANY reasons why I have fallen in love with this Middle Eastern country.  Stay tuned for my last video in Syria tomorrow -- I saved the best for last!

title: World's FRIENDLIEST Taxi Drivers?... (SYRIA)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I've taken taxi rides in over 170 countries, and I have never EVER experienced more friendly drivers than here in Syria!  Seriously guys - I can't make this stuff up!  

Riding in a taxi in Syria is like being invited into someone's home for an amazing experience.  They offer you tea, candy and anything else they have in the car.  And most importantly, they smile at you and make you feel safe and comfortable!   

Also in this video, I didn't mention how CHEAP they are.  A 30 minute ride across the city is around $2USD.  Not a bad deal if you ask me!

If you're still reading this, I'd just like to extend an extra thank you to everyone who has watched, liked, commented and engaged in my Syria videos so far.  It's been incredible to experience this culture and hospitality first-hand.  It's one of my favorites in the world! More to come tomorrow.

title: She's Getting a Degree Around the World
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

This is the story of a young Spanish girl named Kenya, who is taking a much different approach to getting her college degree.   

Instead of staying on one campus, attending boring lecture halls and taking final exams -- her innovative schooling system, called Minerva, is 100% online and involves debating and learning REAL WORLD tactics.  There are 130 people in her class who come from 65 countries and they are constantly traveling, living in 7 different countries for 4 months at a time.  

I'd love to get your thoughts on whether you think this is the future of education or not?  I certainly think it is a lot more valuable than the "traditional colleges" that we know of today.

title: The 8th Wonder of the World? (NAN MADOL, MICRONESIA)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

WOWOWOW!  Have you ever heard of Nan Madol?  It's my favorite place in the Pacific Islands so far (and top 10 site in the world). 

Nan Madol is an ancient city built some 2,000+ years ago out of volcanic rock and sea coral on the Eastern shore of Pohnpei island in the country of Micronesia üá´üá≤ It‚Äôs something like Angkor Wat but on the middle of a remote island... 

It was a place for royalty gatherings as well as the burial site for the king and queen. I honestly hadn‚Äôt heard about it until a week ago when my friend mentioned it to me in Nauru, and I am completely blown away by what I have seen here. My friend and I were we were the ONLY ones around to explore and it is just fascinating.

Have you ever heard of Nan Madol before?  Add it to your list!

title: TRUE STORY: Surviving Both Wars in Syria & Iraq
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
üìù Join my Newsletter for free travel tips: https://bit.ly/3ebkR0Y

This story is a little bit of a different from my style, but it's one that I feel is incredibility necessary to share.  

While at a coffee shop in Baghdad, I met a young lady named Aya.  We sat down and starting chatting, and she started telling me the most somber and vivid stories about how she managed to survive BOTH the recent wars in Syria and Iraq.  I asked for her permission to interview her and share her story, and she was happy to do so because the world needs more empathy for the people of Iraq and Syria. 

Aya is one of the strongest, most resilient women I've ever met, and I hope you take away something powerful from this video.   And realize how good you have it. 

Thanks for watching, and I'll see you guys next week with a more positive story from Iraq.  For now, you can catch me on IG Stories for live updates from my trip! https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

Regardless of your views on Israel and Palestine, this video will widen your perspectives.

The duel-narrative tour that I just had around Jerusalem, by two native Jerusalemites ‚Äî Yuval (an Israeli Jew) and Samer (a Palestinian Muslim), was life changing, to say the least. It's extremely rare to get a duel-narrative tour of Jerusalem, and I learned more than I ever thought I'd know about the history and politics of Israel & Palestine.

From hearing their real-life stories of growing up in segregated Jerusalem, which challenges they've faced, and how they connect to certain parts of the city ‚Äî to witnessing them being friends and colleagues today, treating each other equally and with respect ‚Äî is very humbling and reassuring, and this experience has restored my faith in humanity.

I know there are more Yuvals and Samers out there, either living in Israel/Palestine or elsewhere in the world, who treat each other equally and respectfully, despite their religion and/or differences. Maybe ‚Äî just maybe ‚Äî this video will spark a light that will start a movement towards peace for Israel and Palestine. I sure hope so.

This video was by far the most challenging one I've made - from the planning stages, to the on-site shooting (i.e. security checkpoints) and especially, the tedious editing process which took me pretty much 2 full days. I am proud of how it turned out, and I truly hope your perspectives have been opened, or you've learned something new by watching this video.

I welcome your thoughts, opinions and constructive criticism (which I know this will get a lot of)‚Ä¶ But I'd like you to think twice about how you say things... If you are going to be an online troll ‚Äî full of hate and ignorance, and someone who causes further conflict through foolish comments ‚Äî then please turn your attention elsewhere. I know there are plenty of cat videos on YouTube that you'll probably enjoy ;)

I will only be responding to carefully thought-out comments, reactions and questions in this thread.

Thanks again for watching, and the best is yet to come :)

Music: Kevin MacLeod

title: El Salvador Needs to be on Your Bucket List
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Did you know that El Salvador is smaller than Massachusetts, but has HUNDREDS of volcanoes?!

I had the opportunity to visit El Salvador a few weeks ago on a tour with Salvadorean Tours, and I was blown away by the natural beauty, hospitable people and tasty food (hello #pupusas)! We went all over the country, hiking volcanoes, visiting small villages, touring big cities, etc -- and I loved every second of being there.

El Salvador, unfortunately, gets a bad reputation on the news & media for being unsafe, and therefore, many tourists avoid going there. I'm here to tell you not to listen to the news and come visit for yourself to see how truly spectacular this country is. I'm not saying crime doesn't exist there (crime is everywhere) -- but as long as you take normal precautions and use common sense (i.e. avoid dangerous areas at night), then you will be fine. Salvadorean People are warm and friendly, and almost everyone is open to having a genuine conversation.

I hope this video changes your perspectives on the beauty of El Salvador.

title: How FILIPINO is HONG KONG? (Domestic Helpers)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

If you've never been to Hong Kong, then you may never realize how many Filipinos are living here -- over 130,000 of them in total!

The vast majority of them are middle age Filipina women who are working here as domestic helpers.  The reason they come here is because they are able to earn 10X the salary as back home for the same job.  They are some of the most unselfish people you will ever meet because they make huge sacrifices to live here, like not being with their family and not keeping any of their hard-earned income for themselves. 

But nonetheless, they always put a smile on their face and will just warm your heart to be around!  Here is the fill story of Filipino domestic helpers of Hong Kong.

title: Be Thankful For Your Parents
description:
Dear Mom and Dad,

I love you guys more than anything in the world, and I will never be able to thank you enough for all you've done for me.  

You both have sacrificed a huge part of your life to give me opportunity to play competitive sports, attend a great college, study abroad (etc) ‚Äî and you've always supported my decision to travel the world and making a living online.

It's been an amazing past 2.5 weeks with you guys in Hong Kong, Macau, Bali, Phuket and Bangkok!   We've had so many fun memories that we will cherish forever, and I can't wait to see you again in a few months. 

To everyone else reading this, please take a moment to call your parents and/or loved ones today and say hi.  If anything, it will mean more to them than it will to you.

title: My First Time to JAKARTA
description:
After living in Asia since 2013, I have FINALLY made it to Indonesia's capital of JAKARTA!  Despite been in Jakarta for only 24 hours so far, I can confidently say that this city is VERY UNDERRATED.

All you hear about in regards to Jakarta is the extreme pollution and busy roads with the worst traffic in Asia.  I'm not going to deny that the traffic is miserable in Jakarta -- but there is a thriving life that I've thoroughly been enjoying!

From the delicious street food to crazy modern buildings, smiling faces and everything in between -- this video recaps my first time in Jakarta. 

Does anyone else out there also think Jakarta is underrated?  Please share your thoughts and comments on Jakarta below!

description:

OMG GUYS, I SERIOUSLY FOUND PARADISE in the Dominican Republic, and NO, it's not in Punta Cana or La Romana!

It's called Saman√° -- a peninsula way up in the North Eastern part of the country, home of 110,000 smiling faces and 6 MILLION palm trees.  That's approximately 54 palm trees for every 1 resident. 

I am really impressed by what I'm experiencing up here in Saman√°.  I've been to 190 countries and this is one of the most outstanding places in the world for pristine nature, awesome adventure and just life in general.  Do me a favor and visit Saman√° if you ever find yourself in the Dominican Republic, you won't regret it!

Special thanks Go Dominican Republic for helping make this trip possible, and to "That Jungle Life" for the extra footage.

title: She's Saving Her Culture (NIGER)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

It's time to put Niger on the map!

When I arrived in Niger yesterday, my 168th country, I was picked up at the airport by an Instagram friend named Aminata.  

Little did I know that she'd be one of the coolest people I've ever met in my life!

After living in Germany for the last 7 years, she was fed up when people would mistake her for being 'Nigerian' (the English-speaking country next door).  So she recently moved back to her hometown of Niamey, Niger to start an NGO promoting her country's culture and traditions.  In a sense, she is the one and only 'cultural ambassador' for her Niger and she is doing big things like organizing the first international cultural festival in August.

In our globalized world of fast-paced, cut-throat societies -- it's imperative for us to preserve our beautiful cultures, like Aminata is doing with Niger. 

Share this video to help Aminata's goal of putting her country on the map!  I may add, an amazing country that is :)

Follow me on Instagram for more stories! @DrewBinsky.  And Aminata's Insta is @SensaiCulture

title: The World's Happiest Country?! (GROSS NATIONAL HAPPINESS)
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Truthfully, I have never witnessed happier human beings than right here, in this lovely country called BHUTAN. 

Instead of using GDP to measure their country‚Äôs wealth and prosperity, they use GNH - GROSS NATIONAL HAPPINESS. (Seriously, this is not a joke!!!)

The 4 pillars of GNH are: 
- Sustainable development
- Environmental protection
- Cultural preservation
- Good governance 

Together, these 4 pillars have been ingrained in Bhutanese society since 1974, when King Jigme Singye Wangchuck created it. GNH has revolutionized the way in which this country operates, going far beyond happiness of its people. It has led to Bhutan becoming one of the greenest countries in the world and a global leader in sustainability. It's the ONLY country to have negative carbon emissions. This means that its forests absorb more carbon dioxide each year than its sources of pollution (factories) give out. How amazing is that? 

There is so much to admire about Bhutan, and it all stems from Gross National Happiness. 

Have any questions about visiting Bhutan? Comment below, and I'll be happy to help out!

title: How Tourism Changed Thailand
description:
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

DID YOU KNOW that Thailand gets 35 million visitors every year? Or that Forbes named Bangkok as the most popular city for international tourists? It's truly mind-blowing how many foreigners you will see on the streets of Bangkok, myself included. 

On one hand, mass tourism is good for Thailand's economy -- it pumps $100 BILLION USD annually into their society, which means better roads, better hospitals, more schools, more jobs and it gives the people a better overall quality of life.

But on the other hand, mass tourism brings MANY negative aspects to Thailand, which I discuss in detail in this video. 

What are your thoughts on mass tourism, not just for Thailand but for any country? Do you think it's a good or bad thing? Should we encourage it (like they do in Thailand), or take action to prevent it (like they do in Bhutan?!) Please share your thoughts below.

title: Inside Africa's Biggest Slum (Kibera) - Nairobi, Kenya
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Nairobi (Kenya) is a very complex, diverse city. The rich are REALLY rich, and the poor are REALLY poor. 

Today I took a trip to a district in Nairobi called Kibera, which is considered to be the biggest urban slum in Africa. More than 1 million people live within 2 square kilometers. 

I don't know how many videos it will take me to spread this message, but I can tell you with absolute certainty that people in impoverished areas are significantly happier than the wealthy. 

And overall, I've found Kenyan people to be the most heart warming, welcoming and friendly people in Africa (along with Malawians!) Have I mentioned that I love Nairobi?!

title: THE HITCHHIKER (Amazing Travel Story)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/
‚ñ∫ Daniels' YT: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCK9NRLlLN3IB0PRJAav39EQ

Have you ever hitchhiked before?  This is an incredible story about a 29 year old named Daniel, who spends his life hitchhiking around the world. 

From Mexico to Croatia to France, this guy LITERALLY relies 100% on the kindness of others to pick him up on the side of the road and take him to where he wants to go.   He was recently stranded in Albania because of COVID-19 and had to come back home to the U.S., but if there was no pandemic happening, then he would be heading all the way to Vietnam.  That's about 8,200 kilometers! 

Daniel has such an inspiring story that I know you will enjoy hearing, and I'm really glad we met.

On a personal note, I've only hitchhiked once in my life, from the Croatia/Bosnia border to a Bosnian town called Mostar, and it was an amazing experience.  I couldn't imagine the thrill of doing this every day!

If you have any hitchhiking stories, please share them below!

Manila is a city of contrasts, with some 21 million people in the metropolitan area, and about 5 million of them living in squatter's areas (slums).   

I have been living in Manila all summer long, and I wanted to make this video to show you a new side of Manila that you probably don't know exists.  

Making this video in Manila was a challenge, but it has been the most touching video I've made thus far.  

My idea was to bring food and school supplies to kids living in the San Andres Bukid Squatter's area of Manila ‚Äî where 120,000 people live within 1 square kilometer and on less than $1USD per day.  

I welcome your thoughts, comments and feedback on my video in Manila.

title: 11 Billion Tons of Ice Melted (TODAY IN GREENLAND)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

IT'S REALLY HOT IN GREENLAND RIGHT NOW... Like 15 degrees Celsius or 60 Fahrenheit. THIS IS NOT NORMAL.

Today alone, Greenland's ice sheet (the second largest on earth) lost a record 11 billion tons, which rose global ocean levels half a millimeter.   

It was bizarre to witness this first hand, as our Hurtigruten expedition explored the sea ice on small tender boats.  

No region on earth is more affected more by climate change than the polar regions, and you don't realize how big the issue is until you see it with your own eyes.  I made this video to raise awareness because it's up to us to fix it.  I am speechless by what I saw today.

Please share your thoughts, comments and suggestions on climate change.  I want to get some discussion going about what is happening right now on our lovely planet.

Join me on Instagram @DrewBinsky for daily travel content that is not shared on Youtube.

title: The World's GREENEST SHIP! (Battery Powered)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

HELLO FROM THE ARCTIC!  We've already seen 3 polar bears in their natural habitat!

Do you guys remember how much fun we had in Antarctica with Hurtigruten a few years ago?  We're back for round 2, but this time we are exploring some of the most remote areas on earth in North Eastern Greenland, followed by the wonders of Iceland. 

The innovative ship that we are currently on is called the MS Amundsen and it was completed just a few weeks ago. It's the world's first battery powered hybrid expedition cruise ship -- think of a Toyota Prius on the sea!  It's extremely impressive, and Hurtigruten is revolutionizing how we explore our oceans in the most sustainable way possible.

I can't wait to show you more of Eastern Greenland over the next few days!

‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Could you imagine your weekend being 1 day shorter?! ... Here in Iran, that‚Äôs the reality. 

Instead of Monday morning kicking off your work week, it is SATURDAY morning in Iran. And the work week ends on Thursday night, making Friday the one and ONLY day to spend your weekend.

When I think of Saturday's growing up, I think of them being spent at a sporting event or watching movies or relaxing on the beach -- not spent in an office! 

As I strolled around Tehran (capital city of Iran) early this Saturday morning, I was confused to see heavy traffic on the streets and the markets booming with life ‚Äî but nonetheless, it was a unique experience and that‚Äôs the beauty of travel. Because truth be told, the more I travel, the more I realize how little I actually know about the world. 

More to come from this beautiful country of Iran tomorrow!

title: I'm Jewish and I Love Muslims
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

As a Jew, and someone who has traveled extensively in Islamic countries, I can tell you honestly that Muslims are some of the most hospitable and friendly people in the world. The Middle East is one of my favorite regions to visit for this exact reason.

I get a lot of messages from people telling me to be 'careful' traveling through Muslim countries because I am Jewish... And I don't understand WHY they think this way. It doesn't matter whether you are Christian, Buddhist, Hindu or Jewish -- if you travel in Muslim countries, they will welcome you with open arms and food on the table.

I hope that this video teaches you a lesson that Muslims don't hate Jews, and vice versa. The world is a much more peaceful place than you may think. 

Anyone else agree?

title: DREW BINSKY DOCUMENTARY (Border 197: Coming Soon)
description:
ANNOUNCEMENT!! 

I am thrilled to tell you that I will be making a 90 minute documentary called BORDER 197,  which will be filmed from May 15 to mid-July during my final 6 countries of Palau, Saudi Arabia, Ghana, Ecuador, Venezuela and Jamaica.  

This is a project that I've been wanting to create for 4 years, since I knew I was going to every country, and after pitching it around to some of the best documentary filmmakers, I teamed up with an awesome guy named Chris Wedding.  He and another top-line cinematographer will be traveling with me as become one of the youngest people in history to visit every country.  

This documentary will NOT be anything like my daily travel videos, nor a compilation of my travels.  You've already seen that through my videos. 

Instead, the film will take you behind the scenes of what it's really like to visit every country.  It will be personal.  You will hear from my family and close friends.   It will discuss things that I don't ever tell you, like my severe anxiety.  It will reflect on my biggest realizations/takeaways from crossing 197 borders.  We will discuss how dedicated I am to work 15 hour days, 7 days a week for 3 straight years to create these videos, which have amassed 1.2 billion views.  We will talk about how social media has not only allowed me to finance my trips, but it has let me connect with amazing locals (YOU GUYS) -- and how I rely on their generosity to introduce me to their homeland.  We will dive deep into this 'every country' culture, as there are only ~ 200 people who have done it.  And TONS more!

If you want to stay up to date on our project, please follow us on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinskydocumentary

Chris will be sharing a lot of BTS on his Instagram as well: www.instagram.com/look_see_do

I will be investing a lot of my time, energy and money into this project throughout 2020, and I couldn't be more excited to share it with you!

THANK YOU!!

title: The Friendliest People on Earth (FILIPINOS!)
description:
There's a reason why I've been to the Philippines more than 30 times -- Filipinos are truly the friendliest people on earth!  

Yes, the beaches are amazing.  Yes, the coconuts are tasty.  Yes, the prices are cheap...

BUT IT'S THE FILIPINO PEOPLE'S over-the-top hospitality that stands out to me the most about this country.  

Regardless of where you go, you will be welcomed with open arms and smiling faces, and that is the Philippines' biggest asset.  It what keeps bringing me back here every time, and I am proud to call this country my second home. 

Share this video if you agree and you also love the Philippines!

description:

Before I came to Mexico on this trip, the first things that came to mind when thinking about the country were beaches, tacos, tequila, pyramids, and (sadly), cartels.   Even from an international standpoint, these are the things that Mexico is best known for...

But I'm here to change that narrative and let you know that MEXICO HAS SOME OF THE WORLD'S BEST HOSPITALITY!!  Earlier today in Oaxaca, I was invited into a household for a delicious home-cooked meal and I am just blown away by the friendliness and warmheartedness of this family.  I've never felt more comfortable in a strangers house before in my life. 
 
This dinner is only one example of the many experiences I've had in Mexico where the people are as kind and genuine as can be.   But today was special -- I am falling deeper and deeper in love with this country!

Share this video if you agree that Mexico has world class hospitality!

title: I'm Burning Out & Losing Hope
description:
The last 2 weeks have been the most stressful since I started making videos.  I'm burning out.

My views & engagement are at an all-time low, whether it's due to FB's annoying algorithm changes or my content has been uninteresting... or both. It's really frustrating when I put all my effort & energy into making these videos -- 17 hours a day -- and I'm not getting rewarded through the only measure I care about... views. 

This has nothing to do with money. My ultimate goal (since I started my first travel blog in 2012) has always been the same -- to inspire as many people as I can to travel the world. I want my content to reach eyeballs of people from all corners of our planet and I want to be a resource to help them plan trips and ultimately create lifelong memories. 

I hope that I will get out of this funk soon, or else, I may reconsider my career as a video maker. Or I might take a 5 weeks off during my upcoming Central Africa trip which starts on Monday. We'll see.

Thank you to all those who have stuck with me. I love you all

title: The Biggest Fish in India? (Chennai Fish Market)
description:
My alarm rang at 3:30AM this morning to see some fish at the Chennai Fish Market.  I jumped in a taxi and headed to the Chennai Fish Market ‚Äî one of the biggest fish markets in India ‚Äî to catch the wholesale auction‚Ä¶. and the fish were HUGE!

Over the years, I've enjoyed going to fish markets across Asia, from South Korea to Hong Kong to Japan‚Ä¶  but I've never seen chaos like I've seen this morning in Chennai.  

It's crowded.  It's grimy.  It's loud.  But it's all part of the experience, and I'm excited to share it with you in this video!

Would you ever go to an early morning fish market?  I highly recommend it for a different travel experience!

title: LAND OF 10,000 TEMPLES (Bagan, Myanmar)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

This is a video about one of the most spectacular places on planet earth.  It's a place called BAGAN in the Central part of MYANMAR.  I  came here once 5 years ago, and I am still blown away by what I am seeing!

In short, there were over 10,000 temples and pagodas built in Bagan between the 9th and 13th Centuries, and it was a center for Buddhism worship in South East Asia.  Today, about 2,700 of these temples remain, ALL IN ORIGINAL FORM, and they are scattered around an area that's 13 kilometers by 8 kilometers large.  It's the biggest UNESCO archeological site in the world.  

In my opinion, Bagan is 10X more enjoyable than the Angkor region of Cambodia because there's much less tourists here and you can freely roam around on your own to have these magnificent temples all to your self.  

Oh yeah, and I forgot to mention that every morning in Bagan is like a hot air balloon festival!  I highly recommend adding Bagan to the very top of your bucket list, and I promise you it won't disappoint!

Has anyone out there been to Bagan?  Can you back up my thoughts on how amazing it is?

Follow @DrewBinsky on IG Stories right now to see life here unfold behind the scenes: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: 27,000 Deaths a Year?! (Bangkok's Traffic Problem)
description:
If you've ever been to Bangkok, then you know how hectic the streets of Bangkok are. 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, the main roads of Bangkok are slammed with traffic jams -- tuk tuks, motorbikes, taxis, buses, bicycles and pedestrians honking their horns as they inch closer to their destination.

A recent study by the World Health Organization founds that Thailand is the world's second deadliest country in death rates by road accidents at ~27,000 per year. That's outrageous.

Driving on a motorbike taxi in Bangkok is one of the scariest experiences you can have -- especailly because they rarely provide you with a helmet -- but that's just how life unfolds in this bustling metropolis.

You'd think that traffic wouldn't be so bad because Bangkok has both an efficient overground AND underground metro system... but it doesn't seem to make any difference. What are your thoughts on how Bangkok (or any other city) can make the roads smoother? Please share your thoughts below.

title: THE TATTOO LADY
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

I've spent the last 24 hours living with the Embera tribe of Southern Panama, and the most fascinating things about this experience has been learning about their tattoo culture.   

They have this local fruit called JAGUA, which only grows on select trees in Central/South America.   The Emberas extract black juice from the fruit and use it as an ink that they paint their bodies with, and it stays active for about 2 weeks.   The geometric shapes and designs have been passed down from their ancestors, and they use it today as a sunscreen and shampoo as well.

This lady, named Lisa, is the main tattoo artist in her community of 24 families and so I wanted to make a story on her life because I find it to be incredible!

Anyone out there have a love for tattoos?   Please do share in the comments below!

title: LGBT Pride in Timor-Leste?
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

This is a special video and a touching story. 

While in Timor-Leste, I got connected with a local named Nata. He‚Äôs a really cool and friendly guy, who has been kind enough to take me around his country! 

Nata and his youth group, Hatutan, recently started a LGBT pride parade in the small country of Timor-Leste, which has been making international headlines. Their movement has provided an opportunity to promote social inclusion for everyone in a country where LGBT people have struggled to gain family/social acceptance. 

Their first pride parade was held last year, which attracted 500+ people and was so powerful that it brought in support from the previous Prime Minister. They are already planning their second pride to happen this coming June. 

I really admire Nata's approach to make an impact in his country‚Äôs society, so I sat him down to question him and learn more about his story. 

This is the longest video I've ever made, at nearly 5 minutes, and also the hardest I've spent editing... I hope you enjoy it as much as I enjoyed making it.

Special thanks to PixelAsia and FilmDeit Productions for the extra footage, and to Nata & his friends who helped make this video happen.  Music: Epidemic Sound

title: He Helps Afghan Refugees
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

I'm glad Sayed reached out to me on Instagram when I came to Reykjav√≠k, Iceland, because his story is very inspiring and needs to be shared with the world.

Sayed himself is a refugee from Afghanistan, who has gone through a very rough childhood that I wish nobody has to experience. 

He was forced to flee his country at 14 after the Taliban destroyed his school, killed his uncle and paralyzed his brother.

Eventually, he made his way to Iceland (via Turkey, Greece and Holland) and he was just granted asylum here for 4 years.  Awesome news!

But perhaps the most inspiring thing about Sayed is how he strives to help other innocent refugees seek asylum and assimilate into Icelandic society, because he is a giver. 

This guy really has a heart of gold, and I can't wait to catch up with him the next time I come to Reykjav√≠k.

title: THE KISSING SOUND of MYANMAR (what is it?)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

If you come to Myanmar, then prepare yourself to hear the kissing sound in restaurants, on random street corners and pretty much anywhere you go around this country!  

At first, you might think it's an inappropriate form of 'cat calling,' but in reality, it's simply a way to get someone's attention.  All you do is simply make a kissing sound two or three times in the direction of the person you want to speak with, and they instantly turn around -- like magic! 

The kissing sound is one of the most unique things about Burmese culture, and honestly speaking, it makes ordering anything in a restaurant a lot more fun!!   

The bigger moral of this story is about having cultural awareness and etiquette when traveling in foreign countries.  You will often see or experience things that may not be normal to you, but are completely regular in other cultures.  And if you ask me, that's the beauty of travel!  

Thank you @Corona for sponsoring this video.

description:

Today I am excited to share with you the story of Adam, who is a paraplegic hiker from Malaysia.   He got polio at a young age and became paralyzed from the waist down, but it never stopped him from living a normal life and pursuing his dreams. 

He is a recent college graduate, a motivational speaker and is the first person in history to summit Mount Everest Base Camp without using legs.   He crawled all the way up with his arms.

title: The World's FRIENDLIEST People! (IRAN)
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Out of all my travels in 137 countries, it is right here, in Iran, where I have found the most hospitable and friendly people. Complete strangers coming up to me on the street, from big cities to small towns, offering me a cup of tea in their shop or a bed to sleep in their home. 

I'm convinced that I could come to Iran with $0 in my pocket and easily be able to make friends, find delicious meals and be welcomed in a comfortable home like family. Seriously, it‚Äôs almost like Iranian people force you into their homes (in a good way!)

Over the last 2 weeks, I‚Äôve told dozens of Iranians that I am both American and Jewish, and contrary to what you may think, it makes them like me even more, peaking their interest and asking more questions. I have not felt a minuscule of negative hostility yet from anyone in this lovely country called Iran.

Also, as I have now published 10 videos about Iran so far -- it really makes me laugh when I read some of the comments and hear people calling my videos "propaganda." These videos are the farthest thing away from propaganda!!! They are telling you the downright truth from my experiences in Iran. Nobody told me to make this video (or any video). I made this because I feel the need to share what I am seeing to you. And I hope that by watching this video (and my others about Iran) -- that you will remove your negative stereotypes about this humble nation and realize that it's one of the safest and best places to visit on our planet.

If you have ever been to Iran, and you agree with what I am saying, then please share your thoughts or a quick moment/story from your experience with the people here. I want the entire world to know!!!

title: Big Update on ‚ÄúSouth Sudan Cow Tribe‚Äù Video #travel
World's Cheapest Michelin Star Restaurant (DIM SUM)
description:
Today in Hong Kong, my local buddy Uptin Saiidi and I ate dim sum at the world's cheapest Michelin-star restaurant called Tim Ho Wan's.  Our entire meal was less than $10 each - for dim sum!

Tim Ho Wan's started 9 years ago as a hole-in-the-wall dim sum restaurant in Mong Kok - the busiest district of Hong Kong.  The dim sum is so freaking tasty that it has expanded to more than 50 locations in dozens of countries over the last decade. And it's so damn inexpensive!

It blows my mind how food can be THIS GOOD and THIS CHEAP in one of the world's most expensive cities... But I am surely not complaining!

Have you ever heard of Tim Ho Wan's?  Or tried dim sum before?  Can anyone back me up by how good it is?

title: Driving 4,000 KM with Sister | WHAT I LEARNED
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1

ROAD TRIP WITH SISTER ACROSS EUROPE!

My little sister, Amanda, and I just wrapped up an amazing 18-day road trip from Rome to Amsterdam -- covering 10 countries, 16 cities and driving over 4,000 kilometers!

This trip was a graduation present to her for becoming an eye doctor (after spending the last 20 years of her life in school), and it's also her very first time in Europe.  We had an absolute BLAST every day and night, exploring (and eating) our way from city to city.   

Here is a recap video that I made of our trip, along with some of the most important things I learned from this adventure.  It will be fun to rewatch this video in several years down the line!

Love you, sis!

title: He Traveled 15,000 KM Solo by Land
description:
Today I had the pleasure of meeting an amazing 23 year old traveler from Thailand named Petch, who just finished a solo trip going overland from Bangkok to Morocco -- that's 15,000+ kilometers over 115 days and 29 countries.  

Wow.

He's aiming to be the first Thai-born person to visit every country in the world, and he's well on his way to achieve his goal!

Would you have the guts to go on a trip like that?  I'm not sure I do... too lonely and too long without wifi üòÖ

title: The World's Most Unique Tribes!
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me @drewbinsky!

There are many reasons why I am addicted to traveling, but none is bigger than my admiration of indigenous cultures. 

I thoroughly enjoying traveling to far away places and discovering ways to connect with local people -- observing how they live, what they eat and how they carry on their traditions generation after generation.  And guess what?  My biggest realization from doing this over the last 7 years is that ALL PEOPLE ARE THE SAME.

Join me in today's video where I take you on a journey to learn about the 5 most unique tribes I've met in my travels, from Namibia to Ethiopia to Thailand to Yemen and Swaziland.

As our world quickly becomes more globalized, fewer and fewer indigenous people remain every day.  It's our responsibility (as tourists)  to protect their environments and traditions, because they live in the most simple and sustainable way possible. And frankly, their cultures, languages and customs are incredible.

title: How JAPANESE is BANGKOK?!
description:
One of the things I love so much about Bangkok is the diversity.

Similar to NYC and London, you can get anything you want here at any time of the day. Especially in regards to food - name a country's cuisine and you can find multiple places to get it in this sprawling metropolis.

Many of you may already know my love and desire for Japan, as I've been 7 times and itching to go back again. I am addicted to their futuristic, tech savvy and innovate way of life -- and of course, their food is amongst the world's best.

Today, I met up with my Japanese friend Yusuke, who is a resident of Bangkok, and he took me to some of his favorite Japanese spots in town. Join us to see how Japanese we can live for a day in Bangkok!

title: THE BEST MAKE UP? (Thanaka in Myanmar)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM? Join me: https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

Perhaps the most noticeable (and beautiful) thing about the culture of Burma (Myanmar) is the white/yellow paste on people's faces -- mostly women and children -- and it's seen everywhere!

This magical stuff is called THANAKA and it's been around in Burmese culture for over 2,000 years.   It's essentially a natural paste that is derived from a very specific tree bark, and it really enhances the beauty of the people here!

Have you ever heard of thanaka before?  This is one of the MANY reasons why you should add Myanmar to the top of your bucket list -- this country is truly amazing inside and out! üá≤üá≤üá≤üá≤

title: The Best Neighborhood in BANGKOK?!
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

We've spent the last few days exploring our new neighborhood in Bangkok, and we couldn't be happier!! It's literally PERFECT for us :D

Bangkok is THE city of CONVENIENCE -- Within a 5 minute walk from our building, there are (literally) hundreds of street food vendors, dozens of massage places, five 7-Elevens, 2 shopping malls, a co-working space (our new office), a Muay Thai gym (where I train daily), a big swimming pool, and the BTS (metro) station that takes us downtown in 5 stations. Not bad at all, considering we each pay $225/month in rent!

I am so excited to make daily videos around Bangkok. Yesterday I stayed up up all night writing down ideas for video topics in my phone! Do you have any ideas for videos you want to see here? Please let me know in the comments below.

title: HE SWALLOWS SWORDS (amazing talent!)
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

*DO NOT TRY THIS AT HOME*

Ladies and Gentlemen, it's my pleasure to introduce you to Dan Meyer  - one of the world's only remaining sword swallowers üó°Ô∏è  

I first discovered Dan Meyer Sword Swallower after seeing his finalist performance on America's Got Talent a few years ago, and when I found out that he lives in Phoenix, I had to meet him and hear his story!

It took Dan 14,000 unsuccessful attempts before getting his first sword down in 2001, and since then, he has remarkably made a living traveling around the world and performing on game shows, private gatherings, concerts, competitions and more.   He has over 40 world records, most impressively, swallowing 29 swords at once!

But his road to get here was not easy...  Dan grew up with severe social anxiety disorder and was the target for bullies in his school.   Watch the video to find out how he broke out of his shell and went on to "do the impossible!"

title: Ice Cream of the Future? (Thai Ice Cream Rolls)
description:
Any ice cream lovers out there?  Please allow me to introduce you to one of Thailand's greatest inventions... THAI ICE CREAM ROLLS!

They are exactly what they sound like -- little rolls of flavored ice cream, about the diameter of a quarter, packed into a cup and topped with all sorts of delicious toppings like hot fudge, coconut shavings, toasted marshmallow, fresh fruit and/or gummy bears.

Thai Ice Cream Rolls are way better than they sound in words.  Trust me. 

I've been wanting to make a video about ice cream rolls since I moved to Thailand in June -- so here it is and I hope you enjoy :)

Share this video if you've tried (or want to try) Thai ice cream rolls!

title: I Stayed With 2 Snapchat Followers in Morocco
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Social media has changed my life. 

Thanks to Snapchat, I've connected with two amazing people in Morocco who hosted me at their family's houses over the last 5 days. Saad, in El Jadida, and Hajar, in Casablanca. 

I cannot even begin to tell you how amazing this experience has been!

10 years ago, or even 5 years ago (when Snapchat was founded), it would have not been possible to meet Saad and Hajar. If it wasn't for social media, I would have never met their wonderful families, eaten their delicious home-cooked meals, slept in their comfortable beds or enjoyed the presence of their smiling faces. 

I am very grateful for the times we live in. Many people see our "social media" generation as a disaster, that we are constantly glued to our phones all day long, etc. But I will always argue against them. What has happened to me over the last 5 days in Morocco is a perfect example. I am living proof. Social media (i.e. Facebook) has also connected me with you. 

What's your take on our 'social media generation?' Have you met others through social media on your travels?

P.S. -- I'd like to let all of you know that Arabic hospitality is truly the best in the world. I've never been treated with more respect and sincerity than in Arabic countries. Similar situations have happened to me in Kuwait, Oman, Jordan and Bahrain.

title: WHAT'S A MARIACHI? üá≤üáΩ
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

There are a lot of things that I love about Mexico, and the MARIACHI culture is certainly one of them!

In short, mariachi is a genre of Mexican music that involves a group of men playing violin, trumpet, guitar, harp and taking turns on the vocals.  They are available for hire to serenade you in plazas, restaurants and street corners around Mexico. 

Today, I went to the famous Plaza Garibaldi (Mariachi Square) and my mind was completely blown!!!  If you come to Mexico, don't miss out on this!

**I made this video 2.5 years ago, but only shared it to Facebook...so I wanted to post it for all you guys here on YouTube!  Please excuse the fast paced editing and shaky camera -- I was a newbie back then**

NEWSFLASH: The Czech Republic is MORE than just Prague!

We spent all day frolicking around my favorite small town in Europe - ƒåesky Krumlov! It's my 3rd time in this town and it's truly as good as it gets -- the sun was shining, and we were able to see the autumn trees in full bloom!

ƒåesky Krumlov is a tiny town in the southern tip of the Czech Republic that is famous for its 13th Century Castle and historic old town -- both of which are listed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Not to mention, the windy alleyways, open air markets, outdoor cafes along the river, and artsy boutique stores are fantastic! 

After watching this video - you'll see why I rave about this town and I will 100% be back for a 4th visit in the coming years.

title: He Has Saved 1 Million People Living in Extreme Poverty
description:
This story will make you smile :)

It's about a 70-year-old Priest, Father Pedro, and how he has given a life to over 1 MILLION people who are living in extreme poverty in Antananarivo, Madagascar. An Argentinean native, Pedro first came to Madagascar in 1970, and after witnessing some of the world's most brutal living conditions -- he decided to do something about it. 

So in 1989, he raised ‚Ç¨900 from Christian missionaries to create a community called Akamasou -- which offers jobs, schools and a better life for the people living in extreme poverty. Year after year, Pedro got more funding as the word spread about his initiative. 

Today, Akamasou is a massive self-sufficient town which sustains more 25,000 people regularly, and has provided food, shelter & clothes to over a million people since opening its doors 30 years ago. 

Pedro's philosophy is, "If you are not willing to work (or study), then you are not allowed to eat." And once you join his community, you are offered a very nice house and life than is unparalleled to living on the streets of the city. 

Today has been one of the best travel memories of my life. Thank you Pedro for hosting me, and thank you to my local friends Ali, Dave, Nancy and Antonio for driving me here and helping translate from French to English! 

I don't ask you to share my videos often, but if you enjoyed this one, please share it so more people can hear this inspiring story.  It will take a global effort to end extreme poverty.

title: I FOUND MARS ON EARTH (NAMIBIA)
description:
I have never been to Mars, but I imagine that it would look very similar to what I have seen today in Namibia. 

Seriously guys! I am still in shock by what I have just experienced in the world's oldest desert, dating back 80 million years... But that's not even the coolest part. 

Namibia's desert is home to the largest and tallest SAND DUNES on earth -- reaching up to 1,200 feet high. I spent all day trekking around these dunes and I am left speechless. 

HAVE YOU EVER BEEN TO NAMIBIA? If not, then add it to your list!

title: Entering The World‚Äôs Scariest Airport
Surviving in the Iranian Desert? (Yazd, Iran)
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Could you survive in the middle of a desert as hot as Iran, with no electricity, limited water and temperatures often over 45C (113F)? Now try to imagine doing that in Iran, 1,800 years ago!

Here in Yazd, Iran -- I‚Äôve learned the different methods for how ancient humans in this area survived dating back to the 3rd Century. To get water, they would dig a system of deep underground tunnels (up to 300 meters deep) to find wells, and somehow, find a way to funnel down the water into the towns. 

It‚Äôs summer right now in Iran, and let me tell you, it‚Äôs BLISTERING HOT outside here. Reminds me of summers back home in Phoenix, Arizona. I cannot imagine the struggles these people went through to survive. 

Putting the history aside, the old town of Yazd is stunning with the most beautifuly-crafted blue-tiled mosque and a thriving shopping scene at the bazaar! 

Have you ever heard of Yazd, or been here to Iran before? Let me know in the comments below!

Hi guys! I finished my second trip to HA LONG BAY - the mystical place where 1,969 limestone islands are scattered around a giant bay in Northeastern Vietnam. It's one of the 7 Wonders of the World, a UNESCO site, and in my opinion, the top 5 most stunning displays of nature on our planet.

In this video, I take you around Ha Long Bay (with my brand new Panasonic Lumix GH!) and teach you some interesting facts about what I've discovered.

Do me a favor and add Ha Long Bay to your bucket list if you haven't been already -- You can take a 2 day/1 night all-inclusive trip from Hanoi for as cheap as $40 per person.

title: 5 Reasons Why TRAVEL is the BEST EDUCATION I've Ever Had
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

I spent 18 years of my life in classrooms, followed by 6 years of my life traveling nonstop. There is no question that I've learned more & become wiser over the last 6 years of travel, than the previous 18 in classrooms. 

The act of TRAVELING -- anywhere -- means pushing your limits, broadening your mind and expanding your knowledge. 

Through visiting 136 countries, I've learned how to be independent. I've discovered hidden things about historical places. I've learned how the world works, how to appreciate other cultures, and how to use common sense to figure my way out of any situation. These life-long skills are impossible for any professor to teach.

In this video, which has clips from 37 countries, find out 5 reasons why TRAVEL is the best education I've ever had. Does anyone else out there agree with me?

title: We've Arrived in Our 7th Continent.. TOGETHER!
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

Earlier this morning, Deanna and I arrived in MAURITIUS, which means that we have officially visited all 7th Continents TOGETHER (Yes, Mauritius is a country in Africa and yes, we went to Antarctica last October!) 

It's been incredible to see the world by her side, and we are thrilled to be able to say that we've experienced 42 countries and 7 continents together. 

HOW DID WE DO THIS?

While it may not appear this way from the the outside (i.e. watching videos) -- we both work VERY HARD online behind the scenes to make our dreams become a reality. We are behind our computer screens 8-10 hours a day, grinding in coffee shops, hotel lobbys, airport lounges and anywhere else where there is a wifi signal. We fund 100% of our travels through our online jobs. 

I am not making this video to brag, but to hopefully inspire some of you that you can do this too if you set your mind towards it.

Words cannot express how sincerely I've been treated so far in Malawi -- by every single person I've come in contact with. Malawi is the most laid back, peaceful and genuine place I've been over the last 4 weeks in Africa.

title: THEY GOT MARRIED IN A #BLM PROTEST
description:
‚ñ∫ SUBSCRIBE for daily travel videos: http://bit.ly/2hyQnZ1
‚ñ∫ INSTAGRAM for more! https://www.instagram.com/drewbinsky/

This is one of the most amazing stories I've ever had the pleasure of telling you!!!  

Meet Lara and Sam - two incredible people who fell in love and had a wedding scheduled for May 31, 2020.  Little did they know that we would be in the middle of a pandemic, so they arranged a beautiful marriage in front of their house in Los Angeles, California. 

Even more surreal was the timing -- during their wedding night was one of the largest protests for #BlackLivesMatter on the streets of L.A... So Lara and Sam (in full wedding attire) decided to take their celebration to the street with thousands of people cheering them on. 

You can't plan things like this.  They just happen.  I'm so happy that I was able to meet and tell their story, and I hope it can bring you happiness among these unpleasant days!

Follow @Drew Binsky for more inspiring stories like this one.  Instagram: https://instagram.com/drewbinsky

title: Carving Wood for 47 Years?
description:
Earlier today, in the middle of a small Sri Lankan village, I met a guy named Dhramadsa who has been carving wood for 47 years!   

I spontaneously sat him down to hear about his life story, and I was shocked to find out that he's been at this wood carving job for nearly a half-century!

This is not your ordinary wood carvings... Dhramadsa molds the most detailed animal sculptures (elephants, tigers, etc) starting with an empty block of wood.   Each piece takes him roughly 2 weeks of work (nonstop), and he sells them in local markets for around $100 USD each.   

Does he do it for the money?  Absolutely not.  It's just hobby that keeps him busy.  He's very content living a simple life in his beautiful village, and he plans to carve wood until he dies!

Instagram @drewbinsky for daily travel content!!  Thank you Michael (IG @affinityadventure) for the help shooting & editing!

title: I've Expanded by 100% :)
description:
ANNOUNCEMENT: I am thrilled to say that the "Drew Binsky Team" has just expanded by 100% with the addition of Michael -- a cinematographer, editor and all around great guy from Ottawa, Canada. 

About 4 months ago, I made a video calling for a videographer & editor to travel with me and help improve my videos. After going through roughly 500 applicants, Michael's work stood out the most and it's very exciting to have him here in Bangkok (his first time in Asia)!

He will be traveling with Deanna and I for (at least) the next few months. From Thailand to the Philippines, Indonesia, India, Sri Lanka and who knows where else we will be. 

Don't panic, because my video content, style and storytelling will remain exactly the same -- but you will see major improvements in the cinematography with cleaner shots, transitions, sound design and beyond. 

This is a huge step forward in my career, and I couldn't be more thrilled to see what we can do together. Two brains are always better than one.

title: They Are Unifying Malaysia!
description:
In this world, there are people with national pride... And then there's Faye and Rachel, who take it to the next level.

Do you remember the Malaysia Airline Flight 370, which went missing back in 2014? Well, after that incidence, these two ladies were fed up from all the negativity & hate that their beloved country (Malaysia) was getting... So, in effort to better unify their diverse nation, they created a movement called The Rojak Projek, where they traveled to every region in Malaysia to make colorful portraits of people by using FOOD as the ART. 

Over the last 3 years, they have already made 540 food portraits around Malaysia, and they are wrapping up on their 550th to honor Malaysia's 55th birthday coming up in a few weeks. 

Faye and Rachel's story is one of the most innovative and impactful I've witnessed. They are opening so many doors for the togetherness of Malaysian people, as well as sending a positive message to the outside world -- and I'm happy that I got to experience it first hand. 

To end this script on an unrelated note... I LOVE MALAYSIA!!!

Music: Ben Sound

title: Inside look of the Biggest Slum in Mumbai (DHARAVI)
description:
üì≤ My JUST GO APP is here! Connect w/ travelers for free: https://apple.co/3vYPr75 
‚úÖ SUBSCRIBE for more travel videos: https://bit.ly/3iAZlnw

In Mumbai, India, I took a tour of the biggest slum in the world called Dharavi.  

Also made famous by the movie Slumdog Millionaire, Dharavi has well over 1 million people living in a space that's half the size of Central Park in NYC. Walking through Dharavi was the most eye-opening and real experience that I've ever had. At first, I was nervous and I thought it'd be unsafe and scary, but I was proven wrong. I learned how productive the people work and how much this slum produces to the Indian economy. Everything there is VERY well organized with industrial factories and residential neighborhoods. Dhravi is over a billion-dollar industry, using recycled foods to produce everything from aluminum to leather to pottery, and they make everything by hand. The poverty levels and dirty streets are nothing like I've seen in my life, with most people working 15 hours a day in extreme hot weather for just $1-3 USD per day. But above all, most people didn't seem unhappy. I saw hundreds of smiling faces on the kids as they were giving me hi-fives when I walked past them. It was both humbling and mentally exhausting and something I'll never forget. I think everyone should see Dharavi with their eyes because then you'll begin to appreciate how much you have in life.

For more, check out my travel blog http://thehungrypartier.com/

title: He's the Monster Man!
description:
Meet Georgio -- the man who makes a living by drawing monsters on his phone.  AKA the Monster Man!

Georgio and I met online (via Snapchat) 3 years ago because we both got a head start as a creator on the platform. I've been telling him for years that I was gonna visit him in Lebanon, and I finally did! We met (in person) for the first time 4 days ago, and we get along so well that I can already tell we will be friends for life.

I'm guessing you already know something about him already, as he's been in my last 3 videos around Lebanon, but his artistic talents are so unique that I wanted to share with you how he makes a living -- by drawing monsters on his phone!

Side note: We live in such a cool generation. I am seeing more and more people turning their passion into careers than ever before. We are collectively finding ways to work creatively, remotely and efficiently using the internet. Cheers to all of the "Georgios" out there who are following their dreams!

Music: Epidemic Sound

P.S. THANK YOU to Georgio and his family for giving me the best tour of Lebanon ever. Check out his mind-blowing art on Instagram @georgio.copter.
